pageElements.text: April is the cruelest month only to poets and those who don't live in the frozen North. For Michiganders like us, April is filled with the promise of great drives and vacation destinations to plan, daffodils to watch for, and nurseries to visit for flats of pansies to plant.
With that in mind, here are ten places I went on the Internet while going to imaginary summer places in my mind.

1. Is this the year for your great drive? Automobile Magazine has just taken this year's ten All-Stars on one. Follow them from the Great Lakes to the Gulf of Mexico in this absorbing tale, and get inspired.

image.altText: Berlin Metro Subway U Bahn Map 1000

pageElements.text: 2. Once you get to the city of your dreams, can you figure out the subway system? Here's an artful rethinking of the subway maps of the world's great capitals, from an architect named Jug Cerovic, who's based in Paris. You can't stop looking at them, but they're simplified and clarified so you won't have to spend all your time, you know, looking at them to find your way around.

3. Or maybe you're thinking about something closer to home. Rand McNally's Best of the Road website breaks down trips into small bites: over ten and under 300 miles, with up to a dozen attractions to see. Choose your general vicinity, and get out there.
4. We're all in favor of planning ahead, but this college prof is serious buzzkill. Keep scrolling (and scrolling) to see the hundreds of warnings to would-be travelers.
5. Watch that food budget, hipsters. There's now a $100 grilled cheese sandwich in Chicago, $4 for toast in San Francisco...
6. When really, the new "foodie destination" is....spoiler alert: It has devils, but it's not hell. Just about as far away, but not hell.
7. Have you backpacked through Europe? Or just wish you had? Take this quiz and see how you measure up.
8. While driving in the U.K., there's more than just the "wrong side of the road" to think about. No sex, please, they're British.

9. Words of travel wisdom from the addictive blog of a twentysomething woman who quit her job to wander the world solo. Permission granted to be a cheesy tourist on your travels this summer. "The main reason why places are touristy is because they deserve tourists! Stop worrying about how other people think of you—and start taking some goofy pictures."
10. You didn't have to tell these people twice. Here are my favorite on-the-road pix from Pinterest: the Winner. The Runner-Up. The Best involving Kids. and the Best GIF.

pageElements.text: If you read A Teenager's First Road Trip last week, you know that I'm a high school junior and I was just given the privilege of being put in charge of planning a cross-country road trip with my mom. (Also click back for Day 1, and Days 2/3.) We're on that trip now, and here's how it's going:

image.altText: on the road memphis to nashville

pageElements.text:
Day 4: Memphis to Nashville

My mom and I spent the morning exploring Memphis's Cooper-Young neighborhood. She loves to shop and will skip meals so that she doesn’t waste precious time. I convinced her to stop at Java Cabana and split a muffin. She agreed to the stop, but we got it to go so that we could press on.
We popped in and out of shops, and we both absolutely loved the House of Mews. It was closed, but dozens of cats were loose inside, with no human in sight.

image.altText: on the road memphis to nashville

pageElements.text: Our very best find was Memphis Drum Shop. I don’t even play the drums, but we managed to spend an hour checking out the goods. By the time we loaded up the bright red GMC Terrain, it was two o’clock. Since it is three hours to Nashville, we needed to seriously get moving.

Now that we have logged 650 miles, we are nearing the halfway point. Both front seats are eight-way power with lumbar, and the best part is that they are heated. It is shocking how exhausting just sitting can be, but these seats are literally saving my ass.

image.altText: on the road memphis to nashville

pageElements.text: On Saturday I am going to the Miley Cyrus concert in Michigan, so I have been listening to her a lot on our drive. The Monsoon speakers are awesome, but my mom is constantly turning it down. We have spent some time with it cranked up loud, and it sounds real good.

My midafternoon I was starved, and since we were in a hurry we stopped at a McDonald’s. My mom explained how when she is traveling alone she always uses their bathrooms rather than rest areas. She thinks they are safer. This McDonald’s was actually really nice, and the bathrooms were exceptionally clean. The food however was, well, you know, just as expected. We ate it in the car. How very American of us. I actually prefer sitting down and taking a break.

We noticed that Tennessee drivers are a touch more aggressive than their neighbors farther to the south. As we flew down the highway, a warning came on the screen that there was a camera in the area. We thought that was odd on the highway but appreciated the heads up and slowed down to the posted speed.

At one point we came to an area where the highway was under construction—no shocker. They had dug grooves into the road, like a rake in a Zen garden. We could still drive regular speeds, but the Terrain was slipping all over the road, like we were driving on ice. My mom was relieved when it was finally over.

We watched the gas gauge, and when it slipped below a quarter of a tank, we filled up. (Not like yesterday.) My mom shared stories of running out of gas over the years. Note to self: never let the level dip below a quarter of a tank. I do not want to be stranded on a highway or in a questionable neighborhood.

Our Airbnb host for the night asked us to meet her at her vintage shop in East Nashville, the Pony Show. Both my mom and I were psyched because we love vintage finds, and the pictures of her house were straight out of an Anthropologie catalog.
At one point we came to an area where the highway was under construction—no shocker. They had dug grooves into the road, like a rake in a Zen garden.

We arrived to Nashville right at rush hour, but luckily every time we made a turn we missed the heavy traffic. Winning. We pulled up to the Pony Show and it was exactly what we expected. From used cowboy boots to funky antler necklaces—we swooned over the merchandise. It was nearing six, so we drove the short distance to the Airbnb house and unloaded for the night. Again, we absolutely loved it. From the vintage sewing machines to the turntable and vintage albums,  we were sold. Every inch of the house was full of little knickknacks, and most definitely Anthropologie. Love was in the air.

image.altText: on the road memphis to nashville

pageElements.text: We quickly drove two minutes to a shopping district, checked out a few stores, and finally sat down to eat a meal at a Mexican restaurant called Rosepepper Cantina. Great food, great atmosphere, full of hipsters, and those are all good things. This may be my favorite vibe so far.
Back to our lovely home for the night. Perhaps I will look for colleges in Nashville.

title: A New York Auto Show State of Mind
subTitle: What this show means to New York, and the world. A preview.

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: The New York Auto Show is the country’s oldest, most-well attended auto show. It's also proof that you don’t need to have a car—or even a driver’s license—to be intrigued by the promise of new car designs.

Only 23 percent of Manhattanites actually own a car. When the compass spreads to include all five boroughs, about 1.4 million out of 3 million households actually own a car. This is small potatoes compared with the rest of the country, where most households own and drive cars as a matter of necessity.

Cars in New York City clearly aren’t a matter of practicality, which makes them all the more appealing. It’s costly to park here, driving is often slower than taking the subway, and this spring the potholes are particularly atrocious. Drivers share the lanes with cabs, bike lanes, and pedestrians, none of whom think you’re as tough as they are—and will cut you off in your lane to prove it.
Automobiles are another stopping point on the culture calendar in a city that prides itself on insomnia. And brands are in competition to make their imprint.

However, what is considered rare is also a delicacy. Cars in New York capture the psychological appeal of exotic goods. Simply put: people are curious about what they don’t—but could—have. It’s part of why New Yorkers love a theme week, whether it’s fashion, films in Tribeca, or seasonal art auctions. Automobiles are another stopping point on the culture calendar in a city that prides itself on insomnia. And brands are in competition to make their imprint.

The most anticipated moment at the upcoming show is the unveiling of a Mustang that will hang over Manhattan. In the re-creation of a 1965 car stunt, the Ford Motor Company will hoist a 2014 Mustang to the top of the Empire State Building. The climb coincides with the pony car’s fiftieth anniversary and the New York Auto Show media preview days. And this year the show will feature several never-before-seen models: Dodge’s Challenger and Charger, the raring Mercedes-Benz S63 AMG, Subaru’s flagship Outback, a new Murano by Nissan, Toyota’s mid-cycle refresh of the Camry, and a slew of BMWs from the rip-roaring M4 to the X4. Attention in New York gives brands incentives to reserve space for splashy events at the city’s endless array of hot spots to woo producers and editors who often do not drive themselves.
New York City legitimizes the pulse of trends. It’s built on clichés about power, ambition, grit, and glamour, and most of these truisms hold up.

New York City legitimizes the pulse of trends. It’s built on clichés about power, ambition, grit, and glamour, and most of these truisms hold up. It helps that several luxury brands have their East Coast outposts here: Mercedes-Benz, Jaguar Land Rover, and BMW. Ford and General Motors both have New York City offices. Let’s not forget about Wall Streeters who work in New York but actually live in car-friendly Greenwich, Connecticut, where Porsche Cayennes are built for the average grocery getter.

For borough dwellers and Westchester County and Jersey drivers, the auto show is a reason to go to “the city.” Tri-staters love a reason to go the city. The New York Knicks don’t give much consistent incentive to their fans,  and the improved Javits Center is square in the heart of the West Side. The auto show is a sneak peek to the road of the future. And real New Yorkers know that everything comes to New York that matters, even if it doesn’t.
The New York International Auto Show press preview days are April 16 and 17. The show is open to the public from April 18–27.

title: Volvo Inflatable Child Seat
subTitle: Safety-forward automaker does it again with a concept for a child seat you can truly take with you.
promoTeaserSmall: Safety-forward automaker does it again with a concept for a child seat you can truly take with you.
promoTeaser: Safety-forward automaker does it again with a concept for a child seat you can truly take with you.
metaDescription: Volvo Inflatable Child Seat: Safety-forward automaker does it again with a concept for a child seat you can truly take with you. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: There's nothing quite as essential as a child safety seat in the car: required by law, for one thing, and an absolutely indispensable piece of safety equipment to protect your child, for another. But wrestling it in and out of the car, let alone lugging it through the airport or into a rental car or taxi, is one of parenting's greater annoyances.

Leave it to Volvo to come up with a solution: this new inflatable child seat concept. It's a rear-facing seat that is strong enough to do all that a safety seat needs to do, without the cumbersome qualities you've been used to. It's rear facing and can accommodate children up to four years old.
You won't be surprised to hear that the seat concept's designer, Lawrence Abele, has two children. He's design manager at the Volvo Monitoring and Concept Center in Los Angeles.

It inflates in a stunning forty seconds, using an integrated pump, and weighs a mere eleven pounds. When deflated, it stores in a handy bag (as shown here). Compare that with your average seat, for example the Britax Marathon rear-facing convertible seat, which weighs in at a hefty 19.5 pounds and, despite its excellent safety qualities, has no shape-shifting properties.

The light weight and inflatability are due to the use of a "drop-stitch fabric" material developed for use in boating. Volvo's  Maria Hansson notes that the military has also used it in trying to make (wait for it) inflatable airplanes. It also was designed for Swedish-style good looks with some stylish liner fabrics, as shown here.

I have child-seat-lugging memories of my own, so I applaud this concept, which can't hit production too soon. No surprise that it comes from the automaker that created the world's first rear-facing child safety seat...this one, in 1964.

title: 6 Dog-Friendly New Models
subTitle: A plethora of pet-worthy debuts coming to the 2014 New York International Auto Show this week.
promoTeaserSmall: A plethora of pet-worthy debuts coming to the 2014 New York International Auto Show this week.
promoTeaser: A plethora of pet-worthy debuts coming to the 2014 New York International Auto Show this week.
metaDescription: 6 Dog-Friendly New Models: A plethora of pet-worthy debuts coming to the 2014 New York International Auto Show this week.

pageElements.text: Car manufacturers today have learned that they have to sell a car, not just to one person, but to an entire family. And that includes the family pet. Those of us who share our lives with pets know that their needs are an essential part of every car-buying decision. That explains why Subaru offers a Dog Matchmaker on its Facebook page, and why you’ll see dogs co-starring in ads from Land Rover and Chevrolet, among others.

Jean has been taking her four dogs along in a wide variety of test cars for years. She notes that "Cars today are so much more dog-friendly: from technology such as air bags and traction control that make cars safer than ever, to seats that fold easily so you can fit dog crates in back. That, and the proliferation of tall wagons and SUVs, means you are much less limited in your car choices as a pet owner than in the past."

At the New York International Auto Show, which will be open to the public from April 18-27, you’ll see a wide variety of cars, from dreamy supercars to the latest high-tech concepts. But what is there for someone who has an animal companion along for the ride? Good news: Here are six great possibilities, each of which will make a splashy debut at media previews in New York this week. They run the gamut from a pair of subcompacts that have surprisingly usable space in back to a couple of SUVs that will take you and your dog just about anywhere you can dream of. One might be just right for you and your pets.

1. 2015 Honda Fit Crossover

Believe it or not, this all-new version of the subcompact is enough car to let you bring your pets wherever you’re going. The hatchback, shown here, went on sale on April 14. At the New York International Auto Show, a small-SUV version, out this fall, is making its debut. Both will be built at a dedicated new plant in Mexico. Interior space was the goal, and they met it: “Man maximum, machine minimum” was the watchword in creating the completely new 2015 Fit, according to Jeff Conrad, senior vice-president and general manager of Honda Division, but “man’s best friend maximum” also applies. Conrad calls it Honda’s “packaging magic.”

Your dog gets maximum space in the back seat: even in a crate once you fold the 60/40 split seats. With both folded--which can be done instantly by flicking a switch--you get a surprising 52.7 cubic feet of space back there, easily accessed through the easy-open hatchback. If you need a subcompact but also need your pet to ride along, one of these Fits might fit your needs perfectly.

image.altText: dog friendly cars at new york

pageElements.text:
2. 2015 Jeep Renegade

If rough and ready is what you’re looking for, the new Renegade Trailhawk will offer it in spades. It seats five—"comfortably,” promises Jeep—and you won’t feel hemmed in thanks to an optional My Sky dual-panel sunroof that can be removed and stored flat in the rear cargo area. Jeep’s Active Drive Low 4x4 system, skid plates, off-road wheels and tires, and red tow hooks complete the rugged package. “It has a good mix of being playful, but with real capable, serious bones” is how its designers, Ian Hedge and Jeremy Glover, described it. “Like a dog—just shaking it off.”

The Renegade made its debut at the Geneva Auto Show in March, is being built by Jeep’s corporate owners in Italy, and will export its all-American looks all over the world. New York marks its U.S. introduction. It will be on sale here in late 2014.

image.altText: dog friendly cars at new york

pageElements.text:
3. 2015 Kia Sedona

The minivan is not dead, and that’s good news if you want serious carrying space without feeling like you’re driving a giant truck around town. Kia has completely overhauled its Sedona, which it wants you to call a “multipurpose vehicle.” You’ll call it gorgeous when you look inside. Available to seat seven or eight, its measurements are little changed on the outside from the old model, but it has much greater versatility, especially in the flex seating that will let you accommodate pets way more easily. Slide-n-Stow tracked seating can slide or fold upright; no middle seats to remove if you need them out of your way quickly.

Even better, you can slide the second row of seats back, first class airline style, and riders can enjoy retractable leg rests. Meanwhile, the third row is 60/40 split folding and retractable, so your passengers can ride in executive comfort, while pets and their crates have ample room in the back. Don’t be fooled by the luxurious-looking fabric; it’s antimicrobial, anti-static, and stain-repelling due to YES Essentials fabric technology. That's a first in the segment, says Kia.

We applaud the spread of the easy-open tailgate onto the marketplace, and the Sedona’s Smart Tailgate automatically opens when the key fob hovers nearby for three seconds. It’s even programmable by your height preference. And there are so many other creature comforts, such as a high-power USB charging port, a dual glove box with a cooled lower half, and a real-time Surround View camera. All this usability comes with no looks penalty, thanks to the continued design leadership of Kia design chief Peter Schreyer. It goes on sale later this year, with pricing to be announced closer to launch.

4. Land Rover Discovery Vision Concept

This is strictly a “future vision,” but pet and nature lovers of all kinds should keep an eye on Land Rover’s premium SUV ideas, even if only out of curiosity. These high-end explorers are rugged enough for your pets and more than luxurious enough for you. The Discovery Vision concept previews a future family of Discovery vehicles, plus a future set of technology that boggles the mind.

Chief among those: a set of cameras under the grille that create what Land Rover calls “an augmented reality view of the terrain.” In plain English, that means you can see what’s below the front end of your car and avoid obstacles you’ve never been able to see before. The animal lover in us applauds that extra bit of safety.

Other nice touches: a one-piece, power-operated tailgate; a deployable rear sill step and a folding bench seat in the loading area in back; and washable, oil-repellent Foglizzo premium leather that, Land Rover promises, "can be cleaned in seconds." That, and the Harris Tweed accessory trim, is the kind of thing you buy a Land Rover for.

image.altText: dog friendly cars at new york

pageElements.text:
5. 2015 Subaru Outback

If you know anything about dogs and cars, you already know that Subaru wants to be the dog lover’s brand of choice. Although the official unveiling isn’t until Thursday, April 17, teaser images released ahead of time show that the 2015 Outback will have similar breedlines to the five generations of Outbacks that came before. That means a tall-wagon look, more ground clearance than most wagons, plus Subaru’s expected all-wheel drive to make it a go-anywhere, do-anything, take-your-dog-with-you vehicle. Both 2.5-liter four-cylinder and 3.6-liter six-cylinder engine choices in Subaru's traditional horizontally opposed, or "boxer," configuration, are expected to be offered, along with improved, more luxurious interiors—but Subaru practicality is sure to be an important part of the package. Another good alternative for dog owners from Subaru: the 2015 Legacy, which was introduced earlier this year.

image.altText: dog friendly cars at new york

pageElements.text:
6. Volkswagen Golf SportWagen

There are lots of Volkswagen cultists, and they have a point. Jean showed how well her Jetta SportWagen works for her family and its four dogs in our video review. At the New York show, VW will show a concept SportWagen that previews the model slated to go on sale several months from now, in early 2015.

If you have dogs to bring along in your car, VW’s SportWagens let you think 
outside the box and have the sleeker, lower wagon experience without losing SUV-like practicality. As part of a clean redesign, the Golf SportWagen has a lowered height at the tailgate and a wide rear window, and that means better load-in for you and your dogs. The Golf SportWagen is a preview of a larger, yet more fuel-efficient VW to replace that Jetta. It has a new TDI Clean Diesel or a 1.8-liter turbocharged gasoline engine.
This concept has a trifecta of desirable attributes: all-wheel drive, up to 17 percent better fuel economy, and, VW says, as much cargo space as a compact SUV.

pageElements.text:
If you read A Teenager's First Road Trip last week, you know that I'm a high school junior and I was just given the privilege of being put in charge of planning a cross-country road trip with my mom. We just got home, and here's my wrapup.

Catch up with part 1 (Austin to Dallas), part 2 (Arkansas), and part 3 (Nashville, headed north).

Nashville to Cincinnati

We woke up in our dreamy Airbnb rental and planned to spend the day in Nashville. It just fit to be wandering the town in the 2014 GMC Terrain Denali AWD. I was on a mission to get something to wear to the Miley Cyrus concert back home in Ann Arbor the next day, and my mom wanted to get a taste of this town. We listened to our hosts' records while we packed and then headed to the Ugly Mug coffee shop for a quick bagel. Later, we were heading to Cincinnati to pick up two of my girlfriends.

Our first stop was the gift store Welcome Home. I literally wanted everything in the store. I ended up buying awesome temporary tattoos. They seemed appropriate because East Nashville was filled with tattoo-sporting humans. Next we found a cute shopping district, Shoppes on Fatherland, also in East Nashville. As we whipped around these unknown areas, we were happy to have the backup camera. We noticed that the monitor is much clearer than one we have on our Chrysler Town & Country. We came away without a purchase and headed out to find the music scene in Nashville and grab a lunch.

As we searched for the country music part of Nashville that we have seen so many times on TV, we found a barbecue spot, the Judge's Vinegarroon, and ate a delicious lunch. Then we went straight to Music Row. We knew we were there because it was packed with people, and we could hear the music coming out of every bar. The neon signs were great. I am sure that at night this place turns into a giant party. I was overwhelmed by all of the people, though, and convinced my mom to head to a mall so that I could get my Miley outfit.

We spent a few hours there. I know, I know, I was in Nashville, and I shouldn’t have wasted our time. But Miley was going to bring a little country to me in only twenty-four hours. This is what you get when traveling with a teenage girl. When we finally left Nashville, it was starting to get dark, which was actually perfect so that we could get in some night driving in strange territory.

As the sun set behind us, we decided that we were not huge fans of the red lights that light up the GMC Terrain's dashboard and center console. I prefer blue or white lights. In fact, my mom had a hard time getting used to the transmission shifter's lights, too. It had a white light for the gear you are in, and the rest are red. I wonder if they choose red to go with the red stitching that lines the dashboard? I liked the stitching and found the rest of the dashboard both good-looking and easy to use.

The night driving made driving through the construction even more difficult. At night, the side blind zone alert really stood out on our side mirrors, which was very helpful. We were tired and some of the areas had bright lights, and the cement barriers made it seem like the lanes were even narrower. My mom used this as a teaching moment, telling me that until I am a more experienced driver I should always try to reach my destination during the day.

We talked about our week with the Terrain and what we thought about the ride. The fuel economy of the four-cylinder engine was perfect for our highway cross-country trip. We were still able to merge and accelerate when we needed to with ease. Every now and then it would lurch when my mom really punched it. But as a passenger, I felt it was smooth, and inside the cabin it was pretty quiet. Most of the roads on this trip have proved to be smooth, which will not be the case at home in Michigan.
As we pushed through the night, the Terrain's nav failed us and went berserk. Just as we needed it at a tricky interchange, it froze to where it wouldn’t even shut off.

As we pushed through the night, the Terrain's nav failed us and went berserk. Just as we needed it at a tricky interchange, it froze to the point where it wouldn’t even shut off. It finally turned off and back on, but our route was lost, and so we  switched to using our iPhones. This happened twice during our drive and would prompt a trip to the dealer upon our return.

Cincinnati to Ann Arbor

It was dark when we arrived in Cincinnati, but we had planned on a copule of hours to take a quick walk around before we picked up two of my girlfriends from camp, who were joining us to drive up to the concert in Michigan. The Reds fans were everywhere. We had dinner in a great restaurant, Nada, which was directly across the street from the Contemporary Arts Center. The food was fantastic, and it was great to be eating our last meal outside before we would be joined by my friends. In some ways, this was the end of the trip with my mom.

We picked up my girlfriends in Mariemont, just outside Cincinnati, and we were stoked to see each other and even more so about the concert. We quickly crammed their bags into the car—it is amazing how much we girls pack for an overnight. It took some work, but everything fit. My friends agreed to give me some feedback about the back seat, since I had spent our entire trip riding shotgun. They liked how the seat was slightly reclined and were impressed with the legroom. They liked how the entire entertainment system was built into the back of the front seats.

What I Learned

During the past week with my mom, I have learned so much about road trips and how planning them makes things run smoothly. It was nice to have all of our accommodations set beforehand. One thing I learned was that I need to research neighborhoods and parts of town more carefully. If I had been alone, I would not have been comfortable in some of the places we ended up.

The Terrain was an excellent car for exploring the South. All the safety equipment made me feel that we were well taken care of on the road, and this SUV's size made us comfortable, never cramped. The spacious seats and amount of storage as well as the (mostly) great navigation assistance made the time spent driving much more pleasant. The trip with my mom was amazing, and I am so happy I got the chance to experience planning a road trip. As you can see, we all got home in time to get our Miley Cyrus faces on. Now, where should I go on my own road trip?

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
“Here lies one whose name was writ in water.”

Epitaph on the tombstone of Keats

Sandra Lou Jennings, Chesapeake Bay retriever of my heart for the past fourteen-plus years, has departed this mortal coil after a full and glorious life of hunting, swimming, and being queen bee of the Jennings dog pack.

My husband, Tim, and I brought Louie home to be a companion for our first Chessie, the mighty Ron Dog. They were fast friends, and she joined him in our fields and streams once we sorted out her poor little back legs. A genetic defect caused both rear knees to require a complete rebuild before she was one year old, a surgery that she patiently endured but that just undid Tim. He called me on the way back from the vet with a frantic message that I had to hurry home from work because she was distraught. I arrived in a rush to find Lou dozing, but a very distraught husband.

She also had a lower jaw that never fully grew out, leaving her with the overbite of Marge Simpson, necessitating the removal of her upper canines so the lower teeth wouldn’t impact the roof of her mouth.

None of this impacted her hunting skills, however. She unfailingly retrieved any downed bird she’d flushed and carried it proudly and unerringly to Tim’s or my hand, with her big, old fluffy tail flailing briskly as she walked up. Her first retrieve was in the duck marshes around Delacroix, Louisiana, when I shot a duck that cartwheeled through the air at a zillion miles an hour; slammed into Tim’s chest, nearly knocking him on his ass; and fell dead on the ground in front of little one-year-old Louie’s sleeping nose. She woke up, sniffed, stood up, picked it up, and put it into Tim’s outstretched hand.
Never any drama, a serene presence in the pack of snippy Chessies. The best hunter, the prettiest head, the sweetest face, and the most angelic disposition.
And that’s the way it remained with her: Never any drama, a serene presence in the pack of snippy Chessies. The best hunter, the prettiest head, the sweetest face, and the most angelic disposition.
Our LouLou Belle, as the writer Susan Orlean nicknamed her during a road trip we took down south in 2000. Our Lucifer when she was nosing in the trash.

Lou remained remarkably healthy all of her life, but as she aged, those rear legs began to let her down. Our vet told us it was the legs that would finally take her out. And they did, although we slowed the decline with medicine, with lots of swimming, and then with acupuncture, which was remarkably effective.

It was such a tough, tough winter. We were hoping against hope we could limp her through and then give her the summer of her life. She made it through all three Polar Vortices, waited until I got home from my two-month TV shoot in Los Angeles, and spent a week basking in pets, brushes, all the treats she wanted, and being lifted into bed at night.
But even as her hearing remained sharp, her heart beat strong, her appetite raged, and her angelic disposition never faltered, those twisted back legs finally gave up the ghost.
Goodbye, our little bat-eared dog, our precious Lou. We will remember and love you forever.

pageElements.text: Of all the glamorous cars you'll see at an auto show, these are not two examples. The Ford Focus and the Chevrolet Cruze are the everyday compact cars you see around the streets and might not particularly notice. You're also fairly likely to know someone (or be someone) who drives one of these multimillion sellers. But this week is a moment in the sun for both: the updated and improved 2015 models are making their debuts at the New York International Auto Show. Let's give them the attention they deserve, since we'll be seeing these new models everywhere for years to come.

2015 Ford Focus

You're looking at a winner: The Ford Focus is the top-selling nameplate in the world. Twelve million have been sold since the initial launch in 1998, including almost 1.1 million in 2013. In China alone last year, sales topped 400,000, which was a 50 percent jump for that aspirational country.

The 2015 Focus five-door hatchback made its debut last month, in Geneva. At the New York show, we'll be seeing the four-door sedan version and the Focus Electric. The 2015 version of the hotter Focus ST comes out later in the year.

What's new for 2015?

For starters, you can now get the 1.0-liter three-cylinder EcoBoost engine, which is already in the Focus's little sibling the Fiesta. Pair that with the new six-speed manual transmission, and you'll be expecting some great fuel economy (not yet announced). The standard engine is a 2.0-liter four-cylinder, which returns 37 mpg on the highway in the 2014 Focus.

An SE Sport package is new; it comes with a revised suspension, paddle shifters, and seventeen-inch gloss black aluminum wheels. The electronic nanny MyKey is standard on all 2015 Focus models, and a heated steering wheel is optional. And it should be; let's not hog that fabulous feature only to the luxury classes!

Technology moves forward for 2015, too. A rearview camera is standard on every trim level, whether with the basic 4.2-inch screen or the MyFord Touch eight-inch screen. Blind spot monitoring and lane keeping systems are optional.  Ford Sync AppLink has been upgraded, so you can download dozens of apps for your Android or iOS smartphone.

The Focus's new grille is a smaller copy of the one on the larger Fusion. Something about that bothers me: family resemblance is important, but even an attractive front end like this will get tiresome the 500,000th time I see one go by.

What does everybody see in this car? Don't make too much of the fact that the top-selling Focus color in the U.S. is the dull-sounding Sterling Gray. The Focus has a likable combination of fuel economy, modern technology, and just plain fun-to-drive personality. And, of course, people can afford to buy them. Prices for the 2015s aren't out yet, but the 2014 sedan started at $17,635, while the 2014 hatchback's starting price was $19,450 (prices include destination). The first buyers will get their hands on the 2015 Focus late this year.

2015 Chevrolet Cruze

Here's another ubiquitous compact that has achieved great popularity. The Cruze is the top-selling Chevrolet product worldwide, and more than 2.5 million have been sold since it came out only in mid-2010.

Chevrolet's marketing chief, Paul Edwards, would like you to know as well that it's the number-two seller among U.S. buyers under twenty-five. But the Cruze is not necessarily just a rite of passage for entry-level shoppers. Look at the connectivity features GM is putting onto this low-priced car, especially OnStar 4G LTE with an optional Wi-Fi hotspot feature so you'll be able to stay Internet connected just about everywhere in your universe. There are also new text message alerts and upgraded voice recognition features that work with Chevrolet's MyLink telematics,  and Siri Eyes Free for iPhone users.

There is no doubt that in-car connectivity is the future, and it's nothing short of awesome that Chevrolet makes its affordable sedan into a rolling hotspot on the leading edge of that future, so millions of people can enjoy it. What's more, you can hook up seven devices to the high-speed wireless. If there are three passengers in the car, and each has a smartphone, a laptop, or a tablet, seven isn't as crazy as it sounds. Okay, kids, get that homework edited and submitted before we get to soccer practice!

What's new for 2015?

The Cruze's new look is not a complete overhaul, just a refreshed appearance, but it does bring the small car closer to the look of larger siblings Malibu and Impala, notably the new front end with its LED daytime running lights and a split grille. GM also promises several new colors, without giving details yet.

You'll still be able to get the fuel-efficient Eco model and the diesel version, which in the 2014 version takes you more than 700 miles between fillups and offers 46 mpg on the highway. Pricing has not yet been announced, although the 2014 model started at a reasonable $18,345, including destination. The 2015 Cruze will be on sale in the fall.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. pageElements.text: Auto-show reveals are always exciting, and the one last night for the 2015 Hyundai Sonata was no exception, as our video (below) shows. The all-new seventh-generation version of the mid-size sedan, built in Alabama, will be on sale this summer, and here's what you can expect.

This new body design is described as Fluidic Sculpture 2.0. We've got more patience with this kind of poetic lingo when it really shows on the car, as it does here. The looks are definitely more refined without becoming too aggressive: "the way an award-winning chef refines his recipe over the years," in the words of Chris Chapman, Hyundai Design North America's chief designer. The cleanliness of the new Sonata's design cannot be overstated. Or, put simply, it's "a more planted look," as Chapman described it.

At the official introduction this morning at the Jacob Javits Convention Center, president and CEO Dave Zuchowski called the new sedan "more taut, sophisticated...the next step in a substantial design evolution" and "a great leap forward in Hyundai's engineering capabilities." How do you like it?
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/rGuimyksRA8?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

What's new for 2015?

Active safety is upgraded for 2015 with a Lane Change Assist package. It determines the closing speed of any vehicle in the lane next to the Sonata and uses an audible alarm to let you know if the lane change is safe. Along with that go lane departure warning, rear cross-traffic alert, and blind spot detection, so you're covered at every angle.

A pair of four-cylinder engines have been revised for better drivability at low RPM: the 2.4-liter 185-horsepower four-cylinder in SE, Limited, and Sport models, and the 2.0-liter turbo, which makes 245 horsepower and is for the Sport 2.0T model. Both are mated to a six-speed automatic transmission. Hyundai explains the continued commitment to four-cylinders only is a way to optimize space and fuel efficiency.

Other tech to appreciate, coming down from the 2015 Genesis to the mid-size class, includes high beam assist, smart cruise control, a more touch-sensitive 8.0-inch navigation touchscreen, Siri Eyes free integration, and a smart trunk that opens if you get anywhere near the trunk with the key fob in hand and wait three seconds.
Good news about color: seven choices will be available. That orange, though, that you see in the video: it's exclusive to the turbo model.
A Blue Link in-vehicle app for Hyundai Assurance car care downloads onto the nav screen so, if you want to, you can schedule your maintenance and service right inside the car. Interesting!

People who ride along will appreciate a height-adjustable passenger's seat, a pair of heated and ventilated front seats, and heated rear seats, plus an optional heated steering wheel. Another inch of rear legroom is added this year, and Hyundai points out that it has so much space inside that the EPA actually classifies the Sonata as a "large car," unique among cars in the mid-size class. Put this together with the new 2015 Genesis, and Hyundai has an ambitious sedan lineup in place.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: Toyota’s top seller has just gotten a remake, part of an overhaul of the automaker’s lineup that has seen the introduction of six new products in the past eighteen months.

Toyota Group vice-president Bill Fay headed off this morning’s introduction at the New York Auto Show with the statement, “Toyota is going places.” With the introduction of the 2015 Camry, the automaker is working to keep the title of America’s favorite car.

Since 1983, more than 10.2 million Camrys have found U.S. buyers, and there are a staggering 6.6 million on the roads today. All North American market Camrys are built in the United States with 75 percent North American content.

What's new for 2015?

This newest Camry is sleeker, with a more refined design than its forebears. It gains 1.8 inches in overall length. Visually, its new headlamps and more aggressive front fascia are notable. Mechanically, there’s updated braking, more torsional rigidity, and a retuned suspension.

The revised interior is the standout, with soft-touch materials, French stitching, satin and metallic black chrome, a simpler, more intuitive center stack, and better wireless connectivity. Inside an enclosed bin in front of the shifter, a wireless charging system is now available—first in the segment, says Toyota. The 2015 Camry will be available in ten colors, including the new Ruby Flare Pearl and Celestial Silver Metallic shades that are shown on this page.

Toyota has a watchword: "waku-doki. " That’s the code word for excitement, and, no, it’s not altogether out of place when talking about the Camry. The success of the sportier Camry SE model, which is the choice of 45 percent of Camry buyers, inspired Toyota to add an XSE (shown here) with eighteen-inch wheels, a sportier suspension, and the same mesh grille and fascia treatment as the SE model. Toyota’s proud that the median age of SE owners is twelve years younger than the segment’s average of forty-five; the XSE plans to skew even younger.
For 2015, a Hybrid SE is added for what Toyota insists on calling “an eco-fun driving experience,” but despite the hyperbole, we’ll bet it will be.
The 2015 Camry will go on sale in the fall.

pageElements.text: I still remember the buzz around the offices of Automobile Magazine when the first Mazda MX-5 Miata arrived, prior to being named Automobile of the Year for 1990 ("Lemiata here," exclaimed one editor, the minute the keys were handed to him), and it’s hard to believe that has been twenty-five years already. But, yep, it has. This 2015 Mazda Miata 25th Anniversary Edition proves that time flies. And so can the 100 buyers of this limited-edition model, which will be on sale before summer.

The roadster was unveiled at the New York Auto Show, partly slaking the thirst of people wanting to know more about the all-new Miata coming for 2016. This is the last hurrah for the third-generation Miata before then. All 100 copies will be sold in Soul Red Metallic. The contrasting color is black, including on the power retractable hard top. Six-speed manual or automatic transmission versions will be available, with the manual versions equipped with Bilstein dampers as standard. Mazda trumpeted the fact that individual engine components have been selected by hand for each copy of the 25th Anniversary Miata: a nice touch.
More easily visible to the passer-by is 25th Anniversary badge with serial number, located on the driver’s front fender.

Inside, the seats and door trim are almond-colored leather, matched to piano black steering wheel spokes, a black seat back, and leather on the steering wheel, shift lever, armrests, and parking brake handle. All get contrasting red stitching. The drilled aluminum pedals are worth noting as well.

pageElements.text: As buzz accumulates about the next-generation Mazda Miata, the Japanese automaker is reminding us that in order to understand the future, we should also honor the past. And what better way to celebrate a quarter-century of blissful top-down motoring than with a 2015 Mazda Miata 25th Anniversary Edition? Mazda debuted this special-edition Miata at the 2014 New York auto show as a preview of the limited-run roadster set to go on sale later this spring.

"The original concept behind the MX-5 was so simple: to offer the pure joy of a lightweight sports car that moves precisely as the driver intends," said Mazda chairman Takashi Yamanouchi in a statement. Twenty-five years later, with nearly a million Miata vehicles sold worldwide, the 2015 Mazda Miata 25th Anniversary Edition keeps the same formula of light weight, balance, and handling prowess that we’ve known and loved since we named the Miata our first Automobile of the Year in 1990. Today, the Miata still carries the torch for the original car we called, “a paragon of sports-car virtue. It does everything right, and it’s enormous fun.”

Under the hood is the Miata’s third-generation, 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine delivering up to 167 hp to the rear wheels.  Mazda says that for every 25th Anniversary Edition Miata, its engineers hand-selected the highest-quality pistons, connecting rods, and flywheels for exceptional lightness and low inertia. Mazda doesn't claim that hand selection leads to more horsepower, but does say those engines will rev, “even more freely.” Vehicles equipped with the six-speed manual gearbox also get standard Bilstein dampers.

All 100 2015 Mazda Miata 25th Anniversary Edition vehicles will come in Soul Red Metallic paint with contrasting black for the A-pillars, mirrors, windshield surround, and power-retractable hardtop. Other black trim pieces include the headlamp bezels and 17-inch aluminum-alloy wheels, which are shod in Bridgestone Potenza RE05A tires. Unique 25th Anniversary badging on the front driver’s side fender distinguishes each vehicle with its own serial number.

Almond leather seats and door trim come standard on the special-edition Miata, which is finished with aluminum pedals and satin chrome details on the door handles and gauge cluster rings. Black seatback and Piano Black steering wheel spokes match the leather steering wheel, shift lever boot, armrests, and parking brake handle, which echo the exterior’s theme with contrasting red stitching.

On sale later this spring in a limited run of 100 vehicles, the 2015 Mazda Miata 25th Anniversary Edition should be a wonderful collector’s car for any Miata enthusiast, as it also represents the final iteration of the third-generation “NC” Miata. Mazda’s fourth-generation Miata will presumably go on sale as a 2016 model with a full redesign that includes a new lightweight Skyactiv chassis. More details on the next-gen car will be revealed today in New York.

title: 2015 Jeep Renegade
subTitle: New small Jeep looks to attract X-Games-loving, adventure-seeking youth. Oldsters may love it, too.

metaDescription: 2015 Jeep Renegade: New small Jeep looks to attract X-Games-loving, adventure-seeking youth. Oldsters may love it, too. Read the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: It’s small. It’s wide. Or, as Jeep would have it, it’s “small-wide.” That’s the name for the build of this 2015 Renegade, Jeep’s entry into the small SUV segment. It’s also rugged yet adorable, especially with the new removable open-air roof panels known as My Sky. Driving the point of it home, the new Renegade made its debut at the New York Auto Show perched on the way down a steep incline.

Advantages to the new architecture: best-in-class off-roading and world-class on-road driving dynamics, says Jeep, which introduced the new model at the New York Auto Show today. It builds on the Wrangler’s form and the Cherokee’s 4x4 technology but has a charm all its own.

“The Renegade is the essential element for the next urban adventure. It can go from rigorous off-roading to social climbing in the city,” according to Jeep Brand president and CEO Mike Manley, but what you’d really want the Renegade to do is go exploring. For that, there are two versions: the Latitude (the red model shown here) and the Trailhawk. The Renegades include not just full-time four-wheel drive but a standard Active Drive Low 4x4 system with a 20:1 crawl ratio, which engages instantly in case you need that kind of traction. Or how about the five inspiring modes in the Jeep’s Selec-Terrain system: Auto, Snow, Sand, Mud, and Rock, that last one exclusively available on the Trailhawk model. In the Trailhawk with its Trail Rated 4x4 capability, you can ford up to nineteen inches of water! Will you? Well, you could if you wanted.

Designed in the United States but to be built in Italy, the new Renegade is intended for sale worldwide. Already this year, Jeep is proclaiming sales up 44 percent, with some 85,000 of its vehicles sold worldwide so far, on the way to a target of a million. The new Renegade's 30 mpg on the highway should aid popularity; the Renegade comes with a choice of a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine with a nine-speed automatic transmission (a first in this segment) or a 1.4-liter MultiAir Turbo engine with a six-speed manual transmission.

Jeep buyers are looking for a rough-and-ready interior, and they’ll get one in the 2015 Renegade. “Tek-Tonic” is the descriptor of the style. Several off-road-ready features (like grab handles) are borrowed from the Jeep Wrangler. The flexible interior package includes a removable, reversible, and height-adjustable cargo floor panel.
Protective clamp fasteners and the X shapes on the taillamps will make you think of camping equipment or extreme sports, Jeep hopes.

Maybe our favorite part of this new Jeep is its My Sky roof system, either with a power tilt and slide feature or manually removable, that lets you take off the fiberglass roof panels and store them in the rear cargo area.

It may look old school, but Uconnect touchscreen, emergency assistance, Bluetooth connectivity, HD radio, and an optional seven-inch instrument display are all on board.  Plus the active safety features that are becoming more common across the automotive world: forward collision warning, lane departure warning, blind spot monitoring, a rearview camera with dynamic grid lines, and rear cross-path detection are all available.
The 2015 Jeep Renegade goes on sale late this year, with pricing to be announced closer to launch.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: Here’s an all-new performance-luxury sedan from Acura, which made its debut at the New York Auto Show after being displayed in prototype form at the Detroit Auto Show in January. It can be hard to keep up with the Acura lineup, since all its products have similar alphabet names. Suffice it to say that this one  replaces the TL sedan and TSX sport wagon. It joins a lineup that includes the five-passenger RDX and seven-passenger MDX SUVs and the ILX and RLX sedans

It’s worthwhile getting to know the initials, because this sedan offers some major upgrades from the previous models. As Acura senior vice-president Mike Accavitti proclaimed, “The 2015 Acura TLX is the next generation, a true world-class athlete built and bred to deliver performance.”

Among the news: Two new transmissions to go with two familiar Acura engine choices. With the 2.4-liter four-cylinder, you get a dual-clutch eight-speed transmission, and with the 3.5-liter V-6, you get a nine-speed automatic that operates using a push-button gear selector instead of a gearlever for “a premium futuristic appearance.”
The new TLX is projected to get highway fuel economy as high as 35 mpg. An Acura Super-Handling All-Wheel Drive version is also available, which garners 31 mpg on the highway.

Physically, the 2015 TLX is nearly four inches shorter than the outgoing TL, and it has cut weight (at least 145 pounds) thanks to diligent use of lightweight materials. The interior gets soft-touch materials on the instrument panel, optional Milano leather seating and trim surfaces, and alloy and wood-grain accents. The exterior gets the Jewel Eye LED headlights that distinguish the Acura marque these days.  As an option, you can get a 455-watt, ten-speaker premium audio system that has been created by multi-Grammy-winning music producer Elliot Scheiner specifically for the TLX.

Technologically, there’s a full slate of active safety technology, including collision mitigation braking, forward collision warning, lane departure and lane keeping, adaptive cruise control, and blind spot monitoring.

The new TLX goes on sale later this year, with pricing to be announced closer to the launch date. As a comparison, the outgoing 2014 TSX starts at $31,530, and the TL at $36,925 (including destination charges).
“We think it’s ready for the bright lights of Broadway and a getaway to upstate New York,” noted Matt Hargett, chief engineer and vice-president of Acura R & D.

pageElements.text: The unseasonable arrival of spring sleet and snow didn’t defeat the overnight assembly of the 50th Anniversary triple-yellow Mustang on the eighty-sixth floor of the Empire State Building during the New York Auto Show.  Ford had a deadline fifty years in the making. But first, as it had done back in the Sixties, it had to get the Mustang to fit into the elevator.
Preparation for the feat began six weeks ago. Turns out, it’s no small thing to hoist a car 1,000 feet in the air.

image.altText: ford mustang on top of nyc

pageElements.text: The first car to be displayed atop the Empire State Building was in October 1965, a quintessential moment in the early years of the Mustang brand. It followed the 1964 introduction of the first Ford Mustang at the 1964 World’s Fair. Preparation for the feat began six weeks ago. Turns out, it’s no small thing to hoist a car 1,000 feet in the air. Ford stuck with a tried and true formula, removing parts piece by piece in the tradition of age-old craftsmen. The Detroit automaker collaborated with the longtime Michigan-based supplier DST, which helped stage the first Empire State Building suspended stunt. The Mustang was cut into surgically rendered pieces and then reformed for display in a narrow six-hour window while the observation deck was closed to the public.

Mustang has become the iconic symbol for all things Ford embraces about its heritage. Bill Ford, Jr., the brand’s scion and Ford executive chairman, was on hand to take a seat behind the wheel. He remarked that his first car was a 1975 electric green Mustang.

To commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the pony car, Ford has produced a Mustang 50 Year Limited Edition and made an appropriate number, 1,964 vehicles. It will go on sale this fall. The special car will be made in Kona Blue and Wimbledon White—in homage to the very first Mustang—and relies on the classic 5.0-liter V-8 that produces 420 horsepower and 390 pound-feet of torque. Brembo brakes and nineteen-inch alloy wheels are also included in the performance package. Two transmissions are available: a six-speed automatic and a souped-up six-speed manual. It’s essentially a GT.

image.altText: ford mustang on top of nyc

pageElements.text: Meanwhile, the suspended Mustang will be on display only through today, April 17, before it makes the long journey back down to earth. Check out the stunt in progress in the photo gallery below.

title: 2015 Subaru Outback
subTitle: A new face for the old friend makes its New York Show debut.

pageElements.text: You wouldn’t have to look too far to find a Subaru Outback out on the road that is almost as old as the nameplate. It’s twenty years since the all-wheel-drive specialist came out with this rugged take on the family car, and today at the New York Auto Show, the fifth generation made its debut. Not surprisingly, as you see in these photos, its look is not drastically changed from the capable, maybe a little staid, appearance it has always had.

And that’s just how its devotees like it. The Outback has everything to please the adventurous but unpretentious family: great visibility, pretty good fuel efficiency, and all-weather capability. There’s little doubt this new version of the Outback will be flying out of dealerships, and from there, putt-putting down the Colorado highways and the Iowa City and Madison campus boulevards for years to come.

What’s new for 2015?

Chief among the changes are a standard continuously variable transmission as standard on all models and enhanced active all-wheel drive with X-Mode, which first came out on the 2014 Forester. Subaru says this will improve engine output and increase AWD engagement. Speaking of engines, there’s a standard boxer four-cylinder that makes 175 horsepower, but you could upgrade to a 3.6-liter boxer six-cylinder that makes 256 horsepower. Pretty good for a Subaru. Fuel economy for this all-wheel-drive vehicle is estimated at 33 mpg on the highway for the four-cylinder, up from 30 mpg in the 2014 model. The Limited with the six-cylinder should get 27 mpg highway, up from 25 mpg last year.

New active safety items include a rear vehicle detection system, standard on the Limited model, which includes blind spot monitoring, lane change assist, and rear cross-traffic alert. There’s also new standard Welcome Lighting that turns on the cabin and exterior lights as you approach or leave the Outback, an upscale touch for this wagonish vehicle.

Perhaps most noteworthy is the latest version of Subaru’s EyeSight active safety tech, which includes adaptive cruise control, pre-collision braking, and lane departure warning. It also features steering-responsive foglamps, which activates the lamps independently while you’re turning. EyeSight is available on Premium and Limited versions of the Outback.

Inside the Outback, the closest to luxury is the top Limited model, which gets perforated leather seating, a ten-way power driver’s seat with two-position memory, dual-mode heated rear seats, and a power rear gate that memorizes your desired height. There’s also an All-Weather package available that adds heated front seats, heated exterior mirrors, and the luxury of a windshield wiper de-icer.

Subarus aren’t known for their useless gewgaws, so the 2015 Outback offers an infotainment system with a modest 6.2-inch touchscreen, although it’s quite up to date with Bluetooth connectivity, Aha, Pandora, and iHeart radio, and Subaru Starlink smartphone integration. The Limited gets an HD radio system with Harman Kardon twelve-speaker audio. A nav system is optional.
The 2015 Outback goes on sale in late summer, with prices to be announced closer to launch. For reference, the 2014 Outback started at $24,320 (including destination charge).

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: The 2015 Honda Fit is already out, as we showed you last week, and now it’s joined by an all-new compact SUV, the Fit-based HR-V. Well, sort of. We saw photos, but no actual vehicle, at the New York Auto Show this week.
Not to worry, because this HR-V is definitely going to be seen a lot once it goes on sale next winter.

The new HR-V is to be assembled alongside the Fit at a purpose-built new plant in Mexico, and both models are huge for the Honda brand in North America. And since, as Honda senior vice-president and general manager Jeff Conrad points out, the Fit has the most brand-loyal customers of any Honda product, there will probably be a lot of people ready to look kindly on the new HR-V.

“Great things can come in small packages,” Conrad said. Is this going to be great? Let’s consider. It has the same clever packaging as the Fit, which has surprising amounts of interior space thanks to its center gas-tank layout and easy-folding Magic Seat. One hint about its looks: It will have hidden rear door handles, for what Honda terms a sportier appearance.

This is a smaller SUV than the already not huge CR-V; you may remember the size of it as shown in this Urban SUV Concept (right), which was displayed at the Detroit Auto Show in January 2013. Want to see it posed right next to the Fit, for size comparisons? Us, too. Soon!
Other details will just have to wait, but since the 2014 CR-V starts just under $24,000, expect this smaller version to have a very interesting price to go with its new look.

subTitle: Another cute little Chevy hits the market. The crossover for those who want more than a minicar?

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: Everybody’s got a small crossover these days, and now, so does Chevrolet. Sixty other countries have had the Chevy Trax, including Canada, Mexico, and even China since it made its debut in late 2012; now the U.S. market gets a shot at it. The Trax will arrive in U.S. dealerships early next year as a 2015 model.

Set up to compete against such products as the Kia Soul and the Nissan Juke, the Trax will join other cute little cars in the Chevrolet lineup, the Spark and the Sonic, further consolidating the brand’s appeal to young buyers. In fact, as Chevrolet spokesman Chad Lyons pointed out at the New York Auto Show, the Trax is Chevrolet’s seventh small-car introduction in four years. (Pictured here, from left: 2015 Cruze, 2014 Spark EV, 2015 Trax, 2014 Spark, 2014 Sonic.) “We see the small SUV segment growing by 80 percent within the next three years,” said Lyons.

Despite its diminutive appearance, the Trax is said to seat five and is built on the Chevrolet Cruze’s platform. It’s powered by a 1.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine that makes 138 horsepower. The spirited-looking Trax is expected to return 34 mpg on the highway, and an all-wheel-drive version will be offered.

As for features, both connectivity and cargo are carefully thought out. The Trax has optional OnStar 4G LTE to make the vehicle into a rolling hotspot, plus Chevrolet MyLink, plus a seven-inch color touchscreen that ought to look pretty dominant in this small vehicle. Siri Eyes Free is available for iOS users, too, and a rearview camera is standard on all trim levels. The back seats are 60/40 split folding, and there are four bins in the dashboard, more bins under the rear floor, and a secret compartment under the front passenger’s seat. That seat also folds flat so you can carry something up to eight feet long.
The Trax will come in a choice of ten colors: seven metallic, ranging from Brilliant Blue to the Orange Rock shade shown here, plus Summit White, Blaze Red, and White Pearl Tricoat.
If you upgrade to the top LTZ model, you get standard eighteen-inch aluminum wheels; sixteen-inchers are standard on the LS and LT models.

Does it look a whole lot like its sibling, the Buick Encore (shown here), with which it shares specs? Yes, but for those not prepared to spring for the more luxurious Buick—considering the $25,085 starting price of the 2014 Encore (including destination charge)—this might be the ticket. The Trax hasn't been priced yet, but in Canada where it's sold now, the 2014 model starts at the U.S. equivalent of about $18,500. Intriguing!

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.
