title: What Future for Maserati?
subTitle: CEO Harald J. Wester talks to Automobile Magazine's Jamie Kitman about the brand's transformation.
promoTeaserSmall: CEO Harald J. Wester talks to Automobile Magazine's Jamie Kitman about the brand's transformation.
promoTeaser: CEO Harald J. Wester talks to Automobile Magazine's Jamie Kitman about the brand's transformation.
metaKeywords: Maserati North America CEO Peter M. Grady
metaDescription: What Future for Maserati? CEO Harald J. Wester and Maserati North America CEO Peter M. Grady talk Ghibli, Quattroporte, and more with Automobile Magazine's Jamie Kitman. Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Jamie Kitman, a lawyer and rock band manager, contributed to Automobile Magazine in its first year, when its editor bought a story he'd swritten while in law school, about attending a Volvo market research session in Boston. "Earn $75 if you thought about buying a Volvo and didn't" the classified ad that changed his life read. After several years freelancing, he became a columnist for Automobile Magazine in 1991 and has now written more than 200 columns as well as numerous features for the periodical, in the process becoming its New York Bureau Chief. In 2009, Kitman won a National Magazine Award, the "Ellie," for three columns on the collapse of Detroit, marking the first time a car magazine had ever won an NMA. Earlier, he won the IRE Medal for Investigative Magazine Reporting for his in-depth review of the history of leaded gasoline for The Nation, a subject about which he is writing a book for Simon & Schuster, as well as several other IAMA awards. A frequent contributor to GQ, The New York Times, Foreign Affairs and other publications, he writes blogs for NPR's Car Talk and Yahoo! The father of three children, (one of whom is named Ellie,) Kitman's musical clients, as president of The Hornblow Group USA, include OK Go, They Might Be Giants, Mike Doughty, Mike Viola, Moon Hooch and Vandaveer. Former clients have included Violent Femmes, The La's, Meat Puppets, Pere Ubu, Edwyn Collins, Beautiful South, Trashcan Sinatras and Yo La Tengo. He lives in a rivertown not far from Manhattan, where he keeps company with, yes, you read it right, thirty old cars.

pageElements.text: Maserati’s only debut at the 2014 New York Auto Show was a pair of special-edition cars, but that doesn’t mean the Italian brand is resting on its laurels. We sat down with Harald J. Wester, CEO of Maserati, as well as Maserati North America president and CEO Peter M. Grady, to learn what’s next for Maserati.

Peter M. Grady: The Ghibli (shown here) is our first entry into this attainable price range. We’re pretty pleased with where we are so far. We’ve got a fair amount of growth to go in a number of markets. But if you go into New York, south Florida, L.A., our traditional markets, it’s been very well accepted. This is our opportunity to reach in to a number of consumers who would never even think about Maserati before.
Automobile Magazine: How do you reach those people?

PG: A bunch of different ways. We have our traditional ride and drive events, getting people into the car – these cars really do sell themselves. But we’re reaching into the digital side of the business, we’re doing a little bit of TV after the Super Bowl. The Super Bowl ad put us on the charts. The awareness we got off of that Super Bowl ad was spectacular. It spiked awareness. And the beautiful thing is, we’ve maintained that level of awareness. Really a watershed for Maserati here. We’re running now in some of the key luxury markets a cutdown, bookended by fifteen seconds on either side. Where it’s a version of that ad, with the same feel and texture. We’re on news and sports programs with it, that’s really where the demographic is. We’re getting a lot of good traffic in the showrooms. People are loving the car.
Automobile: Who’s looking at your car?

PG: If you’re a [Mercedes-Benz] E-Class driver at $499 a month and you walk into a Maserati showroom, you’re generally blown away by what you see. And you’re probably not as much of an enthusiast or an aficionado as what we would normally get. And those kind of people are discovering the brand and they’re trying to decide if they fit it. Then you’ve got some legitimate [BMW] 6-Series, 5-Series, [Mercedes] AMG types that come in and they’re converted. They’re loving the vehicles.
Automobile: How are you feeling about the volume so far?

PG: It’s good, we’re not satisfied, and we’ve got a way to go, how’s that?

I’m not that interested in talking about volumes; traditionally, we don’t. We’re trying to become a player in this segment, so if we can be legitimate competitor and sell legitimate volume in that sports sedan segment then we’ll be pretty pleased.

Automobile: There was the idea, fomented by Mercedes in the 1990s in my view, that you need to sell a million cars to have sufficient economies of scale. But then you see a Jaguar Land Rover, who sell a fraction of the volume, but manage to make money and deliver a very credible product. You seem to be following much more in JLR’s footsteps, as far as volume goes, and having driven it there’s no doubt Ghibli is credible, yet it too is a relatively low volume enterprise. Of course, for exclusivity, actually being exclusive has to beat saying you’re exclusive, while selling a million or more examples of similar cars. But as a manufacturing and business proposition, can you speak to making money at these lower volumes? Maserati would be happy to sell 50,000 cars.

Harald J. Wester: Yes. If you look back to 2012, from the old QP [Quattroporte], Gran Turismo, and Gran Cabrio, we sold 6,200 cars globally. Now we have a new architecture, new engines, two new cars which we’ve launched. I can’t talk too much about the future – the SUV is on its way and will be ready Oct ’15, early ’16. As with any dogmatic statements, there are a lot of “buts” and “ifs” around it. If you talk about the extremely competitive mass-volume market, I think a million is a good number. We’re in a totally different business. The future of Maserati – and we sold 15,400 cars last year, 50 percent in the last quarter thanks to Quattroporte and Ghibli – we are going to make a significant step towards the 50,000 goal. Without making a precise number, I expect our global sales this year to be beyond 35,000. Obviously, the U.S. is an important portion. For the time being I expect it to remain. China has become a very important market for the Quattroporte. For the time being, it outsells Ghibli there. Totally different demographics than the rest of the world. Forty percent female. Average age: below forty.
PG: This is the demographic that everybody for twenty years has been chasing. In China, they’re buying the cars.

HW: So the answer is yes. We are making and always make money at volumes far lower than a million and the new Maserati, with more products and shared components and drivetrains, makes us well-equipped to compete.
Automobile: A V-6 engine is likely to show up in the forthcoming SUV (called the Maserati Levante). Will it be shared with Alfa Romeo, as well?

HW: No. We believe that you need to have – in this range of iconic brands and products – there are ingredients (like a well-functioning multi-media system) which just need to be properly adapted and work well, not creating problems, perfect function. And there are distinctive elements – for us it’s engines, transmissions, how the car drives, how it looks, the materials (there is no Maserati with fabric seats) and so on. So there is no intention to share this engine [with Alfa].
PG: You don’t mess with the soul of the brand.

Automobile: Describe the interplay between Alfa Romeo and Maserati. There was much grumbling among Fiat dealers when it was revealed Maserati dealers would be selling the Alfa 4C sports car, which they said they’d been promised, along with the rest of the coming U.S. Alfa line-up.
HW: We will reveal this May 6.
Automobile: I’d keep Ferrari and Maserati together and let the Fiat dealers have Alfa. That makes sense to me.

HW: There are some critical issues within a combination of Ferrari and Maserati –particularly with the Ghibli and maybe the entry-level QP – you are entering a new business. You have a lot of customers trading in cars.

PG: It’s not an order-taking business any longer. You have to have a legitimate used car business, you have to understand the customer needs that are different than what they are for the Ferrari owner.

The Ghibli opens up quite a bit of the U.S market for us. It’s a huge segment. Where maybe we didn’t have a lot of demand opportunity, now we do. So we’re expanding, we’ll be somewhere around 120 dealers in the U.S. at the end of this calendar year, up from seventy-four at the start of the year. And it’s not just a simple densification in some of these markets, it’s places that really have a large segment that we can hit. Some places you may not think of, but we’re underserved in the energy sector – Oklahoma City, Dallas, Houston we need expansion. There’s places like that we’re going into right now, where we’ve got some really solid dealers that have come to us and said ‘I like where this brand is going, can I be a part of it?’

We’re primarily going for standalone [dealers]. We’re not going into small markets where the business can’t stand on its own two feet. Separating from all the other brands because we really think we’ve got the product line. We’re requiring building a new showroom and we’re assuming that for the time being they’ll do some dedicated service at an existing location, we’ll dedicate technicians and stalls, then as the business grows…
Cross-shopping has been very positive for us. There are some fantastic dealers out there that really understand the space and Maserati is on their radar.
The new Maserati customer? The people who really love driving the car. There is a simplicity in driving the car; it’s more visceral than just transportation.
Automobile: Psychographics of the new Maserati customer?

PG: It’s real enthusiasts. The people who really love driving the car. There is a simplicity in driving the car where it’s more visceral than just transportation. If you go on the blogs, our target is exactly who seems to be buying the cars.

HW: From 1998 to 2002, I was the head of product development for the road cars at Ferrari. And that was the time that we were working on the fifth-generation Quattroporte of 2003. I left Ferrari in early 2002, then went to Magna – the first time I worked for a supplier after fifteen years with VW/Audi and then Ferrari – and then I came back in early 2004 and took charge of the QP. The first thing we did after some reorganization and Fiat product development was to fix the product issues with Maserati and then I took over the helm for [Maserati] in 2007. It took us seven or eight years to earn the right to go to the next level. (Shown here: 2014 Quattroporte.)
Automobile: We have heard the upcoming Maserati SUV is no longer on the Grand Cherokee platform and instead will rely on the pieces developed for Ghibli and Quattroporte.

HW: It’s a good thing for the brand. Technically it’s a little bit more tricky but we have fixed it. We won’t go to a million cars, but obviously sharing engines, transmissions, within the family is helpful from a cost perspective. It’s more an issue of the purity of the brand. It was both. It was component related. But it was also, we didn’t have a place to produce the car in Italy when the car was first discussed – it’s a big car, the dimensions of the body shop [were insufficient. But] we sorted it out. And for the purity of the brand, the credibility of the product, being 100% Maserati, it was always clear that it would be much better on something that is 100% Maserati.
Automobile: Which competitor is in your rearview mirror?
We won’t go to a million cars, but sharing engines, transmissions, within the family is helpful from a cost perspective. It’s more an issue of the purity of the brand.

HW: We are competing with the real big guys. Sometimes it seems to me they have infinite resources, each and every piece of technology. Nevertheless, there are significant points where we distinguish ourselves. We have a clear strategy, a good understanding of what Maserati stands for and it is pretty much in line to our story the absolute opposite of volume. Offering a real alternative, how you say, in this sea of sameness…It seems to me, you work in New York City, you leave your workplace, you take the metro train home, I think if you would reprogram their remote controls, the people squeezing the buttons, they would open just another, black, whatsoever car and drive home without even recognizing that they are sitting in the wrong seat.
Automobile: Volkswagen’s about to unleash new high-end SUVs from Porsche, Audi, Lamborghini, and Bentley. Does that mean that we can expect a Ferrari SUV one day soon?
HW: I don’t want to talk for Ferrari. But the answer is “no.”

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: If you are in the market for a sport-utility vehicle, you've already noticed how many there are to choose from. How to narrow it down? Beyond the obvious brand loyalty or aesthetic choices you might make, there are some practical considerations that might help. The first one is how many people you're carrying. If you only require five seats, you need to concentrate on the mid-size or possibly the compact segment. You also should consider if you actually need off-road capability or towing capacity. For many buyers it comes down to economy versus luxury, and this SUV, the GMC Terrain Denali, is aiming for the buyer who leans toward luxury at an affordable price point.

I just covered 1,500 miles of highway terrain in the 2014 GMC Terrain Denali AWD. This five-seater is GMC’s smallest sport-utility vehicle, built on the same platform as the Chevrolet Equinox. However, when it comes to sales, the Equinox is king: in 2013, the Terrain sold 99,525 while the Equinox sold 238,621. The Terrain is a relative newcomer, though, having made its debut for the 2010 model year, and the Denali version has only been out since 2013. To be honest, I had forgotten that the Terrain existed. But my cross-country trip gave me a wakeup call.

The Terrain and Equinox were given 2014 Top Safety Pick+ ratings from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, and they are the only mid-size SUVs of the nine evaluated to receive Good ratings in the Institute’s small overlap front crash test. That is huge. This may be reason enough to give serious consideration to the Terrain if you are a mid-size sport-ute buyer.

The Denali is the most upscale version of the Terrain. It shares the boxy shape and exaggerated fenders that make the Terrain recognizable. In the sea of sport-utility vehicles, that is a good thing. You can spot the Denali model by its honeycomb chrome grille, slightly different headlamps and taillamps, satin-chrome accents, and body-colored fascias and rocker panels. It also comes standard with a programmable power liftgate so that it can be set to open lower for vertically challenged drivers or shorter garages. For those who are enticed by bling, the Terrain Denali’s door sills are illuminated. The Denali comes standard with side blind zone alert and rear cross traffic alert.

There are two engines offered: a 2.4-liter four-cylinder and a 3.6-liter V-6. We opted for the V-6 that comes packaged with nineteen-inch wheels for $1,900. Both engines are paired with a six-speed automatic transmission, and both are available in either front-wheel or all-wheel drive models. The AWD version that we drove costs an additional $1,750. The extra power will cost a little in fuel economy but is still decent at 16 mpg city and a respectable 23-mpg highway. The Terrain Denali has dual-flow dampers that deliver a smoother ride. And I must agree it was a very smooth highway ride.
The driver and front-seat passenger have heated seats, and, even better, they are both eight-way power with lumbar. That, my friend, is essential for a long drive.

The driver and front-seat passenger have heated seats, and, even better, they are both eight-way power with lumbar. That, my friend, is essential for a long drive. They won my recommendation for a long haul—no chiropractor needed on your return home. The black padded dashboard has contrasting red stitching that coordinates with the glowing red gauges. I am not a fan of the red gauges, but it certainly was not a deal breaker. All Terrains come standard with a seven-inch touchscreen and a high-quality rearview camera. GMC has done a great job in making the cabin quiet. In fact, the cabin was a nice place to spend time while munching away miles across America.

Although the front seat is slightly claustrophobic, the middle row seats recline and can move forward or back eight inches, depending on whether you need more passenger or cargo space. It is downright roomy in the back seat and can easily take adults on long road trips. As I found on my drive, the front console is so deep that there is no need to have anything hanging around in the front passenger footwell. I easily stuffed in a camera, two phones, a small purse, several chargers, and enough candy to birth a cavity. I was disappointed that the USB receptacle was inside the console, making it awkward to use. There are four auxiliary plugs placed throughout the cabin that are more than adequate for keeping all your devices charged.

Adding navigation to the standard touchscreen audio with IntelliLink—that is GM speak for smartphone integration—is $795. Sadly, the nav failed me multiple times, but hopefully that was just a glitch. OnStar and SiriusXM satellite radio are standard; GMC throws in a six-month subscription to OnStar, and a three-month subscription  for SiriusXM. We included the rear-seat entertainment system that is built into the rear of the front seats for $1,295. It seems like a must for anyone with kids, but obviously a pass for empty nesters. The trailering package adds $350,  and the cargo management package that includes luggage crossbars, a rear cargo area net, and a cover costs $235. Add $495 for the special paint and $925 in destination, and bada bing, your Terrain Denali AWD now costs $42,900.

My driving was mostly on the highway, with some time spent in highly congested urban centers. The V-6 delivered the burst needed for passing seamlessly and was able to easily power this 4000-pound vehicle in both city and highway settings. I found that the A-pillar was a big blind spot, and in general I felt like the visibility was not great. That being said, the blind spot alert was literally a lifesaver on multiple occasions. I did find the lane departure alert annoying but would love to have my daughter, a teen driver, experience this option.

My route took me mostly over smooth pavement, but Michigan’s winter-battled roads proved the Terrain Denali is capable of skimming over rough roads while the cabin remains incredibly quiet. Both the smoothness and the quiet ride are byproducts of the dual-flow damper shocks. I also encountered a few twisty mountain sections that showcased the Terrain’s stability without displaying much body roll. I was pleasantly surprised that this sport-ute was fun to drive.

The Verdict:

The GMC Terrain is a contender for the sport-utility buyer who only needs to seat five and craves some of the finer amenities. It is especially comfortable for long drives, even for fully grown adults in the rear, with the sliding rear seats. That alone makes this car a winner. If you upgrade to the Denali version, almost everything is standard including outstanding safety features, and it has a damn good-looking interior to boot. The GMC may not be a status symbol to everyone, but the shiny chrome grille does look upscale.

2014 GMC Terrain Denali AWD

Price: $27,390 (base model); $37,830 (base price of Terrain Denali); $42,900 (this model) (all prices include destination charge)
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6, 301 horsepower, 272 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/24 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Side blind zone alert
Option I can’t live without: Heated front seats (standard on Denali model)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, forward collision alert, lane departure warning, blind spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, power sunroof, power rear liftgate, heated front seats, voice-activated audio controls, leather seating and steering wheel
Notable options: Rear-seat entertainment system ($1,295), navigation with IntelliLink ($795), cargo package with trunk cargo cover ($235), crystal red tintcoat paint ($495)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Equinox, Ford Edge Sport, Hyundai Santa Fe Sport, Mazda CX-7, Mitsubishi Outlander, Kia Sorento SX, Nissan Murano, Toyota Highlander

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: The Ford Mustang has many fine qualities, not least of which is its sparkling color palette. So it's logical that Ford would offer nail polish in shades to match. Right?

It's for that reason that I was able to choose "The Sky’s My Limit" and get my nails painted right in the middle of the New York Auto Show at the Jacob Javits Center on Manhattan's West Side this week.

The shimmery aqua I chose is part of a limited-edition issue of nail lacquer by the well-known firm OPI that you'll actually be able to buy soon. The six-hue collection is being launched in July in collaboration with the fiftieth anniversary of the Ford Mustang. The other Mustang-inspired hues in the limited edition collection are Race Red (pays tribute to Mustang’s signature color), 50 Years of Style (a partygoing golden pearl), Queen of the Road (jet black, inspired by the pony car's black interior), Girls Love Ponies (which, despite the name, is a grownup shade of pink), and Angel with a Leadfoot (a statement-making white).

“Nail color, just like the car she drives, is the ultimate expression of a woman’s personality,” you won't be surprised to hear Suzi Weiss-Fischmann, OPI co-founder, say. “Automobiles are synonymous with style, and there is a special kind of love affair between a woman and her car.”

I agree. I love my cars and my nails! So, as I was having them polished at the Ford booth, I asked one of Ford’s PR team members if there was any chance of more cosmetics collaborations in the future.
“I’m working on lipstick,” she smiled.
(FYI: The ladies weren’t the only peeps getting their nails done. A few of the trendier guys came in to get one nail painted black.)

pageElements.text: If there was ever a time when an electric car was considered dull, underpowered, or wonkish, that day is most definitely done now: ultraluxe automaker Bentley has rolled out the Hybrid Concept at the Beijing Auto Show. What's more, the company has announced that "at least 90 percent" of Bentleys will be available in plug-in hybrid form by the end of this decade.

The Bentley Hybrid Concept is based on the British company's flagship Mulsanne and has its 6.75-liter twin-turbocharged V-8 that makes 505 horsepower. The plug-in system increases power by up to 25 percent while it cuts emissions by 70 percent, Bentley says, and that's sure to be of interest in the ecologically challenged cities of China. As Bentley chairman and CEO Wolfgang Schreiber told media at the concept's debut, the point is to add "performance and efficiency with no compromise to luxury." Driving range on solely electric power is a less than dazzling thirty-one miles, but, Schreiber noted, making a car from this ultra-luxury sector into a plug-in is still in the "exciting future" category.
Another interesting feature of the Bentley Hybrid Concept is the use of copper styling both inside and out, including grille and headlamp trim and copper cross-stitching in the leather seating.
This Hybrid Concept is an advance look at an upcoming SUV from Bentley, which is set to go on sale in 2016 as a twelve-cylinder gasoline-powered model, with the plug-in hybrid version coming in 2017.

How many people actually buy Bentleys? Although sales were up nineteen percent in 2013, the total still barely topped 10,000. Of those, though, a surprising 2,191 went to Chinese buyers, while 3,140 were sold in North America.

It's not shocking that Bentley would choose Beijing for the Hybrid Concept's debut. It's a key market for Bentley, and in response there were three Chinese debuts at the show this week: the new Flying Spur V8 (shown here) and Continental GT Speed, and the GT V8 S. The Continental GT Speed has a top speed of 206 mph, making it Bentley's fastest ever production car. And the 500-horsepower Flying Spur's range on a tank of old-school gasoline is 497 miles: perhaps more like it for the new-school Chinese luxury-car buyer, at least for now.

pageElements.text: This month, Consumer Reports announced it has implemented a new car seat crash test protocol. The consumer organization believes these changes will better simulate the kind of accidents that unfortunately happen in the real world. In this new testing, the car seat being tested is secured onto a new bench made of stiffer materials that more closely mimic the average auto’s interior as well as the angle at which the car seat will likely sit. Second, the testing now incorporates a surface that approximates the back of the front seat, a common factor in frontal crash injuries. And the standard simulation speed of 30 mph for a frontal impact has been increased to 35 mph. Here's a video explanation of the new testing:

Of course, testing is important, but it loses meaning if you don’t use the appropriate seat for your child. To find the right fit for your newborn, toddler,  or elementary school kid, and to find tips for proper installation, try some of these resources.

1. Know the Kind You Need

Clear and concise explanations of the various types of child restraints (rear facing, forward facing, booster and seat belt) and how to use them are available at Parents Central from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Its car seat recommendations page is color coded and simple to understand. Also look there for a useful downloadable brochure that even has a Vehicle Safety Features chart which gets super detailed about LATCH tether locations, types of air bags, and more for every vehicle model.

Or check our earlier story, What Car Seat When?
If you prefer a video explanation of the various car seat types, a great place to visit is AAA’s Car Seat Safety: A How-to Guide.

2. Find One That's Easy to Use

Securing a squirming toddler already has its challenges without the car seat functions complicating matters. “Ease of use” takes into account factors like clarity of labels and instructions as well simplicity in making necessary adjustments or completing installation. Consult NHTSA's Ease of Use ratings for individual child seats.

3. Then, Install It Correctly

It’s worth repeating. Read the instructions thoroughly for your particular car seat before installing it in your vehicle. Additionally, visit the manufacturer’s website. Many now have detailed video demonstrations for each of their child restraint models. If you're shopping for a new car, always take the car seat with you and make sure it fits well in the back seat.

Still not sure that you’ve done it right? Safecar.gov helps you find an inspection station near you by state or zip code. Stations will have a technician available to physically install your car seat correctly and teach you how to do it yourself. We visited one and made a video; watch it here.

4. Register and Watch for Recalls

It takes a little extra time, but make sure to register your new car seat with the manufacturer so you'll receive vital safety updates or recall information. Parents Central has a “registration and recalls” page that makes it easy to go to your manufacturer’s registration page directly. Then, sign up to get automatic recall notices from NHTSA.

All the due diligence you’ll do to find the right car seat is worth it.  The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report that the use of child restraints in passenger vehicles reduces the risk of death in infants by 71 percent and in toddlers by 54 percent.  Those are life-saving statistics parents can’t afford to ignore.

title: Privacy and Your Connected Car
subTitle: Where's your protection? You'll be glad to know tech geeks are sweating it out right here and now.
promoTeaserSmall: Where's your protection? You'll be glad to know tech geeks are sweating it out right here and now.
promoTeaser: Where's your protection? You'll be glad to know tech geeks are sweating it out right here and now.
metaTitle: Privacy and Your Connected Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute
metaDescription: Privacy and Your Connected Car: Where's your protection? You'll be glad to know tech geeks are sweating it out right here and now.  Read my report on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: We, as modern drivers, are sitting right on the very edge of a whole new world. If you’ve driven a car with “smart” cruise control, lane-keeping assist, and other active safety features, you’ve sampled it. Connectivity has given us more convenience and more safety, and sooner than you think, all of our rides will be communicating seamlessly with other cars and the infrastructure of roads and signage around them.

In fact, right here in Ann Arbor, Michigan, the world's largest test bed for connected vehicles is taking shape. The University of Michigan's Transportation Research Institute (UMTRI) coordinates the academic/government/industry effort called the Michigan Mobility Transformation Center, where the real-world use of vehicle-to-vehicle and vehicle-to-infrastructure communication is being perfected, complete with a test track.
There is so much new technology in our cars! It's all so fun! Who wants to think about the coding that's underneath it, and whether it respects us? Probably not you.

Yet, we have to think about it, for no other reason than that our own sense of the car as a private, personal space may be at risk. In fact, it seems nearly certain that we have already handed over at least some sense of being alone in the car. In exchange, we are getting a lot more guidance in terms of navigation, active safety, and Internet connectivity. The payoff could be a drastic reduction in the kinds of accidents caused by driver error, which is to say, most of them.

I walked in to the Global Symposium on Connected Vehicles and Infrastructure, well aware of my lack of deep technical understanding, but determined to figure out what's up with security and privacy in these fast-developing connected automobiles. You will be as glad as I was to know that these highly educated, deeply qualified scientists all over the world are all over this issue, with plans that are starting to bear fruit.

In the AP Calc reunion that was the session on "V2X Policy: Next Steps, Security and Privacy," I listened, fascinated, as five actively engaged experts dove into the subject of taking on what one called a "Wild West" environment and making it both protective of our privacy and resilient against hackers.

Andrew Smart of SAE International mused, "We all know that the first space shuttle had 420,000 lines of code. Now, today's auto industry has 40 million lines of code as of a couple of years ago. In five years' time, that should go up to 100 million plus." Faced with this complexity, the challenge, he said, is to ensure that it's as error-free and hacker-resistant as possible.
Once upon a time, it was man and machine in harmony. Now, with vehicle to Internet, it's one upon many. Engineers need to deal with the increased complexity.
As Smart put it: "Once upon a time, it was man and machine in harmony. Now, with vehicle to Internet, it's one upon many. Engineers need to deal with the increased complexity."

André Weimerskirch of UMTRI, an internationally known expert in automotive cybersecurity, has given this issue a lot of thought. In a marvel of understatement, he told the group: “It’s fairly simple to imagine that once you have electronics in the car that control your car and can accelerate, de-accererate, and steer, if someone can hack into the car, that is not good for us.”

He outlined three "hot spots" for cybersecurity research into cars. The first is misbehavior handling: "to be prepared and know what to do if someone successfully hacks into the car." Researchers are creating a comprehensive "misbehavior authority" that would include protection against attacks by design and also have a "plan B" in place if the security is breached. The second is creating and implementing standards for every level of automated vehicle, with testing solutions. And the third is privacy in the vehicle-to-vehicle domain, which he said was "highly desired and was included by design." Privacy protection for new applications, as they are invented, will have to be carefully considered, he said.

The quantum change, as Weimerskirch pointed out, is that vehicles are connected over a wireless interface—but “the models we know from the PC world” can’t just be carried over in a safety-critical environment like a car.

It’s too late to ask whether we want this level of connectivity: it's here. But, based on what I saw at this session, it’s reassuring that bright minds are working on compartmentalizing the interiors of our cars so that we get the connectivity we need and at least some level of privacy and protection from hackers. The nightmare scenario of some James Bond villain making your brakes go out on a lonely road by the click of a mouse? Not so much. As A2 Technology Management's Tom Schaffnit quipped, “I don’t think anybody in their right mind would be running their brake system on Android. There’s going to be compartmentalization in terms of what operating systems are used. Most critical systems are embedded and don’t run on Google or other platforms.”

Schaffnit said the five tasks on order are privacy by design (and policy), nationwide interoperability, integrated support for vehicle-to-vehicle and vehicle-to-Internet operations, safety, mobility, and environmental applications, and support for commercial and proprietary applications.

Walt Fehr of the Department of Transportation commented, “There may need to be a fundamentally different way a vehicle connects to the Internet now that we have the possibility of mandated communication-based technology.”
That's encouraging.
Always go for privacy by design. Store only data that is necessary and, more important, have technical limitations to access the data in the first place.

Weimerskirch went on: “You want to be in control of the data that your vehicle stores, but there are many other applications of privacy. People talk about Big Data where diagnostic data of your car is stored in the cloud or in a server. Insurance discounts are offered today where you plug in something to collect data.” If you think about it, there isn’t much that your car will not tell about you and your life, he said.

His watchword, and that of others, which I heard over and over at the session: "Always go for privacy by design. Store only data that is necessary and, more important, have technical limitations to access the data in the first place."

It’s all starting to finally come to fruition, as the DOT’s Walt Fehr said.  This summer, they are completing the fundamentals of the connected vehicle and will be demonstrating how the “elegant solutions” already at use in crash avoidance technology are being extended to overall connected vehicle technology.

“Whatever we come up with here, he said, “any of these processes have to be deployable in a continent-wide scale. That’s why we’re inviting everyone we can think of to collaborate with us as we build out one of the first complete working connected transportation systems using all of these communication media.”
Stay tuned, because this is just starting to get really interesting.

title: Ferrari FF Spa-and-Drive
subTitle: A day with a friend driving Ferrari's four-seater in the moneyed hippie enclave of Ojai, California.

promoTeaser: A day with a friend driving Ferrari's four-seater in the moneyed hippie enclave of Ojai, California.
metaDescription: Ferrari FF to the Spa: I had the opportunity to go for a little spin in Ferrari's four-seater. My story. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: The Ferrari FF is about as counterintuitive as it gets: a two-door four-seater that not only seats four but can rocket them across the asphalt at 208 mph, it’s a super sporty SUV alternative for individuals with an insatiable need for speed and the means to indulge it.

It is, perhaps, Ferrari’s least Ferrari-like sports car. So, when offered the opportunity to drive it for a weekend, I decided to use the $295,000 FF for an equally unlikely purpose: a girls' getaway to Ojai, California. The itinerary: spa treatments and a vegan lunch that wouldn’t quite compensate for the gluttony of a 13-mpg V-12, followed by a thrill ride through the canyons.

I was hoping for a full house—to pack the FF’s four seats with fellow moms equally desperate for a child-free getaway. Alas, there is baseball. I was only able to swap one of my friends' field-side lawn chairs for a leather bucket seat.

But that friend was enormously appreciative. A high-school librarian who is so in love with books that she even brought one along for the trip, she immediately compared the FF’s tactile brown leather to the tomes she shelves daily.
“This is the librarian’s Ferrari,” my friend, Sara, cooed after settling into the low-slung passenger seat and craning her neck to see over the hand-stitched dashboard.
As we headed up Southern California’s Highway 101, en route to the twisty roads that circle the moneyed hippie enclave that is Ojai, that impression was confirmed.

“I thought people would want to race us,” she said, with a hint of disappointment. As the driver of a sensible Mazda 3 hatchback, Sara isn’t one to fawn over exotics, but her deflated expectation was undeniable. “There aren’t even that many people staring.”

It was true. Painted silver and having an elongated hood and overall profile that defies the Ferrari stereotype, the FF is, to the casual observer, an understatement. But pressing pedal to metal, it’s even more responsive than a 458 Italia, its exhaust pipes just as thunderous.

I pitied the women who were relaxing to a chimes-and-chants soundtrack as their flesh was massaged at the Day Spa of Ojai. We could have been cited for disturbing the peace as we pulled in to the parking lot—and back out a few minutes later, since there was no availability. Our fellow patrons at the less-ritzy Bamboo Creek Spa, however, didn’t seem to mind. And the folks passing by the Hip Vegan Cafe, where we dined on raw salads with walnut “burgers” and sipped coconut water, were downright appreciative of the unexpected four-wheeled delight we’d driven into Prius-ville.
“Lots of people have been taking pictures of your car,” said a woman who was holding a bake sale near our parking space. “I didn’t let them touch it too much,” she smiled.
“Ooh, fancy,” a woman in yoga pants commented as we opened the doors to the FF and strapped in for a ride along the Ojai Freeway.

Esteemed as one of the best driving roads in Southern California, its seventy-one miles are a smorgasbord of twists and sweeping vistas that inspire drivers toward idiocy, and I was no exception. The FF was especially adept at indulging my usual character flaw—doubling the posted corner speeds—so much so that I noticed Sara was white-knuckling the grab bar.
“Would you mind slowing down?” she asked. “I don’t mean to be a nerd, but you’re scaring me.”

Truth be told, I was also scaring myself. Ferraris have a habit of outing one’s moron gene, even if it’s ordinarily recessive, so I was happy to oblige and keep my speed to a reasonable 40 mph. Much to my chagrin, and Sara’s relief, I’m sure, the Ojai Freeway was cut short just ten miles north of Ojai due to seasonal road construction, so we doubled back.

Seventy miles later, we were back in the land that is most appreciative of the sports car that got us there: status-conscious L.A., where residents’ ears are tuned to Ferrari’s beautiful racket and the exclusive novelty of its dark horse, the FF.

2014 Ferrari FF

Four-wheel drive four-seater
Base price: $295,000
Engine: 6.3-liter V-12, 651 horsepower, 504 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 11 mpg city/17 mpg highway

For fun in selecting color, trim, and options on an FF (prancing horses embroidered on the headrests? Carbon fiber steering wheel? Daytona-style seats?), visit Ferrari's configurator.

pageElements.text: The FF stands for Ferrari Four meaning that rumbling V12 engine is in service of the closest the Italian carmaker comes to a four-seat family vehicle.  Something like a crossover masquerading in an exotic’s clothing the all-wheel drive can take the corners and also give you confidence in those mountain snowstorms.  Pop the back hatch to access the generous storage compartment for luggage or sports equipment. Each seat feels like its own little cockpit and the two rear ones fold down when necessary to extend cargo space.  Slide into the leather-covered cabin and enjoy meticulous Italian detail at every turn. If you plan on taking grandma for a ride she’ll need to use the front seat since, unlike the four-door Aston Martin Rapide, the FF has only two doors making easy rear access a challenge for some. However, when you step on the gas and feel the revs climb up to 8200 rpm there will be no doubt why you spent around $300,000 to own this versatile supercar.  The back-heavy look of the FF can seem like a departure from the classic Ferrari exterior silhouette and will not appeal to everyone.  However, enough prancing horse signatures remain to satisfy the buyer seeking a rarified vehicle that can get the groceries or tear up the track depending on their mood.

metaDescription: Tire Testing on Michelin's Turf: Learning about the new Premier A/S EverGrip tire, and the charming city Michelin calls home in the U.S., with an all-female journalist group. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text:
Last week I packed my bag for South Carolina. I had been invited by Michelin to come as their guest for a visit to the proving ground outside Greenville in order to learn firsthand about the company's new tire breakthrough, the Premier A/S all-season tire with EverGrip.

The event was for women in the media, some from automotive publications but mostly from female-oriented magazines, websites, and blogs. I was thrilled to abandon the frigid Michigan winter for some southern warmth. So, when I arrived on a Monday afternoon to the Greenville Spartanburg airport, a lovely little transportation hub nestled into a wooded landscape, the unseasonably cold 50 degrees felt like mid-July to this northerner.

The French tire company’s presence is deeply felt in this area. On the drive in from the airport, I already spied its North American headquarters just off the highway. Michelin established itself in South Carolina in the 1970s, taking advantage of the skilled workforce that was being displaced by the disappearing textile industry. The company now has nine plants in the state, so it’s not surprising that on my walk around Greenville's well-executed downtown revitalization along the Reedy River, I stumbled upon Michelin on Main, a retail specialty store devoted to selling clothing and other collectibles with the store’s world-famous logo.

Alas, the store closes early on Mondays.  I could only press my face to the glass, survey the goods from the outside, and gaze at the life-size statue of the Michelin Man within. Did you know he’s one of the world’s oldest trademarks and he has a name? It’s Bibendum, or “Bib” for short, and it means, “Now is the time to drink.”  (That comes from an original ad, in which he "drank" road obstacles such as nails and metal parts.) Hmmm.  Luckily, Michelin had already sent me a stuffed Build-A-Bear version of Bib, so I didn’t feel cheated by the closed doors and pressed on to see what else I could find in Greenville.

At Falls Park I came upon a stunning suspension bridge that curved out over the dropping hillside.  It was glorious to see swaths of purple impatiens and pink blossoming trees as I climbed back up to the search Greenville’s West End shops, only to find them mostly shuttered.  And then I saw it.  Perched on the edge of the ravine was Pedal Chic, a charming girl-centric bike shop with bistro tables on the outside and mint green Bianchi bikes on the inside.

It took only a few minutes for me to select a pink Pedal Chic saddlebag for my daughter and discover the manager, Lisa Parks, and I are both from the Detroit suburb of Birmingham, Michigan.  As we chatted about the charm of Greenville, the joy of biking, and what a small world it really is, in came a couple of men in serious bike gear, one needing a quick wheel adjustment.  The bike mechanic was gone, Pedal Chic was closing, but Lisa let him use the tools.

Turns out the man in need was Lee Willard, the Michelin engineer who designed the revolutionary “run flat” tire. Later on I found out he has also been a pivotal force in the Chevrolet Corvette's tire design. Naturally, he knows Jean. Lee told me that Greenville is more than just a one-company town: besides Michelin and BMW, Greenville is becoming a magnet for European investment, so you never know what kind of accent you might run across. Lee and his friend were headed out biking on the Swamp Rabbit Trail, part of his training regime for the upcoming 24 Hours of Le Mans. I wished them good riding and took off for my dinner at The Loft at Soby’s. Lee gave me a wave and a parting message for Jean. “Tell her to come to Le Mans!” If she doesn’t want to go, hey, I’ll take that invitation.

The Michelin gathering that night was delicious and a bit surreal as Bib posed for pictures with us on the rooftop deck one minute and passed a plate of crab cakes the next. Surveying the dinner table later, I was struck with the thought that years ago, when I was a program staffer at these kinds of automotive events, I was often the only woman in the room. Now, as a mother of a ten-year-old daughter, it was encouraging to see all women reporters chatting with product marketing director Cyrille Roget, one of the few men in the room from Michelin, about the challenges of de-molding the uniquely treaded Premier A/S tire (shown here).  Or hear female voices grilling technical marketing manager Sarah Robinson on how much driving time we would get on the track.

The next morning we arrived at the rain-soaked proving ground, and Tiffane Thompson, Michelin's country operations manager, explained just what makes the Premier A/S so different. First the EverGrip rubber recipe calls for a greatly increased amount of silica to enhance grip plus the addition of sunflower oil to boost traction. Second, there’s a whole new groove, expanding rain grooves to be exact, which give the Premier A/S the ability to keep evacuating water efficiently even as it wears. And last, a bit of tire magic: emerging grooves. You don’t see them when the tire is new, but more than 150 new grooves appear along the sides of the tire surface as it wears over time. Michelin commissioned this video from The Fast Draw’s Mitch Butler to lay out the tire’s new features. The result of all this cutting edge technology? Better stopping power in the wet weather and more bite in snowy conditions even as the tire clocks the miles.
It's tire magic: emerging grooves. You don’t see them when the tire is new, but more than 150 new grooves appear along the sides of the tire surface over time.

We would need stopping power since dark clouds rolled in again that afternoon, and even some hail graced the asphalt during our safety exercises, which I'll be detailing in an article to come. The main event was our chance to see what the Michelin engineers mean when they say the Premier is “safe when worn” by participating in a stopping distance comparison.  By turns, we got to drive three Cadillac CTS sedans: one equipped with new Bridgestone Turanza Serenity Plus tires; one with new Goodyear Assurance Triple Tread A/S tires; and one with half-worn Michelin Premier A/S tires at about 5/32 of an inch, about half the tread depth when new. The sun finally appeared, we shed our ponchos, and we got our chance to be the test drivers.

I was paired with engineer Michelle Phillips, who gave me my instructions to get the car up to speed and then hit the cruise control, which was set to 50 mph. We drove onto a wet patch of road, and I hit the brakes hard at a tall orange cone. The car was wired to register how far it traveled before coming to a complete stop. My first ride was on the Michelins, which stopped at 110 feet. The second time through, on the Goodyears, held up at 123 feet. My third outing was on the Bridgestones; the car fully arrested at 121 feet. I was impressed, considering the worn Michelins stopped me about a car length sooner than the others. We registered all our results on a comparison chart in the Michelin tent, and I noticed that many of my fellow participants experienced an even a more significant gap between the worn Michelins and the two competing brand-new tires, mostly in the fifteen-foot range. It was thought-provoking data.

The Michelin Premier A/S made its debut in stores on April 2.  It comes in thirty-two sizes, retails for about $156 per tire, and carries a 60,000-mile warranty. Since the new tire is designed for comfort and longer-term driving security, the initial release is geared toward sedans. Interested SUV and light-truck drivers can expect an LTX version to come out in the fall.

Eventually, it was time to leave Michelin country and my new girlfriends behind. Within two hours, I arrived back to a wind-chilled Detroit Metro Airport but warm embraces from my husband and daughter. As I recounted my experiences at the track, my husband broke in with a question. “So, what kind of tires do we have on our car?”

Has Michelin Made a Safer Tire? January 14, 2014

title: In Pursuit of a Happy Commute
subTitle: Three ways to make the drive better for your health and well-being.
promoTitle: In Pursuit of a Happy Commute

metaDescription: In Pursuit of a Happy Commute - News flash: Ford study finds commutes aren't great for your health or well-being. Three solutions. Read them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: Do you think that your commute is a grind? You’re not alone.

In a recent survey conducted by Ford Motor Company, polling 800 American adults who commute to work with their own vehicles or by carpool, almost half said they always or frequently encounter traffic while commuting.
The drivers described their commutes as frustrating, stressful, unpredictable, and long.  A note: 47 percent of the 800 respondents were women.
Ford wants to change this mind state with "The Pursuit of a Happy Commute," a campaign that examines how your commute affects well-being, relationships, mood, and money.  And what to do about it.

To ignite the initiative, the automaker invited us to a lunch/discussion in New York City, moderated by Catt Sadler of E! News (who is shown above), with Flywheel (spin) co-founder Ruth Zukerman and author/relationship expert Steve Santagati.
The findings:

1. Driving is eating up our free time.

Two-thirds of Americans spend at least thirty minutes commuting, which is more time than they are exercising.

The cure: The mind/body connection.

Make the extra effort to plug in exercise before or after your journey; you’ll feel so much better. Eating a healthy diet is key. Forgo fast foods, and check out Food Tripping, an app for Android and iOS developed by Ford and SHFT.com. It shows you a variety of healthy food resources, from farm-to-table restaurants and juice bars to fresh produce stands and organic grocery stores. Then, of course, there's planning ahead: I always keep wholesome snacks like nuts and raisins, whole-grain crackers, and apples in my glove compartment to keep me from getting too hungry.

2. Multitasking is common.

As the Ford survey shows, commuters do things other than drive while they're on the road. They listen to the news, radio, podcasts or e-books. Two out of five make personal or work-related phone calls, and nearly a quarter of commuters grab a snack or meal when on the road. Some even put on makeup or fix their hair (that would be me!).

The cure: Give yourself a break.

Try to stop multitasking in the car and get off the grid. To help commuters do this, Ford has developed a Do Not Disturb feature to block calls. The idea is to let you disconnect on the way home and thereby decrease your stress levels. If you don’t drive a Ford, you can just elect to turn off your phone. And if you’re going to listen to tunes, or if you find your blood boiling, put on some soothing spa tunes or classical music, or chill out to jazz.

3. Most of us don’t consider our commute a happy place.

More than half of commuters feel that their commute has little positive impact on their lives. They say that it takes away from: Maintaining a regular exercise routine and eating healthy Spending quality time with family and friends. Having personal interests or hobbies.

The cure: Navigate your way to a better result.

Avoid traffic jam headaches by using your nav system to dodge the gridlock. Check out alternative routes. Even if you drive more miles, you’ll get to where you’re going feeling less stressed.

And another cure: Change your attitude and put a smile on your face.

Catt Sadler lives in Los Angeles, where traffic jams burden each driver with an average of sixty-four wasted hours a year. That's on top of already heavy commute schedules. At the Ford meeting, she quipped: “Let’s think about collective happy commuting. Let someone pass, pay attention to your neighbor, and send them a small dose of “carma.”

One last reminder: Hands on the wheel, eyes on the road. Steve Santagati reminded us, “Never forget that you have thousands of pounds of steel under you. Your number-one priority is watching the road!”

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: April is Car Care Month, and as part of that, you get to see my mug on the dirt-encrusted window of a car. You're welcome!

Yes, it has come to this: famous "dirty windshield" artist Scott Wade was asked by Sears Auto to immortalize Automobile Magazine, Jean Knows Cars, and me in dirt. ("Immortalize"? Let me get a hose...)

This is a man who grew up in central Texas on a long dirt road. Every car around him was perennially covered by a thin layer of limestone and clay, and he started drawing on the windows because, why not? First with a fingernail, then with a Popsicle stick, then with brushes, and it all leads straight downhill to my face. Thank you, Scott. Thank you very much. My mother will relate to this, I promise you.
You can see some of Scott Wade's other dirt-works on his website, Dirty Car Art, and a quick time-lapse of the work in progress below.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Do you know what to do if one of your tires blows out while you are driving? Well, if your car has something like Bridgestone’s brand-new DriveGuards on, you just keep on driving. That is because they are run-flat tires. You can actually drive for up to fifty miles at 50 mph after a puncture or even complete loss of air. No more dangerous side-of-the-road replacing necessary.

In the past, run-flat tires were limited to vehicles that were equipped with them at the factory. Not anymore: DriveGuard is a new family of all-season run-flat tires, the first you can buy aftermarket. With them, Bridgestone is aiming for the sweet spot as replacement tires on today's bestselling coupes, sedans, and wagons that came from the factory with standard tires. The one caveat is that the vehicle must be equipped with a tire pressure monitoring system.
My mind flashed back to a recent scare with my octogenarian parents, who experienced a blowout in a remote area and were stranded until a kind motorist stopped.

Bridgestone recently invited me to drive cars at a track to compare the DriveGuard with conventional tires. They released all of the air in the front left tire right in front of me and then told me to take a lap and to make sure I hit 50 mph. Then I was asked to make lane changes and experiment with hard braking. I dutifully did all three tasks. There was absolutely no pulling, and other than a slight clunking the car handled normally. My mind flashed back to a recent scare with my octogenarian parents, who experienced a blowout in a remote area of the upper peninsula of Michigan. Luckily they did not lose control of their vehicle, but they were stranded until a kind motorist stopped and helped them out. Perhaps DriveGuards are the perfect Christmas gift.

Run-flats have a reputation for delivering a stiff ride thanks to their reinforced sidewalls. But Bridgestone has worked some molecular magic on the DriveGuard tires. They have a lighter-weight construction while still maintaining the strength to support the vehicle weight with zero pressure.

The tire also has cooling fins built into the exterior of the sidewalls. Heat is Kryptonite to tires, and when the tire has less than the optimal amount of air the temperature of the rubber begins to rise. Eventually the tire starts to break apart.

I tested the DriveGuards side by side with conventional tires, including Bridgestone’s best-selling Turanza Serenity Plus. I could not tell the difference in ride even on skidpads with very tight cornering.

Michigan would prove a worthy adversary for any tire right now. Our roads are chewing up tires at an alarming rate. Bridgestone will replace your tire in the first year or 12,000 miles if it can’t be repaired. There is also a tread-wear warranty of up to 60,000 miles. I recently had to replace a factory-installed Yokohama tire on my less-than-one-year-old car and did not have that coverage. You can also take advantage of the Buy & Try program: drive on them for thirty days, and if you aren’t satisfied, you can return them. But in order to switch to a DriveGuard, you need to switch out all four tires.
These are all-season tires, so if you want a winter tire as well, you will need to switch to conventional tires when the snow starts to blow.

At the time of my visit the pricing was not set, but Bridgestone did say the run-flats will cost about as much as the all-season Turanza Serenity Plus line. So a safe estimate is between $400 and $800 a set, depending on size. That's not bad for a tire that is able to let you keep driving until you can safely drive it to a repair shop. I once had a flat while on my way to a job interview. It would have been nice to be able to go to the interview and deal with my tire trauma afterward.

When it gets right down to making the decision to switch to run-flats, consider just how important your tires are to safety. Consumers often forget how important the rubber is when it comes to automotive safety. Airbags, traction control, blind spot alerts, and other accident prevention technologies are very important. But also remember that you are literally sitting on arguably the most important safety feature in your car: the tires. The contact patch—the part of the tire that actually touches the road—is only about the size of your hand. So next time you are considering a tire and are comparing prices, you may also want to add into the equation if the added safety of run-flats might be worth a few more Benjamins.

metaDescription: Connected Cars: 7 Things to Know: How soon will your car join the conversation? . An update from inside the Ann Arbor pilot project. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The comparison of the city streets outside my window with Disney World doesn't immediately come to mind. But it was interesting to hear the perspective of Francine Romine, head of marketing and communications for the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute (UMTRI).

Romine recently went to the Magic Kingdom, and on entering she and her husband were issued Magic Band wristbands. These connected bits of plastic absorb the owner's identity, both personal and financial, and are used to open hotel room doors, get access to theme parks, make reservations at restaurants and for shows, and to make purchases. "My husband was not so excited that you could just swipe the wristband and the money would immediately be removed from our bank account," she said with a laugh.
That's pretty Magic, all right. But it makes Romine's point about connected technology in cars: "If you want the benefits of the latest technology, you'll have to suspend some concerns," she said.

I guess you could say that I, personally, suspended a concern or two when I was one of the initial signups to UMTRI's Safety Pilot connected car program in Ann Arbor. For a year now, I've had one of UMTRI's data collector devices installed on my car, putting out communication to other cars and to devices at the roadside around town. Am I worried that Big Brother is watching? Well, not really. I'm more interested in the idea that cars are becoming more than silent lumps of sheetmetal and are able to interact with each other in a modern way that will advance safety. Call me in denial; maybe all the people at Disney World are, too. But the tradeoff might be worth it.

At this week's Global Symposium on Connected Vehicles and Infrastructure, UMTRI has brought together experts from around the world to talk about progress of its program and encourage discussion about making connected technology as globally secure and useful as possible. The Safety Pilot program was much talked about.
Here are some fun facts I learned:

1. It's huge.

The Safety Pilot program started in late 2012 and enlisted 2,800 participants (including me) who have allowed UMTRI to install devices in their cars. Most, like mine, send and receive signals without doing anything you can see, hear, or detect from inside the car. A few are equipped to alert the driver about safety issues such as impending collisions or traffic issues. All the devices store data that researchers are using as a rich mine of information to help develop connected-vehicle technology. From 2012 until now, these devices have collectively recorded 3.9 million trips or 24.6 million miles on the roads, and they've sent out 30 billion basic safety messages through the technology. And about 80 percent of the time when the participating cars are on the road, they've come into contact with another connected vehicle. Kind of amazing considering the small size of the participant group! But really, this whole thing is similar to, but more interesting than, the gathering of market data that Disney is looking for when it hands out those Magic Bands.

2. It's diverse.

Among the participants are six motorcycles, which ran up 4,676 connected miles from May to November last year. During that time, they encountered another connected pilot vehicle 4,376 times. They've collected useful data on kinematics and motorcyclist behavior that University of Michigan engineering students are analyzing as we speak.
A participant about to hit the roads next week is a bicyclist.

3. It's growing.

The project put out a call to grow the number of participating vehicles to 9,000. On the day an article appeared on the local Ann Arbor newspaper's website, 500 people called to volunteer. The next step is to expand the program from one part of Ann Arbor outward to all of southeastern Michigan, with a planned participant base of 20,000 vehicles.

4. It has a really important point.

Mike Shulman of Ford is technical lead of the Crash Avoidance Metrics Partnership (CAMP), which is a consortium of several automakers working on connected-vehicle technology. . "If drivers are pretty good most of the time," he says, "every once in a while, not so much, and when you aggregate over the whole population you see 32,000 fatalities." He notes that early estimates suggested vehicle-to-vehicle communication could help avoid 80 percent of crashes. That's a persuasive argument.

5. It's going to be complicated.

UMTRI's Sayer says it's no good creating connected vehicles that become obsolete, noting that every device in the Safety Pilot program had to come in for at least one software update this year. "We need something that drivers, passengers, and pedestrians are going to maintain," he said.

Automakers, through the CAMP consortium and other efforts, are working together on setting standards, test procedures, and safety requirements. Such things as retrofitting existing vehicles or selling the connected technology as an aftermarket product? That's all still up in the air. So is figuring out how the devices would be maintained and updated.

6. It's going to be expensive to set up.

Shulman commented: "We can demonstrate a bunch of operations, but the infrastructure guys are really broke, and they've got to be convinced this is a good thing to invest their money in. Is Montana going to do this? We need the data that enables people to make those investment decisions."

NHTSA is looking at the cost over a forty-year time horizon. That's some amortization table. Does the benefit outweigh the cost? The agency is slated to release a decision paper and analysis soon that should have some answers.

7. It has all kinds of possibilities.

For example, UMTRI principal investigator Jim Sayer said, a couple of temperature/moisture sensors were embedded in the pavement around Ann Arbor to issue an ice formation warning. (It must have gotten quite a workout in this winter of record-setting snowstorms.) This application collected and analyzed conditions and lowered the recommended speed on the roadway in response. People are used to getting warnings from their cars and, as Shulman pointed out, it's not clear how much it will matter to the driver where the warning was generated, only that it was generated in time to get him or her out of potential trouble. And getting drivers out of trouble is what, at its foundation, this whole thing is about.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.
