pageElements.text:
Photography by Ronald Ahrens.
This article originally appeared on the website of Automobile Magazine.

Even without the plangent wailing of V-8 engines on the Las Vegas boulevards, we would have known the Mustang Club of America was in town on Thursday, April 17, as members celebrated the 50th anniversary of their favorite car. We were able to break the code. In the casino, people wearing the matching garb of a regional chapter referred to R-code Mustangs. In the souvenir shop, it was different clothing but a similar conversation on K-code models.

Odd trivia was another thing: A bearded, pony-tailed, pot-bellied savant discoursed on the challenge of selling unwanted six-cylinder models in 1966. Ford couldn’t produce enough V-8 engines, he said, so it pushed special trim packages for the sixes. Of course, everybody knew the fundamental fact that Ford division president Lee Iacocca officially revealed the Mustang to the public on April 17, 1964, at the New York World’s Fair. Base price was $2368.

Beyond the coded conversation and the tongue-wagging, foreign tongues reminded us that the Mustang was introduced in eleven European capitals on the same April day that Iacocca charmed the New York press. So it should have been no surprise to meet some Dutchmen, a few Swiss, a band of Aussies and Kiwis, maybe forty Swedes, and around 300 members of Mustang Club of France. We even encountered nine members of the Mustang Club of Aruba, who spoke their native Papiamento patois. Many foreign visitors rented Mustangs at various arrival points and drove to Vegas.

image.altText: Ford Mustang 50 Years Las Vegas Event

pageElements.text: Besides the car display outside the Las Vegas Motor Speedway grandstand, a few dozen participants lapped the 2.5-mile LVMS road course on the first day of the four-day gathering. People also cruised the Las Vegas Strip or ventured out of town to see weird rock formations at Valley of Fire State Park.

The MCA threw a simultaneous party at Charlotte Motor Speedway in North Carolina, and a larger contingent of Arubans went there. But we heard it rained. True or not, the ultimate suitability of Las Vegas is demonstrated by the fact that a production like Zombie Burlesque, showing nightly at the V Theater, is practically impossible to find anywhere in the Carolinas.
While everybody had the Mustang in common, what was demonstrated in the LVMS parking lot was how many variations and mutations exist.

image.altText: Ford Mustang 50 Years Las Vegas Event

pageElements.text: While everybody had the Mustang in common, what was demonstrated in the LVMS parking lot was how many variations and mutations exist. Because of the Mustang’s mass production—more than 1,000,000 sold in the first 24 months—they exist in quantity. We couldn’t count all the 2+2s, coupes, convertibles, Bosses, Mach 1s, Mustang IIs, Roushs, Saleens, and Shelby Snakes being shown. Here you will note three truly vintage examples in the first row, ahead of a rental fleet flying Swiss and French flags.

Incredible differences among Mustangs, indeed. The Mustang started out as an expression of modest personal luxury and sporty but unintimidating performance. Chevrolet’s general manager Bunkie Knudsen raved after driving it on April 20, 1964. “Things that are outstanding on the car are the cost in the instrument panel, the cost of the steering wheel and the glove box door which is a die casting,” Knudsen confided to his diary. The sewn pleats in the seat cushions were another surprise-and-delight feature. “The trim in the car would be considered out of the question for even our highest-priced Impala.” The ’68 coupe pictured here still has the lithe body, but with twin 750-cfm four-barrels, a supercharger, and nitrous, it’s a street machine in need of some fat Hoosier tires at the rear.

Thanks to Knudsen, who became Ford Motor Company president in 1968, the Mustang got pumped up and began to swagger. He used the formula he had successfully implemented at Pontiac and Chevy: find a big engine and make the car’s stance bolder. Iacocca, who thought he should have been named Ford president after leading the Mustang’s development, hated what was going on. “As soon as Knudsen arrived at Ford, he began adding weight to the Mustang and making it bigger,” Iacocca wrote in his autobiography. Knudsen was fired after nineteen months, and the jibe against him floated out of Ford and into the press. “Henry Ford said history is bunk,” it went. “But, today, Bunkie is history.”

image.altText: Ford Mustang 50 Years Las Vegas Event

pageElements.text: The Mustang is so many cars. A police car, for example. Around 15,000 examples of the Mustang Special Service Package were made from 1982 to 1993.

image.altText: Ford Mustang 50 Years Las Vegas Event

pageElements.text: The Mustang is a Playboy car. Donna Michelle, the 1964 Playmate of the Year, received a pink Mustang convertible, along with a pink Honda motorcycle, pink luggage, and a suite of other gifts from the magazine. Ford couldn’t exactly be associated with Playboy in a special-edition car, but pink was an off-the-books optional color. Bob Post spent $30,000 to restore this ’64 1/2 coupe after the fashion.

image.altText: Ford Mustang 50 Years Las Vegas Event

pageElements.text: The Mustang is also a pace car, having led the Indianapolis 500 field for the fateful 1964 race. It reprised the role in 1979 and again in 1994. Assessing the car pictured above, a burly fellow took a long time to step away for this clear shot, but in listening, we heard him determine this example is a replica.

image.altText: Ford Mustang 50 Years Las Vegas Event

pageElements.text: The Mustang is a racing car. With Las Vegas in the background, J. Bittle of San Diego drives the Hinchcliff Ross Mustang, a ’68 GT coupe with the 302-cubic-inch V-8 and famed tunnel-port heads. The car raced eight times in the Trans-Am series through 1970 and also saw some NASCAR Grand American action. Bittle has owned it since 1998. “I restored it to its original, patinated warhorse condition,” he said. Goodyear Blue Streak bias-ply tires add to the authenticity.

image.altText: Ford Mustang 50 Years Las Vegas Event

pageElements.text: The Mustang was also a laughingstock. Iacocca, who replaced Knudsen, finally had his heyday with the Mustang II. But Peter Bulcock vigorously defended the Mustang II as a car of its time. He was wiping away 1200 miles of road grime, accumulated on the trip from Chilliwack, B.C. His 1978 Cobra II, purchased in the fall of 1977, has accumulated 205,000 miles. Modifications and updates include a Boss 347-cubic-inch stroker engine and Tremec TKO five-speed transmission. “I bought it brand-new, had fun with the car, and built it this way for me,” Bulcock said. We went away feeling a little envious, because he gets to drive it home.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: If you've shopped for a car lately, you might have been faced with the decision of whether to look at a front-wheel-drive, rear-wheel-drive, four-wheel-drive, or all-wheel-drive vehicle. These monikers describe how the power from the engine is delivered to the wheels and thus helps determine how the car will handle in various conditions. Sure, you know pretty much what the difference is, but here's a quick guide to what each type of drive system really describes and how each affects a vehicle’s character in the way it handles on the road.

Rear-Wheel Drive (RWD)

Power goes to the rear wheels only. As a vehicle accelerates, the weight naturally transfers to the back of the car. This equation of weight on top of the rotating wheels gives a rear-wheel-drive car a sensation of power and possibly speedier takeoff. For the enthusiast driver, a car feels livelier when the front wheels do the steering and the rear wheels deliver the power. RWD is a durable and reliable system that dates back to the days of the Model T, yet it also adds weight to the vehicle and can take up some room in the passenger cabin. These days, RWD is the choice of heavy-duty utility vehicles like trucks and full-size SUVs, or it’s used in performance-oriented cars, like the Porsche Boxster S shown here.

Examples of the type: Aston Martin Vanquish, BMW 3 Series, Cadillac CTS, Chevrolet Corvette, Dodge Charger, Ferrari F12 Berlinetta, Ford Mustang (pictured), Jaguar F-Type, Lexus LS, Maserati Ghibli, Mazda MX-5 Miata, Mercedes-Benz SL-Class, Ram 1500, Tesla Model S, Toyota Tundra

Why you'd want it: If you're driving for the love of driving, some of the world's great performance cars are RWD. If you're asking your utility vehicle to pull a boat or haul heavy loads on a regular basis, you'll want the power to come from back there, too.

Why you wouldn't want it: If you live in a cold climate where the roads are bad in the winter, most people find RWD cars to be the least pleasant to maneuver in snow.

Front-Wheel Drive (FWD)

In a car with FWD, the engine drives the front wheels. The weight of the engine is directly over the rotating tires, and this creates useful traction in all kinds of slippery conditions.. FWD has proliferated over the past four decades and is common in passenger cars. Since the front wheels do all the steering and deliver the power, a FWD car feels intuitive to drive. The compact drive unit under the hood also makes possible a more spacious passenger cabin, while lighter weight can improve fuel economy and also make a car feel livelier, like the Volkswagen GTI pictured here.

Examples of the type: Acura RLX, Chevrolet Impala (pictured), Chrysler Town & Country, Fiat 500, Ford Focus, Honda Accord, Hyundai Elantra, Kia Cadenza, Lexus ES, Mazda 6, Mini Cooper, Nissan Cube, Scion xD, Toyota Prius, Volkswagen Golf/GTI

Why you'd want it: If you are seeking everyday performance with reassuringly stable handling and good all-weather traction, front-wheel drive should be your choice. If you are seeking better fuel economy, same. From limousine size to fuel-efficient runabout, there is a FWD car for just about everybody's needs.

Why you wouldn't want it: If you are looking for high-performance handling, a front-wheel-drive car delivers the goods up to a point just like the Volkswagen GTI, but there’s a reason why ultra-powerful cars feature rear-wheel drive.

Four-Wheel Drive (4WD)

Four-wheel drive has become the term that describes old-school 4x4 technology in which the driver must manually activate the 4WD to deliver equal amounts of power to the front and rear tires for improved traction while navigating difficult terrain in slippery conditions, whether this is dirt, mud, sand, or snow. Historically, four-wheel drive had been reserved for off-road vehicles like Jeeps and trucks. These heavy-duty vehicles typically weigh far more than road vehicles in order to withstand the stress, so fuel economy suffers even if mobility is improved. At the same time, modern 4WD vehicles are easier to use thanks to electronics that engage the 4WD system whenever wheel slip is detected.

Examples of the type: Chevrolet Tahoe, Ford Expedition, Jeep Wrangler, Toyota FJ Cruiser (pictured)

Why you'd want it: A 4WD system proves useful in a truck or a heavy-duty SUV when towing is a requirement, or as a measure to improve mobility in dirt, mud, sand, or snow. If you want to go adventuring in truly rugged conditions, 4WD is the time-honored strategy to get the all-terrain traction that you need. Most 4WD vehicles also tend to have a good amount of ground clearance to enhance mobility, so if you live in a place where the winter roads are rough going because of deep snow, 4WD might be your best shot at getting where you need to go.

Why you wouldn't want it: If you don't feel comfortable with the idea of having to make the decision when to activate 4WD, this system might not be for you. 4WD can also increase steering effort somewhat. And if fuel economy is your top priority, the added weight and friction of a 4WD vehicle don’t make it a fuel-sipping star.

All-Wheel Drive (AWD)

The mechanics of these systems vary from manufacturer to manufacturer, but their common characteristic is that all four wheels are driven more or less simultaneously all the time. The result is improved traction and reliable handling in all kinds of weather situations. Modern electronics can vary the proportion of driving force front to rear to enhance traction or simply improve fuel economy. The electronics can also vary the power delivery between the left- and right-side wheels to improve handling. Electronics can also decide when to engage based on the detection of wheel slip by a single tire. These days, AWD has become available as an option in mid- and full-size luxury cars to enhance all-weather mobility in places where the winters are hard. AWD systems are not as heavy as they once were; nor do they represent lots of momentum-sapping friction. Even so, there is usually a slight compromise in fuel economy that comes with AWD. In general, such systems are found in vehicles meant for the street, not the trail, and this goes for SUVs as well as passenger cars.
Examples of the type: Audi A8, BMW X1, Cadillac SRX, Ford Flex, GMC Terrain, Infiniti Q70, Porsche Cayenne, Subaru Outback (pictured), Toyota RAV4, Volkswagen Touareg
Why you'd want it: All-wheel drive gives you reassuring versatility for all kinds of road conditions in all kinds of weather.

Why you wouldn't want it: Don't opt for AWD while thinking you will become invincible on slippery road surfaces, unless you want to be one of those people who end up in a ditch every February. AWD improves traction while starting from a stop and while braking, but it won’t suspend the laws of physics through deep puddles or in the snow. For serious mobility and reliable handling on slippery roads, you need to get a set of good winter tires.

pageElements.text: I love white cars. Don't you? But I don't love the way you have to wash them every Saturday, or they look all dusty and polluted.

I love my dark-blue car, too. But I inevitably curse the people who drive past my car on my street and splash mud onto the side. It, too, only looks lovely for about an hour after it goes through the car wash.
So I am as excited as you surely are to see what Nissan in Europe is up to. This.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/UwoGsCAKsxU" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Can it be true? Nissan's Swiss technology center is experimenting with this water- and oil-resistant paint known as Ultra-Ever Dry. As the video shows, it seems to let dirt and mud roll right off the shiny surface of the car. The product is made by a company called UltraTech International, so this is (apparently) no April Fool's Joke.

The company describes the product as "super-hydrophobic" and says it adheres to any surface, creating an air barrier. It's so interesting that the National Geographic TV channel is using it in a challenge video. UltraTech points out that it's not available to the general consumer and that it is not to be applied to windshields.
Nissan says the coating "has responded well" to rain, spray, frost, sleet, and standing water. That about sums it up; I'm sold. Nissan says it's considering the aftermarket possibilities. Please do!

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Key Points

• The WRX STI is Subaru’s performance flagship model–aimed at boy (and girl) racers.

•  The redesigned 2015 Subaru WRX  drops the Impreza name and, at the base level, reflects no price increase over the 2014 model. The car we're testing here is a midlevel WRX STI Launch Edition, which has no options and slots in under the psychologically important $40,000 mark.

•  The 2015 Subaru WRX STI Limited is the top-of-the-line model. It starts at $39,290, including  destination, a $650 price increase over the 2014 model. 
 
•   Subaru will build just 1,000 units of the Launch Edition model for 2015.
•  The special model comes in traditional WR (World Rally) Blue Pearl exterior paint with gold-painted eighteen-inch BBS alloy wheels, a color combination associated with Subaru competition cars.

•  The Subaru WRX STI is surprisingly loaded with features, including a leather-wrapped steering wheel, performance front seats, and a six-speaker audio system. The Launch Edition adds keyless access. Option packages (not on the car we tested) include a $2,000 navigation and audio system with nine speakers.

•  Subaru is expanding the reach of the WRX STI. At the 2014 New York International Auto Show, it rolled out this 2015 WRX STI sedan in Rallycross Supercar trim, a special livery done in partnership with the RedBull Global Rallycross Championship.

•  At the same time, Mitsubishi is getting ready to pull the plug on the Lancer Evolution, the brand’s all-wheel-drive performance sedan (pictured). The Japanese automaker hasn’t confirmed when it will stop building the Lancer Evo, but it won’t introduce a successor to the current generation. This eliminates Mitsu’s last sporty offering in the U.S. market as it shifts its lineup toward utility vehicles and EVs.

pageElements.text: Mini USA is known for its emphasis on style and customization, bragging there are "over 10 million ways to configure" a Mini Cooper. The BMW subsidiary has taken that to a new level with a contest that let fans design their own look for a Mini Cooper, and the winner is a Mini you can actually buy.

It was all in service of the new 2014 Mini Cooper's launch at the New York Auto Show earlier this month. From more than 800 submissions, nine winners and a “fan favorite” were selected by online voting to have their test drives captured on video. Each of the top ten vote getters had the opportunity to sit with an illustrator and create their own design and options packages. (See the test drive video here.)

image.altText: Mini Cooper DeLux at New York Auto Show

pageElements.text: When it came to the final draw, the Mini community voted Alex Coyle’s “DeLux” as their favorite. Coyle, a nineteen-year-old sophomore studying creative advertising and photography at Virginia Commonwealth University, created her “Mini Originals” package inspired by black lights. The result is a stunning black Mini with blue exterior graphics.

“‘Lux’ is the root meaning of ‘light,’ ” explains Coyle. "After I went through all the options I had available to customize the car, I went for all the bells and whistles and created what I call  ‘DeLux.' "

The DeLux package adds $8,900 to the $24,395 base price (including destination charge) of the 2014 Mini Cooper S, for a total price of $33,295. It includes the graphics kit on a Midnight Black exterior, plus eighteen-inch silver wheels, chrome exterior trim, LED foglamps and auto headlights, a spoiler, a six-speed manual Getrag transmisison, and a carbon black leatherette interior.
Want one? There will be fifty-six “DeLux” edition Mini Coopers available for order on MINIUSA.com and through MINI dealerships across the country between now and the end of the year.
The still photo gives a good idea, but for real artistry, check out this video.

pageElements.text: Have you ever considered the cost of insuring your car as a percentage of your annual income? NerdWallet has. As its name suggests, NerdWallet.com loves to crunch numbers in the service of the average consumer.

That's why the site chose the Ford F-150, the top-selling vehicle in America, as its point of reference. Its price is average ($24,735 for the base 2014 model); its average cost to insure is pretty average (a little over $1,000 per year). And the average F-150 owner pays 2.31 percent of his or her household income for the insurance policy.
But there's more. How do America’s cities rank when it comes to auto insurance costs? Check out NerdWallet's entire survey.

To figure it out, NerdWallet used four consumer types as examples: a man and a woman, each age twenty-seven and single, and another man and woman, each age forty and married.  Just as a typical consumer would do, NerdWallet averaged the two lowest rate quotes for basic insurance coverage. By calculating the cost of insurance according to a city’s median income, the index arrives at an affordability percentage.

And, surprisingly, California has the other states beat when it comes to affordability. Six of the ten most affordable cities to own an F-150 are in the Golden State, with Fremont toping the list at 0.75%, translating to a $754.38 yearly portion of their $100,574 median income. In fact the top thirty most affordable cities all fall at a desirable 1.5 percent of median income or below. California's high median income and relatively low insurance rates are the reason, says NerdWallet.

On the opposite end of the spectrum is Detroit, the most expensive place to insure an F-150 (or any other vehicle). Detroiters would pay 17.8 percent, or $4,199.43 a year, of their median income of $23,000 to insure the F-150. That’s a situation Detroit’s new major Mike Duggan is hoping to rectify by creating a city run auto insurance called D-Insurance. (http://www.jeanknowscars.com/you-auto-know/car-maintenance/d-insurance-for-detroit/)
Another challenging city is Cleveland, eighteenth on the list with a median income of $24,257 and an annual cost of about $750, or approximately 3 percent of income, to insure the ubiquitous truck.
The F-150 Index is a helpful resource about what to expect geographically, but to compare quotes for your personal car or truck NerdWallet has a tool to evaluate several companies at once.
Of course, don’t discount the value of a good local insurance agent to help you find the best insurance fit.

metaDescription: Toyota will build a new North American headquarters in Plano, Texas, starting this fall, with nearly 4000 employees set to move within the next three years. Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
This story originally appeared on our brother website Automobile Magazine.

Toyota announced today that it will establish new headquarters in Plano, Texas, for its North American operations over the next three years, with the move to be completed by 2017. This new headquarters will unify Toyota’s current model of three separate headquarters for its North American manufacturing, sales and marketing, and corporate operations, which are located in Erlanger, Kentucky; Torrance, California; and New York City, respectively.

Just as when Nissan moved from California to Tennessee in 2006, reasoning behind this move is largely financial. Toyota is sure to pay fewer taxes in Texas compared with California. Automotive News reports Toyota chose the location in part due to "zero state income tax, lower housing costs, and a relatively strong quality-of-life index." This move also means that Toyota’s headquarters will be closer to some of its southern production facilities in San Antonio; Blue Springs, Mississippi; and Huntsville, Alabama.
Toyota will offer relocation packages for impacted employees but expects "some headcount attrition" from employees who don't want to move.

“With our major North American business affiliates and leaders together in one location for the first time, we will be better equipped to speed decision making, share best practices, and leverage the combined strength of our employees,” said Toyota North America chief Jim Lentz in a statement.

Groundbreaking for the new Toyota headquarters in Plano will take place this fall, with construction of a brand-new environmentally sustainable building estimated to take two years or more. Small groups of employees will start moving this summer to a temporary facility in Plano, with the majority of other workers to move when the building is completed in late 2016 or early 2017. The move will affect 4,000 employees total, with 2,000 of those coming from Toyota Motor Sales USA in Torrance, 1,000 coming from Toyota Motor Engineering and Manufacturing North America in Kentucky, and a smaller group coming from Toyota Motor North America in New York. The last group to move, in 2017, will be 1000 employees from Toyota Financial Services in Torrance.

To smooth the transition, Toyota will be making a $10 million philanthropic commitment to the communities in California and Kentucky, which will continue to fund nonprofits and local community organizations for a five-year period starting in 2017. Automotive News reports that Toyota will offer relocation packages for impacted employees but expects "some headcount attrition" from employees who don't want to move.

Along with the big move to Texas, Toyota will also expand the Toyota Technical Center near Ann Arbor, Michigan. Some employees from Toyota’s Kentucky operations will move to the Michigan facility to occupy a new building on the Technical Center campus, which will be accompanied by increased investment in engineering and product development at this location.

title: An American Tragedy
subTitle: Forty-three years of painstaking care. Hurricane Sandy swept it all away. A car guy begins again.
promoTeaserSmall: Forty-three years of painstaking care. Hurricane Sandy swept it all away. A car guy begins again.

pageElements.text: I've found that, to understand the men in my life, I have to understand the cars they love. From the first chrome-plated object parked in his parents’ garage to the functional minivan that protects his most cherished possessions, their cars have  given them (psychologically, anyway) metal muscle power beyond that of mortal man. Which is exactly why I have endless compassion for the men I’ve known who have loved and lost—their cars, that is.

My brother Richard’s love affair began with his first word (“car”) and steered through countless family vehicles (including a 1950 Nash that always reminded me of a cockroach) until his very first new car (a 1962 Volkswagen). Thus began a fifty-plus-year automotive dynasty that would only end with an event of historic atmospheric proportion: Hurricane Sandy.

Happily, Richard married an understanding woman who accepted each new acquisition. With every subsequent “adoption,” Richard invested his savings, his youth, and—most important—his heart. My brother’s favorite child, a 1969 Impala, got special treatment: a heated garage, custom flooring, and periodic polishing of engine parts (seen and unseen).

She’d soon be joined by a 1977 Oldsmobile Cutlass, a  1990 cherry red Corvette, a couple of late model Lexuses, and a series of runaround “everyday” cars that came and went. Eventually the garages, the driveways, and the curb in front of his home were populated by his collection. These were his chosen babies. Each one was loved in its own way and its own time; they were his legacy—that is, until two days before Halloween of 2012, when Sandy made an unwelcome visit to his garage.

“I’m glad I stayed home,” my brother said as he described the flood that overtook his home that night. “It would have killed me to have come home to that.” This, from a man who survived a major heart attack just two years ago.
Not that anything could make the loss any easier. The salt water had devastated the engines beyond repair.
Words failed me when he told me the news. His family all knew what those cars meant to him. How could he get through this?
Ironically, it was my brother’s near-departure from this world that gave him a matchless perspective on all that had transpired. “I realize that, ultimately, it’s just a car.”
even in the darkest time, a little bit of solace can come from the most unexpected source. In Richard’s case, it was the auto insurance representative.
But sometimes, even in the darkest time, a little bit of solace can come from the most unexpected source. In Richard’s case, it was the auto insurance representative.

“You know, Clare,” he said, as he described his precious Corvette squealing like a hurt child as it was being towed from the still-sodden garage, tire tracks left in the silt like desperate handprints scraped in the sand. “I think the insurance guy felt worse about my loss than I did.”
Even though it broke his heart, I could see that it helped to have someone there who truly understood.
“Will you start all over again?” I asked him, trying to find the bright side. “Just think how much fun it’ll be—you love new cars.”

He was quiet for a moment. I knew he was thinking back to that cold January morning in 1969 when the whole family schlepped out to Rice Chevrolet in Manhasset to see the car of his dreams become a reality that would inhabit his life for the next forty-three years. “It’ll never be the same,” he said.

Eight months later, I stood in his newly refurbished garage. It was empty and still smelled of fresh paint, but I definitely got the feeling that it wouldn’t stay like that for long. “Have you decided who’ll live here?” I said, knowing that he couldn’t resist forever.
He smiled at me, and I knew that he was just a showroom visit away from the Dream Reborn.

pageElements.text:
“I have a smartphone. Does my car need to be connected, too?” He was a complete stranger. But he seemed to be directing this question at me, although we were at the launch of the very connected 2014 Audi A3 and standing next to an engineer from Qualcomm, maker of modems and processors for mobile phones and cars. I guess he didn’t want an engineer’s answer, full of jargon and car features. He wanted mine, because I’d just admitted that I write about technology for a woman’s magazine.

The answer? Yes, if you plan to keep that car awhile. And, for the record, this is not a stupid question. In fact, this is pretty cutting-edge stuff involving more than the luxury of listening to Pandora while flying down Route 66.

If you have a smartphone, you’ve probably noticed that it is capable of updating its own software. That phone is always connected to the Internet, so it doesn’t need you to plug in disks or flash drives for that update. It waits for an opportunity and grabs small changes when you are looking somewhere else. It tells you about it when it’s done just to keep you informed.

A connected car can do this, too—in theory. Historically, fixing something in a car meant replacing hardware. In the world of technology though—and increasingly cars—you fix or upgrade machines by changing either their hardware or software. Hardware is expensive and involves human intervention. But software can update itself with no transaction with you—as long as the machine is connected.

Your phone can also gather information about you, what you do, and where you are and send it back to the company that built it. And that company (or companies) uses that data to improve your phone’s information or performance. (And perhaps to invade your privacy. But that’s for another discussion.)
A modern car is controlled more and more by software, not hardware. It’s a small leap to make it as smart as a smartphone and connected to the cloud all the time.

So connectedness has pretty powerful implications for cars. And I don’t mean just for mapping or restaurant recommendations. (Although certainly a car that has up-to-the-second maps and traffic information is a thing of beauty.) A modern car is controlled more and more by software, not hardware. The way it reacts to the road, including such things as how it brakes, is driven by complex algorithms. It’s a small leap to make it as smart as a smartphone and connected to the cloud all the time. And there, like your phone, is a machine that can heal itself.

“If a car is connected,” explains Paul Hedtke, senior director of business development at Qualcomm, "car manufacturers can gather an enormous amount of data in real time and see how the vehicle is performing under different road conditions. And then they can tweak algorithms and push changes out to the cars to alter the way the car functions. The owner doesn’t have to do anything.”

Your car could improve as you use it. It could get the latest features, heal itself, and improve handling if it sees that it doesn’t perform well in some terrains or environments. It could get better, or at least smarter, as it ages, without you doing anything.
Your car could improve as you use it.  It could get better, or at least smarter, as it ages, without you doing anything.

“Customers can currently update the software in Ford vehicles,” explains Julius Marchwicki, global product manager for Ford's Sync AppLink. “But they have to bring a USB stick to the dealer to do it. That is not as easy as if you have a connected vehicle that can update itself. There are a few cars on the market that can do this now. But it is something Ford is just starting to investigate.”

Yes, a car that is as seamlessly connected as a smartphone is cutting-edge stuff. But in the world of technology, cutting edge becomes commonplace very quickly, so I’d venture that cars that heal themselves will be here soon enough. And the bit of hardware that’s necessary to that connection is the modem that connects the car to the cloud. So, yes, strange man who was asking what was not a stupid question, you want a car that’s connected.

But when it comes to actual “connected” features you are likely to encounter today as you shop, most of those will be lurking in the telematics system. The last time you test drove a car, there may have been only a radio in there. Not anymore! This time you will want to spend some test-drive time parked so you can explore what goes on in that screen.

Telematics: Essential to Your Car Purchase

When you choose a car, you will be choosing an app marketplace like App Store or Google Play, just as you do when you shop for apps from your smartphone. That marketplace will determine what apps (Pandora, Waze, Glympse, etc.) you can run in the car and how seamlessly your phone will integrate with that telematics system. There are a bazillion(ish) choices, unfortunately, in this regard at this point in time, just as there were once many phone app markets. And, I’m afraid, there are more to come.

Apple launched Car Play into some cars in 2014. Google hooked up with automotive and technology companies Audi, GM, Honda, Hyundai, and Nvidia to form the Open Automotive Alliance (OAA) to bring Android into car displays in the near future.

And many carmakers offer their own marketplaces. “That marketplace tells you a lot about the philosophy of how the carmaker approaches its consumers,” says Ford’s Marchwicki. It also, if you follow technology at all, tells you that this is early and things will very likely shake out fast.
Touchscreens come in various technologies that affect responsiveness. So, when car shopping, take your fingers out of your pockets and let them do some driving.

In addition to that marketplace, you will be committing to the screen itself, often a touchscreen. Touchscreens come in various technologies that affect responsiveness. So take your fingers out of your pockets and let them do some driving. Sometimes that screen is controlled via a mechanical-feeling MMI dial on the shifting console. This elegant and somewhat retro solution doesn’t peel as much of your attention from the road because you can work the dial without looking at it. I think it’s a clever solve for telematics distraction—at least until voice control gets completely awesome. The screen size, too, will become as important to you as the one on your phone, even though you never put it in your pocket.

Also, with that car, you will be purchasing a graphics processor. If you've ever bought a gaming machine for a teenager, you’ve been here before. And, just as then, your teen will try to get you to spring for something with an Nvidia processor in it. This chip determines how crisp and realistic the images—turn-by-turn directions, apps—on the screen appear and how quickly images draw.

A smart car also has a CPU (central processing unit). And if you get geeky enough to think about that sort of thing when you buy a computer, you’ll want to think about it when test driving a car. Qualcomm makes a Snapdragon processor just for cars. Or you might encounter an “Intel Inside” sticker on the next car you drive.
Drive cars targeted at the youth market, and try a few cars at the highly connected end when you shop so you know what’s coming to in-dash displays in the near future.

But the most important part of this “connected” technology decision will be looking back at you when you flip down the visor to check out the built-in mirror: You. Are you an Apple fanboy or fangirl? An Android geek? Do you need Pandora? Are you devoted to Google Maps?

What does your digital life look like, and do you want to go on a road trip with it? Do you want the car to handle all of this or just connect to your phone? “Or maybe all you want is the remote-start feature on the key fob?” suggests Marchwicki.

Pelt that car salesman with questions. Try a few cars at the highly connected end (say the 2014 Audi A3) when you shop so you know what’s coming to in-dash displays in the next few years. Drive cars targeted at the youth market (the Spark, some Fords with SYNC AppLink) because car makers know that digital comfort is more important to that crowd than most other things in the car.

But even if you are a Luddite today, never say never when it comes to the pure pleasure of bringing your digital life with you get behind the wheel. Even if you aren’t enthralled with your smart phone today, you might be tomorrow. Today, 58 percent of people have a smartphone. A few years ago these devices were much rarer. That’s a lot of people who changed their minds. You could be next.

pageElements.text: The radiant interior perspective of the fourteenth BMW Art Car struck a persuasive note on the Paramount Pictures studio lot, where image and imagination function in a parallel universe. BMW’s display was part of the second edition of the Paris Photo Show in Los Angeles, an art fair that celebrates the still and moving image.

The car, a 1995 BMW 850CSi, designed by David Hockney, a British native who has spent much of his life in Los Angeles, explores the interior of the automobile. It’s a work that’s about exploration, exposition, and exposure, rather than power and speed. Hockney (shown here) even included imagery of dachshund in the back seat.

The display of the Hockney Art Car (pictured) set the tone for BMW’s ongoing involvement with the Paris Photo Show’s Los Angeles outpost. The fantastical California art fair also served the introduction for the first complete publication to explore the BMW Art Car Series, published by Hatje Cantz, which goes on sale in the U.S. in June.

The acclaimed product designer Carl Gustav Magnusson authored the essay about Hockney’s art car and also attended Paris Photo. “The car is the focus of the story, the content and the canvas,” he writes. “The imagery, flat and Matisse-like, narrates the emotional connection and singular bond between the driver and the vehicle.” Hockney’s work, which often explores travel, seemed like an inviting way to tackle the journey.

The book is encased in a cover designed by Jeff Koons, the most recent artist commissioned to imagine an art car, and features 200 pages that explore the evolution of art and design within the seventeen cars that make up the collection. The book includes an interview with Hervé Poulain, the French racing driver who commissioned Alexander Calder to make the first car, which he went on to drive at the 1975 edition of the 24 Hours of Le Mans.
“I wanted art—reflecting and learning about, the act of losing myself in it—and motorsport to be the purpose of my life,” Poulain says.

Along with stunning photography of the Art Cars, scholars and journalists reflect on the relationship between the automobile and the artists, who include Robert Rauschenberg, Andy Warhol, Jenny Holzer, and Roy Lichtenstein.

“What will continue to maintain the significance of this series in the future is the constantly changing perception of the interplay between design and art,” writes Thomas Girst, who heads up BMW Group Culture Engagement.

“At the time, Calder’s BMW 3.0 CSL [pictured] was the latest thing in innovative engineering technology, but almost forty years later, the sports car seems like an antiquated time traveler from the 1970s.”

To look at the Art Cars online: Go to BMW's Museum website, where you can see images and video here.

title: Uber Comes to Ann Arbor
subTitle: How uber is this app-based ride sharing startup? I tried it out, and here's what I think.
promoTeaserSmall: How uber is this app-based ride sharing startup? I tried it out, and here's what I think.
promoTeaser: How uber is this app-based ride sharing startup? I tried it out, and here's what I think.
metaTitle: Uber Comes to Ann Arbor - JeanKnowscars.com
metaDescription: Uber Comes to Ann Arbor: How uber is this app-based ride sharing startup? I tried it out, and here's what I think.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: It arrived in Ann Arbor just as the trees began to blossom, touting clean cars, clear pricing, fast service. And the best part: it was free for two weeks. How could I not try Uber, a ride-sharing startup that is already in fifty-four U.S. cities and thirty-five countries?

It took me a moment to wrap my head around the idea of ride sharing. With Uber, you don’t ride along with someone else who is going to the same museum as you. Uber’s app connects people who need rides with people who will drive you to your destination in their personal car. This is achieved through the magic of a smartphone app.

I've ridden in enough filthy taxis, worrying about paying for my ride, that it seemed like nirvana to me. But was there a catch? A little Googling revealed plenty of controversy, starting with tabloid tales of criminal drivers and even one alarming report of a little girl being killed in a traffic incident by an off-duty Uber driver.  On the legal front, many taxi and car-for-hire services are concerned about their very livelihood. Detroit even has a cease-and-desist order against Uber. All of this gives the startup plenty of publicity, but I wanted to know more.
I like the idea of being able to give a good rating to someone who shows up with a super clean car and a lower grade if I can tell the driver hasn't showered this month.

I was immediately reassured when I learned about Uber's rating system, an interesting twist for a ride service that reminded me of Yelp. Once a ride is completed, both the driver and the rider evaluate each other online, using a five-star scale. I read that if the driver falls below a 4.2, Uber drops him or her. I assume a poorly rated rider will not receive rides. I like the idea of being able to give a good rating to someone who shows up with a super clean car and a lower grade if I can tell the driver hasn't showered this month. And I am sure that the drivers like the idea of not picking up passengers who've been rated as rude.
But, before I formed a final opinion, I decided to throw caution to the wind and take advantage of being chauffeured all over town for free. Here's what I learned.

Getting Started

Step one to Uberville is downloading the app (iTunes App Store, Google Play Store, or BlackBerry World) and setting up an account with your credit card information. To me, this is the beauty of the entire service—no money is directly exchanged between the driver and the rider. You should also familiarize yourself with the various types of services available in your area. The main two options are UberX and Black, but depending on your city there are other options from high-end luxury to partnerships with taxi companies. It is important to understand the licensing of the drivers and to know which vehicle you require.

UberX

• Cheapest option
• Drivers use their own mid-size or larger four-door vehicles
• The driver must be at least twenty-three, with a standard driver’s license and personal auto insurance
• Background check on drivers
• Uber has an additional $1 million in primary coverage for when a driver is transporting a passenger

Black

• Premium option
• Black sedans and SUVs
• The driver must have a chauffeur’s license and commercial insurance
• Background check on drivers
• $1 million in liability insurance
• Cars inspected once a year to earn certification sticker that’s visible on back window to police

Understanding the Fares

The prices vary by city, but basically there is a base fare and an additional fee added for time or distance (by the minute under 11 mph or by the mile if over 11 mph). The base fare is more expensive for the Black service, and so is the price per mile. For every ride, there is a "safe ride" fee of $1. According to the Uber blog, this fee “supports the increased costs associated with our continued efforts to ensure the safest platform for Uber riders and drivers. Those include an industry-leading background check process, regular motor vehicle checks, driver safety education, current and future development of safety features in the app, and insurance.”

You may have heard of another feature, Surge Pricing, that is applied during busy times. When it is in effect, the app will clearly state that there is an upcharge, so there's no reason to worry you'll be caught by surprise.

There is an option to calculate a fare estimate, but if your driver takes a longer route you may have an increased fare. The estimate is not automatic; you as the user must initiate the estimate, preferably before you request a ride, because there is a cancellation fee.
But fees and fares aside, the big difference is there is a no tipping necessary (although my driver informed me that some customers do tip anyway).

Requesting a Ride

Finally, you are ready to request a ride. Once the app opens, it automagically knows your location. You then select the level of service and either request a fare quote or a ride. (You can also change your billing info or enter a promo code on this same screen.) Once you make your request, Uber sends a message to the closest driver.
Once a driver accepts your request, Uber sends you their photo, information about the car, and a time estimate. You can watch the car on the app as it moves toward you.

Now the real difference between Ubering (yep, as a verb) versus taking a taxi is apparent. Once a driver accepts your request, Uber sends you their photo and information about the car he or she will be driving, with an estimate of how long it will take the driver to reach you. You can watch your car on the app as it moves toward your location. This certainly beats when I call a cab in Ann Arbor and I am given the estimate of five to forty-five minutes until a possibly dirty cab will pick me up. I'm sure it also beats running around trying to physically hail a cab in a larger city.

Once the car is en route, the Uber app sends you a text message to alert you that your car is arriving. If the driver has trouble locating you, he or she can text you. Likewise, you can text them. But all texts go through Uber so that both your number and the driver’s remain private.

The Test Ride

My daughter and I used Uber to go to dinner across town. I could have easily driven. But I didn’t have to park a half block from the restaurant or circle the block several times looking for a parking spot. I could have cocktails if I wanted and demonstrate to my daughter my own responsible drinking.

When the Black car arrived, it was extremely clean, and the driver introduced himself and called me by my first name. He proceeded to tell me about his family and why he liked working for Uber. He actually came from Detroit to take advantage of this new opportunity.

As you'll recall, I was not paying for the ride; during this introduction period, Uber pays the drivers. My driver was not too familiar with Ann Arbor, so I told him the quickest route. All the Uber drivers are given an iPhone to mount on their dash for navigation. Still, I hope that once Uber is established in Ann Arbor the drivers will be from our area.
For our return trip, we chose an UberX. It also arrived promptly and was a very clean Subaru Forester. This driver was also from Detroit but not as personable as the first driver.

The Verdict

One of the best things about Ann Arbor is our great public transportation, in which I include our several taxi options. I am conflicted about the toll Uber may have on the local taxi services. Since you have to have a smartphone to use the app, it seems it will leave lower-income riders out of the mix. Also, the Uber vehicles are not regulated the way taxis are, so they do not have to have handicap-accessible vehicles, nor do they need to register their drivers with the city.

My two cents for the taxi industry: Rather than slay the beast with cease-and-desist orders and litigation, I wish they would try to understand why riders are switching to services like Uber. I personally will continue to use Uber for the cashless experience, clean cars, quick response time, and the ability to know when my car will arrive. If the taxi companies change their business model to be more like that, all the better for everyone.
To answer my own question, yes, Uber is uber for me.

title: 2014 Chevrolet Cruze Turbo-Diesel
subTitle: Is this the car that will make you want to be a diesel owner?
promoTeaserSmall: Is this the car that will make you want to be a diesel owner?
promoTeaser: Is this the car that will make you want to be a diesel owner?
metaDescription: 2014 Chevrolet Cruze Turbo-Diesel: Is this the car that will make you want to be a diesel owner? Here's what we think. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
Price: $25,710 (base price), $28,120 as tested (prices include destination charge)
Engine: 2.0-liter turbo-diesel four-cylinder, 151 horsepower, 264 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/46 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Chevrolet MyLink telematics
Option I can’t live without: Rearview camera (part of $380 Driver Convenience package)
Notable standard features on this model: Heated seats, SiriusXM radio, Chevrolet MyLink with seven-inch touchscreen and hands-free smartphone integration, rear spoiler
Notable options on this model: Power sunroof ($900), audio system with navigation ($795), Black Granite metallic paint ($225)
You might also be considering: Honda Civic HF, Volkswagen Golf TDI, Volkswagen Jetta TDI

You’ve heard the old saying, “Fifty million Frenchmen can’t be wrong.” In this case, can forty percent of European Cruze buyers be wrong? That’s how many buy the diesel version of the compact car there, and Chevrolet is hoping (but not yet finding) that Americans will do likewise. Toward that end, here’s the all-new 2014 Cruze Diesel, available in U.S. dealerships this summer.

Not many U.S. buyers are springing for the additional cost of the diesel version yet: just 1,509 were sold here in the first three months of 2014, representing 2.3 percent of total Cruze sales. When you consider that the gasoline-powered Cruze starts at $18,345 (including destination), about $7,000 under the starting price of the diesel version, that could help to explain why.

The Cruze is Chevrolet’s top seller worldwide, and it’s easy to see why when you step inside the undeniably small but reasonably well-appointed interior of the 2014 Cruze Diesel. Few would deny it is up to the challenge of competing with most modern compacts, from the Honda Civic to the Ford Focus. And it has the bonus (at least I see it as one) of being diesel powered.

You've heard people talk about "clean diesel" technology, notably at a higher price point, on Mercedes-Benz cars. Chevrolet's Cruze has it, too. Its "clean turbo-diesel" generates at least 90 percent less nitrogen oxide emissions and particulate emissions than previous-generation diesels, says GM. That, on top of the best highway fuel economy of any non-hybrid, ought to turn the heads of more than a few environmentalist types (or cheapskates).
In the consumption department, you can drive for more than 700 miles before you’ll need to refuel. Road trip, anybody?

What do you get with that turbo-diesel engine? Do you want to talk power or consumption? In the power department, you get the oomph that comes from 264 pound-feet of torque and 151 horsepower—which means the Cruze is pleasingly aggressive when you call on it for a burst of speed. In the consumption department, you can drive for more than 700 miles before you’ll need to refuel. Road trip, anybody? That 46-mpg highway number is up there in hybrid territory, but with no plugging in required and definitely no range anxiety.

How does it feel to drive? Honestly, at low speeds such as in traffic around town, it does feel, and sound, kind of, well, diesel-y. I felt a slight kinship to the buses and trucks around me in the vague sensation of rumbliness as I slowed to single-digit speeds downtown. But get to an open stretch and hit the accelerator, and you’ll find the immediate power pleasurable. Yes, I said “pleasurable” when talking about a compact Chevrolet.

What’s there to worry about when you try a diesel for the first time? Not smokiness, not inability to work in cold weather—those were the ancient problems of diesels a generation ago. There’s only a little weirdness associated with the different type of fuel. For instance, there’s urea injection, which sounds exotic but boils down to the unobtrusive existence of a small reservoir low in the trunk, where you’d expect the spare tire to be (it doesn't have one of those). The reservoir just needs refilling every 10,000 miles. Chevrolet gives you two years or 24,000 miles of free routine maintenance on the Cruze Diesel, possibly in part to conquer concerns about any extra upkeep.

Now, in terms of styling and amenities, you shouldn't expect much more than a compact car has to give. The black-and-tan interior surfaces were attractive, if plasticky. I particularly disliked the faux metal silver surfaces on the steering wheel. The driver's seat felt narrow and a little firmer than I might like, and the back seats were quite cramped. On the other hand, there was ample headroom even with the sunroof, the trunk was quite spacious, and the Cruze is upright enough to create fine visibility, which is a big concern I have with many of today's modern tiny-windowed sedans. And I am a fan of Chevrolet's easy-to-use MyLink infotainment system, which makes good use of both traditional knobs and controls and a touchscreen.

As for safety, the 2014 Cruze received five stars overall in National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) safety testing. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) named the Cruze a Top Safety Pick in 2013; under stricter test standards for 2014, and a new front overlap crash test, the Cruze didn't make that list this year, although it earned the top Good rating in the four other tests.

Chevrolet showed a face-lifted 2015 Cruze at the New York Auto Show earlier this month, and its grille and a few other details have been changed, making the Cruze look a bit more like the larger Impala. A quirk I quite liked in the 2014 Cruze I drove was the placement of door lock/unlock switches right smack in the center of the instrument panel. For 2015, they're back on the doors where you'd expect them. The 2015 model also will feature the 4G LTE wireless hotspot technology that many Chevys are getting, and for iPhone users, Siri Eyes Free.
An all-new global Cruze is coming as a 2016 model, so if you are not planning to buy a new car for a couple of years, you have that to look forward to.

The Verdict:

There's no getting around the fact that the Chevrolet Cruze is a rather unassuming car. There are many choices in the compact segment that are more interesting, more modern-looking, or just prettier. But at the same time, how many of them offer 46 mpg on the highway or a 710-mile range between fillups? How many, in short, are diesels? That's where your choices narrow to a few. The Cruze is aiming straight at Volkswagen's Jetta TDI. Diesel shoppers already know to look at VWs. The Jetta TDI's price range of $22,000 to $27,000 is slightly better than the diesel Cruze's, but its 42 mpg on the highway is 4 mpg less than the Cruze offers. Many diesel buyers will prefer the Jetta or VW's Golf TDI to this Chevrolet. But many, perhaps you, will prefer the more mainstream look and feel of the Cruze. If you are ready to try a diesel, or if you're a veteran of diesels ready to go for a new one, this is a very attractive choice that you should consider.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: Although I think the gasoline-powered Cruze is a good car at a decent price, I am not sold on the Cruze Diesel. It costs significantly more than the standard Cruze, and it would take a good chunk of time to see the savings from the increased fuel economy. I was, however, impressed that inside the cabin you could not really hear the burbling diesel engine. I found the transmission was a bit clunky when driving at low speeds but perfectly fine otherwise. I prefer the more zippy ride that the Volkswagen TDI delivers—especially matched with a manual transmission, which you can't get on the Cruze Diesel.

Five Reasons You Might Want a Diesel

title: Google, Where's My Car?
subTitle: Google Now for Android automatically remembers where you parked and flags the spot. Nice!
promoTeaserSmall: Google Now for Android automatically remembers where you parked and flags the spot. Nice!
promoTeaser: Google Now for Android automatically remembers where you parked and flags the spot. Nice!
metaDescription: Google, Where's My Car? Google Now for Android automatically remembers where you parked and flags the spot. Nice! Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Hey, Android users! All the fun is not reserved for iPhone types. As of its latest update out this week, Google Now, an Android app, can find your car for you.

If you've ever forgotten quite where you left the car—say you parked in haste to get to a concert or an urban ballpark, and you realize after the event that you hadn't been attentive enough to your surroundings—this will be a very welcome assist.

Basically, Google uses your smartphone's sensors to recognize that you were inside a moving vehicle and now you aren't. So, as Google explains, "you may see parking location cards even if you didn't park your car," for example when you get out of a taxi or someone else's car, or when you get off a bus or train. But no big deal, since what counts is that you will see the location cards when you did park your car.

Google Now will display an indicator that shows approximately where your car is parked. History of your previous parks can be found by touching Previous Locations. In answer to your next question, nobody else can see this location information but you, on your own phone, Google assures us.
Just set your main mode of transportation to driving in Google Now, and watch the magic happen.

Another Cool Thing It Can Do: Commute Communication

You can turn on a Commute Sharing feature in Google Now that will update people you choose about your progress to and from work via Google +.

Just enable location sharing, include those people, and they'll be notified when you have left work and when you get home. Oddly, I would love to know this about other people, like my kids, but I would be less excited about having them know it about me. Character flaw? But I appreciate the security aspect of it.

subTitle: A Sixties icon matures. Is it still Mini enough?

metaDescription: 2014 Mini Cooper S Hardtop: A Sixties icon matures. Is it still Mini enough?  See my short, sweet video review on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Base price: $20,745 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $38,190 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 25 city/38 highway
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 189 horsepower Transmission: Six-speed Getrag manual
Safety features: Eight airbags, including side curtain and front knee airbags, stability control, corner brake control; not yet tested by National Highway Traffic Safety Administration or Insurance Institute for Highway Safety
Tech features: Bluetooth and USB/iPod interface, HD radio, interior LED “mood lighting”
Chief competitors: Fiat 500 (base price $16,995), Hyundai Veloster (base price $18,610), Volkswagen Golf (base price $20,815); all prices include destination charges
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/KpZc-tZJF3c?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• The Mini Cooper S shown here is well equipped, but not fully loaded; it includes eight options totaling $3,200. The most expensive is a $1,000 panoramic moonroof. The least expensive option is white turn signal lights, which are priced at $100.
• Its fuel economy falls just short of the magic 40-mpg highway number that is the Holy Grail for automakers. In comparison, the 2014 Fiat 500 with a 1.4-liter four-cylinder engine and five-speed manual transmission gets 40 mpg on highway. The 2014 Volkwagen Golf with a 2.0-liter four-cylinder diesel engine and six-speed manual or automatic transmission gets 42 mpg on the highway.
• The car we tested does not have this feature, but 2014 Mini Coopers equipped with the optional six-speed automatic transmission (available on all variants) feature the Cooper’s first stop-start function to save fuel.
Mini is going for a more conventional look and feel with less of a retro-chic cabin than in the past, and is moving upscale with such items as optional LED headlights.

• Mini Driving Modes (Sport, Mid, and Green) are standard, operated using a rotary switch at the base of the gearlever. This is designed to make the car more fuel efficient, depending on what the driver dials in. In Green mode, the energy is cut to the air conditioning and exterior mirror heating.
• Mini offers lots of new optional safety features: a head-up display above the steering column, a Driving Assistant system with camera-based active cruise control, collision and pedestrian warning, speed limit information, and a rearview camera. (None are on the car we tested.)
• The range of “Original Mini Accessories” has been completely redesigned for the new model year. This is a way for buyers to put their personal stamp on the car.
• All the classics are still there, including the much-loved roof graphics. But what’s new is a design concept for the exterior and interior made up of four Mini Design Lines. This coordinates the look inside and out. (Again, not on the car we tested.) They are called Vivid Green, Speedwell Blue (the most British, with a reinterpretation of the red, white and blue of the Union Jack), John Cooper Works Pro (checkered flag in black, red, and gray), and Essential Black (with checkered pattern on diagonal).
• You now have a choice of nine roof graphics; for cars with the optional panoramic roof, there are six.
• Mini claims you can come up with “10 million” different looks for the car.

• This is the third-generation Mini.
 • Parent BMW says the emphasis is on a new “more mature character.” Is it still Mini enough?
• The new version has grown by almost five inches in length, and the trunk can now hold more luggage. However, it is still 8.5 inches shorter than a Ford Fiesta hatchback.
• Mini is continuing to adopt a more conventional look and feel with less of a retro-chic cabin than in the past, and is moving upscale with such items as optional LED headlights.
• Mini debuted in 1959 and is considered an icon of the 1960s.
• For the first time, both three-cylinder and four-cylinder engines are available, all turbocharged.
• The car we tested is a four-cylinder; with that engine, the Mini Cooper accelerates from 0 to 60 mph in 6.5 seconds. Peppy.

pageElements.text:
Ford of the Americas president Mark Fields needs to visit his mom more often. What with the daily pressures of saving Ford and all, he could use a bit more of his very down-to-earth mother's brand of support. Elinor Fields lives not far from the old family home in Paramus, New Jersey. She is the mother behind a son who has navigated his way through an economics degree at Rutgers, an MBA at Harvard, and what has been a stunning career at Ford. Fields headed Mazda in Japan at age thirty-eight, the youngest person to ever run a Japanese car company. He went on to lead the Premier Automotive Group, now dismantled, and he sits at the right hand of Alan Mulally, trying to move his Way Forward program, well, forward.

Related story:

Mark Fields Finds His Way Forward May 5, 2014

Today, though, Mark is seated at his mom's left hand, home for a rare lunch while the PR team readies the Flex press fleet for an event in New York. "He always followed his brothers. At A&S department store, Mark worked in Men's Pants, Lee was in Linens, Howard wired the Music Department," says Mrs. Fields, an elegant woman whose flawless skin and thick mane of dark hair make her look fifteen years younger than her actual age. "All three went to Rutgers. They were in the same fraternity. They had the same part-time job in college. All of them worked at IBM."

She hasn't seen her boy in a while, and she's laid out a spread that covers the dining room table. "He told me, 'Ma, I'm bringing someone for lunch, but she's diabetic, so just make tea,' " she laughs. "I said to him, 'What are you talking about?' "
There is a plate of roast beef and seven salads: tuna salad, egg salad, tomato salad, and so on. "I know," she shrugs at her three guests. "But how do I make less after all these years?"
She leans in toward him. A relative is holding a career day at school. "I told her you were very busy, but . . . " and pats his arm.
"Yes, Ma," he says.

"Mark was going to be my girl," she confides. "After two boys, this [she grabs his arm] was supposed to be my girl. But he was a hard worker. He wanted to make money when he was young. He was a caddy, and we found out he was carrying two bags at a time. We couldn't stop him."
She brings out his old tax returns. In 1977 he worked at Feeney's Sirloin Pit of Paramus and reported an adjusted gross income of $1334. The next year, he made $3014 at A&S.
"Do you know he still has his first car?"
"A 1983 Nissan 280ZX with T-tops," he interjects, getting younger the longer he sits here.

"I made him pay rent while he lived here. When he got his first apartment and went to buy furniture, I presented him with all of that rent money." She leans in toward him. So-and-so is selling her Saab, she tells him. "I told her I'd talk to you. Could you get her a deal on a Lincoln?"

"Yes, Ma," he says. She pats his arm and heads to the kitchen for desserts. That would be plural. Mrs. Fields made peanut butter cookies. "But I can't vouch for them," she apologizes. "I used Splenda instead of sugar. They don't look nice." She follows with a jam-filled angel food cake covered in whipped cream and fresh strawberries. "I even got diet raspberry jam," she tells her diabetic guest, who wants to take her home.
She pulls out a recent news clipping. "Did you see this?" She shows him a picture of himself over a fairly lengthy story. "Yes, Ma."

Ma smiles. "I kept it for you. Remember the time you upchucked? Praying to the porcelain god. I said to his dad, 'Jerry! He's sick! We've got to get him to the hospital!' Jerry said, 'Sick? He's not sick - he's drunk!' "
Mark is looking about fifteen years old now.

Mrs. Fields doesn't drive a stick, and her son doesn't buy her cars. "No, I pay. But I get the parents' deal. But I do like to test the next one first."
Has she driven the Ford Flex?
"The one that looks like a hearse?" she laughs. "But that's the look of cars now, isn't it?"
"It's too big for her," he says.
"You know, he is always working. The only time he isn't working is when he lays his head down and passes out. They have always given him something harder to do."

"I like the Zephyr. I was always happy when a car gave me good service. You know, remember when you were in California?" She talks with her hand resting on his arm. "They introduced the Mark. I like that name." Yes, this is Mark's mom. And she will have the last word.

"You know, he is always working. The only time he isn't working is when he lays his head down and passes out. He has never been able to reap the rewards of his work. They have always given him something harder to do. I worry; of course I worry. But if anything happens, it's going to happen to the whole country.

"The press has been nasty. My attitude has always been, if anyone can fix this, he can. Whatever he puts his mind to. You give them a good foundation. You repeat yourself and repeat yourself. It sinks in eventually. And then you never see them."
