pageElements.text: The ascension of Mark Fields to president and CEO of Ford should be a surprise to no one. He has been so successful, is so qualified to do this job, and has the chops to do it.

Mark Fields is the youngest son of Elinor and the late Jerry Fields. The Fields didn’t suffer fools gladly. Their sons were hardworking college graduates and achievers, Mark probably being the biggest achiever of all because he was the youngest. He followed closely in the footsteps of his older brothers. They all worked at the same clothing store in high school and he followed them to Rutgers. But he took a sharp westward turn toward Detroit after his Harvard MBA.

At Ford, he moved very quickly through the ranks. He was identified early as a mover and shaker. At a brash age of thirty-seven in 1998, he was dispatched to Japan to get Mazda back on track, and once he accomplished that, he was sent to Europe in 2002 to get the Premier Automotive Group in order.

His time in Europe was an education in the highly toxic Ford executive culture of the time, which I’ve always called The Medicis Meet the Machiavellis. You had to watch your back if you were running anything at Ford. The family was always meddling (it being their company and all), and the executive ranks were full of snakes in the grass. When Bill Ford took over, the knives-to-knives corporate culture is undoubtedly one of the things that drove him to the outside to find Alan Mulally at Boeing and bring him to Dearborn to straighten things out.

By then, Mark was back at the mother ship and in the midst of a personal PR crisis. He had been named President of the Americas and, as part of his contract, he was given travel home to his family in Miami on weekends. A local Detroit investigative reporter tracked him getting on the corporate plane and flying to Miami and did a series of exposes about how he was wasting Ford’s money. Ford’s PR didn’t handle it very well. Instead of just nipping it in the bud, it got worse and worse and put his name on the map in a bad way.
So, when Mulally (who was once described by a top exec as having "great steely balls" behind his gosh shucks sunny smile) showed up and started to clean up, nobody expected Fields to live long.

The typical executive behavior pre-Mulally was to pick away at each other and see who could out-bully whom. Word came back from an early corporate meeting that Mulally had laid down the law and told everyone how it was gonna be: all for one and one for all, and nothing but the Way Forward and the blue oval and One Ford, and he would absolutely tolerate none of the bad behavior that had been going on.

A high-level executive vice-president who was at the table told me about an important moment in the Mulally/Fields relationship. It was an early roundtable meeting with the top execs where chief financial officer Don LeClair and Fields were going at it. Mulally, with a very smiley face, said, “Hey, guys, remember how we all agreed that we could disagree without being nasty to each other, we’d all get along? Well, if you guys can’t do that” (and his voice went icy), “I’ll find two guys that can.” Shortly thereafter, Don Leclair was gone with a thank you for his years of faithful service, and Mark Fields got religion in a big way.

Mulally had set up a weekly meeting in which every person in the room was in charge of one part of the business, and all the plans and goals were on a big chart. The progress of each part of the goal was identified with green dots, yellow dots, or red dots, and during the Thursday meeting each person would stand up and give a report about all the pieces of their part of the business, and if there was a yellow or red dot, they would ask people in the room for help. For a while, it was nothing but green dots, green dots, green dots, which made Mulally crazy because he knew it wasn’t real.

Mark Fields was the first executive to bring a chart to the meeting with a red dot on it. To tell the roomful of your fiercely competitive peers that you’re having a hard time, you’re behind, and part of your project is in danger of failing—to ask for help—was an act of bravery that made a huge impression on Mulally.

From then to now, I have never seen Fields fail or put a foot wrong. I have seen his cockiness tempered, replaced by a more admirable self-confidence. He is honest, self-effacing, and even self-deprecating. He has shown a great sense of humor, even in the wake of the entire press corps making fun of his clearly mullet-style haircut.

The real turning point for me was in 2008, when he invited me to meet his mom before the New York Auto Show, where I watched him shed probably five years for every hour we were with his mother. By the time we left he was about sixteen years old.

Related story:

Mark Fields's Mom and Me May 5, 2014, from the October 2008 issue of Automobile Magazine

An interesting side note is that he is the first Jewish CEO at Ford, a company founded by a notorious anti-Semite. If there’s any question about the relevance of this milestone, look no further than the fact that there are people in the year 2014 who still refuse to consider a Ford because of the founder’s anti-Semitism 100 years ago.

The success of Mark Fields depends on all the usual factors—good product with smooth roll-outs, a strengthened presence in Europe, a reasoned and successful expansion into Asia, in addition to being able to make the Lincoln brand a success.  It also has two other important factors: whether the Ford family continues to keep the drama down (they’ve been exceptionally well behaved for the past decade) and whether he’ll able to channel Mulally’s energy and keep the egos in check. At some level, all the old conflicts are probably still simmering. Can he maintain the fragile peace among the traditional warring factions at the top of the Ford food chain? And when the doodoo hits the fan, as it always does, can he keep the Way Forward plan going forward?

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: At the New York Auto Show in April, as I settled in to the driver’s seat of the 2014 Buick LaCrosse, Ven Lai, the vehicle's color and trim designer, joined me on the passenger's side for an in-car Q&A. The new Buick was outfitted with stunning sangria-colored leather, authentic tamo ash wood from Asia, touches of jet black, and a black suede-like headliner.  It's called the Ultra Luxury Interior package, and it adds $2,495 to the price of Luxury or Touring versions of the LaCrosse.
Lai explained that she had wanted to curate a new environment: one that goes beyond the beige and brown color palette that Buick has recently been using.
I’m always glad to see car companies stretch beyond the ordinary black, brown,  and taupe.
Lai agreed. “This color is not meant to be mainstream,” she said, pointing out the smooth wine-colored leather seats with caramel-hued stitching on the sides.
The designer conceded, “It’s not for everyone’s taste, but, it’s something different than what’s on the market at the moment.”
I was interested to discover how Lai and her team got their inspiration.

“We feel textures all day long and look for individual components that are strong together yet balance out,” she noted. “We wanted a lot of movement in our wood: one that would hold its own next to the boldness of the interior design.” In fact, Buick stained the normally light-colored tamo ash dark brown to synchronize with the red/blue values of the sangria-colored leather.
Lai also pointed out that dozens of leather swatches were dyed to achieve just the right shade of sangria.

For me, a picture is worth a thousand words, so I asked Lai to show me images of the various items and themes that inspired and informed her team. She enthusiastically pulled out her iPad and showed me dozens of interesting shots. In fact, I created a Pinterest board inspired by the ideas of this innovative designer.

Following are some of Lai’s style and design influences from our interview:
• Home construction and the softness of the green elements outside. "Our customers love warmth, so we think about bringing native elements indoors," she said.
• Beautiful, simple silhouettes—like lamps or sculptures that are graphic but great on detail.
• Festive accents. "Our customers love food. We look at the simple forms of fruit, or how food is presented." Examples: a tea bag folded in the shape of a hummingbird, or a sprig of rosemary used as a skewer.
• Communal eating and bringing the harvest to the table. "We look at contrast, texture, flavors, simple, elegant and well thought out design." Example: edible flowers in ice cubes.
• Craftsmanship and working with artisans.
• A pared-down and neutral look. Soft neutrals paired with high-polish gloss.
• We examine jet black in all its idioms: classic, sporty, and modern."
• "We like clean moods and environments that have a good bandwidth." Example: titanium: a silver-white metal that is light and strong.
• "Dogs are always on our boards. We love our canine pals."

pageElements.text: The first Mother's Day gift I ever recall giving my mom was a poem I wrote myself, at age six. It was pretty bad, but she didn't think so. In fact, she held on to that crayon composition for the rest of her life. Nowadays, with four kids of my own, I know a little something about how simple, heartfelt gifts are the ones moms like best.

But this has got to beat all. University of Louisville's star quarterback, Teddy Bridgewater, who's in the NFL draft this week, just got his mom the 2015 Cadillac Escalade you see here. Did his mom, Rose Murphy, like it? What do you think? Watch the video, directed by Spike Lee, and meet this charming mother-and-son pair.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/gTe5RnL0bmw" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Bridgewater had promised his mom a pink Cadillac when he made it to the NFL. He was in third grade at the time, but she knew it could happen.

According to Mom, Bridgewater had promised her a pink Cadillac when he made it to the NFL. He was in third grade at the time, but she knew it could happen. The National Football League's scouting report on the QB explains why: "Makes few mental errors. Consistently moves the chains and comes through in the clutch. Meticulous in his preparation. Smart, determined and focused. Highly respected, unselfish team leader."
And, perhaps the most prescient of all: "Rises to the occasion on big stages."

image.altText: a pink cadillac escalade for mom

pageElements.text: Yes, this son rose to the occasion, all right. Cadillac called in its color and trim design manager, Erin Crossley, and Escalade ad manager Sean Thornton to help Bridgewater choose just the right shade of pink. Then, knowing a good PR opportunity when it saw one, the GM division helped Bridgewater present the Escalade to his mom at Le Cirque in New York City, followed by an appearance on Good Morning America.

The 2015 Escalade has a 6.2-liter V-8 that puts out 420 horsepower and 460 pound-feet of torque. Its starting price (including destination charge) is $72,690.

So, happy Mother's Day to all you moms out there. We moms know that Rose Murphy would have treasured any token of her boy's affection, but you've got to admit this will look more awesome on the streets of Miami, where she lives, than any old bouquet of flowers would.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: Whether or not you've ever even been in Michigan, you probably have heard about one of Henry Ford's most famous acts, the creation of the museum that bears his name and the accompanying collection of historic buildings known as Greenfield Village. Both are located near Ford's world headquarters in Dearborn, Michigan, and both are more than worthy of a visit. I took my fifth-grade daughter, Rory, and her friend, Maddy, on a day trip to the Henry Ford Museum, known in combination with the village these days as part of the collective entity called The Henry Ford.

The Henry Ford has an astounding collection of mechanized accomplishments from the world of transportation and beyond, with enough variety to engage and delight every member of the family. Wear your walking shoes, because it takes some serious square footage to house decades' worth of planes, trains, automobiles, and more. Here are some of our favorite attractions.

image.altText: a day at the henry ford

pageElements.text:
1. Model T Adventures

Every day, visitors can help build a Model T from the ground up. The car you'll work on is a retired actual Model T from the fleet that drives around Greenfield Village. Wander by this exhibit and, depending on what stage of the process they are in, staff members will direct you as to which part goes on next and then show you how to install it. All ages are welcome to participate in this ongoing, free activity. Rory and Maddy lent a hand installing bolts to secure the engine block. Visit here early, because the car is often finished by the afternoon, when you’ll want to hop in for a photo. At the end of the day, the staff takes the completed Model T apart so the whole exercise can start again the next morning.

image.altText: a day at the henry ford

pageElements.text: Next we tried the toy Model T assembly line. Each person handles a station such as body, front wheels, rear wheels, or cabin. The conveyor belt rolls, and everyone has to do his or her part to make sure a completed toy car results at the end of the line. It gets wildly hectic in the fashion of Lucy and Ethel at the candy factory, so by the end we appreciated the tough job of an assembly-line worker as well as the brilliance of Henry Ford’s mass-production model.

Want to investigate the power plant that made those early assembly lines possible? The actual electric generator from Ford's original Highland Park assembly plant is nearby. It’s so enormous that, when standing next to it, we were literally in the shadow of automotive history.

2. History, from the American Revolution to Rosa Parks

Treasures from the United States' most tumultuous times are presented on a gripping walk through history, beginning with relics from the American Revolution. We marveled at the compact size of George Washington’s camp bed. It was sobering to see the chair where Abraham Lincoln was assassinated and the barbaric iron shackles that had been fitted to the necks of slaves who had attempted escape.

image.altText: a day at the henry ford

pageElements.text: The girls saw how female protesters were jailed for promoting women’s suffrage, even force-fed during a hunger strike, so that, 100 years later, Rory and Maddy’s voting rights are guaranteed. The highlight of the Civil Rights section was the impeccably restored Montgomery, Alabama, city bus on which Rosa Parks refused to give up her seat in December 1955. The docent encouraged the girls to try out the famous bench, four rows back from the front step, but thanks to Parks's bravery, anyone can sit anywhere they choose on this bus.

image.altText: Wright Replica at Henry Ford Museum

pageElements.text:
3. Heroes of the Sky

A huge silver-and-blue Douglas Aircraft DC-3 swoops over the entrance to this awe-inspiring exhibit. The aviation history lesson begins with a wonderfully executed Wright Flyer replica, complete with lively statues of Orville and Wilbur.

We could almost feel the bone-chilling temperatures as we approached the 1926 Fokker Trimotor. Remarkably, there was no heat in the plane that transported legendary explorer Richard Byrd and crew to the Antarctic on an expedition funded by Henry's son, Edsel Ford.

image.altText: a day at the henry ford

pageElements.text: A wing-walker simulation thrilled Rory and Maddy, but I got a woozy as the "plane” dipped and pitched over the countryside. There’s an aviation milestone around every corner at the Henry Ford Museum, but don’t miss an early version of the modern “news chopper.” The 1931 Pitcairn Autogiro, half helicopter and half plane, was used to take photos for the Detroit News.

image.altText: a day at the henry ford

pageElements.text:
4. Housing in the Round

You say you’ve never heard of Dymaxion House? The Henry Ford Museum has the only surviving prototype of inventor and designer R. Buckminister Fuller’s ultramodern round aluminum home. Built in 1945, it was designed to be mass-produceable and easily transportable to fulfill the high demand for post-World War II housing while also utilizing materials and manufacturing practices from the war effort. His dream never got off the ground, but we were all fascinated to go inside the prototype. The girls especially enjoyed operating the rotating in-wall storage shelves, a futuristic feature you might expect in George Jetson’s house.

image.altText: a day at the henry ford

pageElements.text:
5. Presidential Limousines

History hit home in a big way when we came across the presidential vehicles. We learned that presidential limos today are destroyed for security reasons. Ronald Reagan's is the last to be preserved, and it's one of five on display at the Henry Ford Museum. Teddy Roosevelt’s horse-drawn brougham was tiny but humbly dignified, unlike his distant cousin Franklin’s sprawling and elegant Lincoln “Sunshine Special.” We all took a long pause at John F. Kennedy’s Lincoln Continental limousine, the same one he was riding in when he was shot, and noticed it was fitted with a hard top, a feature added after the assassination. How different things would have been if the bulletproof greenhouse had been attached before that fateful day in Dallas.
My fifth-grade companions were impressed by the 1930 Bugatti Royale Type 41 convertible, worthy of Cruella De Vil, and the 1959 Volkswagen Westfalia camper.

6. And, Of Course, Cars

The heart of the Henry Ford Museum experience, of course, is the collection of cars you'll find on display. The full span of automotive history is shown here, including both the iconic vehicles and the culture they spawned.

My fifth-grade companions were impressed by the 1930 Bugatti Royale Type 41 convertible, worthy of Cruella De Vil, and the 1959 Volkswagen Westfalia camper. They played games on interactive touchscreens, each taking an auto personality test with interesting results. (Rory was a Studebaker, unique yet practical. Maddy was a 1959 Thunderbird, adventurous and style-conscious.) The examples of automotive ingenuity are too numerous to mention, but you’ll encounter historic racing cars, see a 1948 Tucker 48 sedan here or a military Jeep there, and can even grab a snack in a vintage roadside diner.

image.altText: a day at the henry ford

pageElements.text: Which we did. Inside Lamy’s Diner, built by the Worcester (Massachusetts) Lunch Car Company in 1946, the girls hopped on two of the sixteen built-in stools along the counter and giggled as the staff served them doughnuts and Faygo root beer. Too bad the prices aren’t the same as the ones on the original 1940s menu: one breakfast of ham and eggs with coffee would have cost us a mere sixty cents. For a modern meal, stop by the Michigan Café, a cafeteria with a wide selection of food and drink as well as kids' meals served in paper replicas of classic cars.

Every inch of this uniquely American museum illuminates the things, large and small, that make up our history. Next time you are in southeastern Michigan, take a day to explore the wonders assembled at The Henry Ford. I’ve been going there since I was Rory’s age, and the experience keeps getting better and better.

What to Know about a Visit to The Henry Ford

Open: Every day except Thanksgiving and Christmas, 9:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.
Location: Oakwood Boulevard, Dearborn, Michigan, about ten miles southwest of downtown Detroit; map here
Cost: $18 for adults, $16 for seniors, $13.50 for kids aged five to twelve; many deals are available if you combine the museum visit with other Henry Ford attractions
Other things to see: Greenfield Village, adjacent to the museum; the Ford Rouge Plant factory tour, accessible by shuttle buses from the museum grounds; Michigan's largest IMAX movie screen, just outside the museum entrance
Need to know more? See the website for The Henry Ford

title: Mercedes B-Class Electric Drive
subTitle: It's a Mercedes-Benz first, an electric car second. Could it be the one to get you into an EV?

pageElements.text: The 2014 Mercedes-Benz B-Class Electric Drive goes on sale in the U.S. this summer, starting with California and nine other states, then rolling out to the rest of the country starting in 2015. It’s priced starting at an interesting $42,375 (including destination).

The arrival of the 2014 Mercedes-Benz B-Class Electric Drive is a reminder of how quickly the pace of technology moves. The first Toyota Prius dates back only to 1997—newborn babies driven home from the hospital in one are still in high school today—and now, a mere seventeen years later, you can buy a practical electric family car from Mercedes-Benz.

More than a million Mercedes-Benz B-Class cars have been sold around the world since it first came out in 2005, but the Electric Drive version has much to recommend it beyond the proven crossover-style body in which it rides: five-passenger seating capacity, a 0-to-60-mph time of 7.9 seconds and top speed of 100 mph, an eighty-five-mile range between charges, and, perhaps most enticing, a Tesla electric drive system inside.

Michael Jordan of Automobile Magazine tested the B-Class Electric Drive in California this week and found, despite its suburbanite looks, it prompted him “to produce a little antisocial behavior from what is meant to be a refined but innocuous people mover.” (Read his review here.)

With a price starting nearly $30,000 below that of the Tesla Model S (pictured), the 2014 Mercedes-Benz B-Class Electric Drive should draw interest based on its Tesla-sourced electric drive system alone. It also features a number of Mercedes’ vaunted safety technology items, including Collision Prevention Assist with adaptive Brake Assist, Attention Assist, and Parktronic advanced parking assistance. A 5.8-inch display screen is standard; a seven-inch display screen with Mercedes’ Comand infotainment system, and blind-spot and lane keeping assistance, are all optional.

Mercedes also set up the B-Class Electric Drive as a “digitally networked” vehicle, meaning you can check and configure its settings remotely using a computer or smartphone. For example, you can see how much charge you have in the lithium-ion battery, or plan out stops for recharging on the navigation system. Or, to be less environmental about it, you can set up heating or cooling so the B-Class is at your preferred temperature before you even climb in.

Add to this the fact that the rear seats fold and there's a back hatch, and the B-Class Electric Drive starts to look about as useful as a standard crossover.

Charge time is encouraging; with a 240-volt charger, you can get sixty miles’ worth of charge in two hours and a full eighty-five-mile charge in three. From a standard U.S. 120-volt electrical socket, charging time will be an overnight process.

How does it compare with BMW’s i3 (pictured), also just rolled out in the U.S.? The BMW, which seats four, is intended as more of an urban runabout, but other specs, including its price ($42,275, including destination), its range of seventy to 110 miles, and its 93-mph top speed,  put it in the same ballpark as the Mercedes. The i3 is available in a Range Extender version with a two-cylinder gasoline engine for an added $3,850, which effectively doubles driving range up to 211 miles.

In the realm of all-electric cars, prospective buyers have been stuck at the mini- or subcompact-car level with cars like Mitsubishi's i-MiEV or the Smart Fortwo or the more reasonably sized Nissan Leaf (pictured); or those fortunate to have the $70,000-plus to spend have sprung for the Tesla Model S. Now we're starting to see fully electric cars  you'd want to drive anyway, with the creature comforts and enjoyable attributes you would expect in any car. And they're practically affordable. That 1987 baby might aspire to own one of these in a few years, if her college loans let her.

title: 2014 Honda Civic EX-L Navi
subTitle: Do its safety features make it a must-buy? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: Do its safety features make it a must-buy? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: Do its safety features make it a must-buy? Here's what we think.
metaDescription: 2014 Honda Civic EX-L Navi: Do its safety features make it a must-buy? Here's what we think. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Price: $25,030 (base price), $25,030 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 143 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic (CVT)
Fuel economy: 30 mpg city/39 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: LaneWatch
Option I can’t live without: Remote start ($399)
Notable standard features on this model: HondaLink Next Generation infotainment system, LaneWatch, Bluetooth hands-free link, SiriusXM satellite radio, USB audio interface
Notable options on this model: None
You might also be considering: Ford Focus, Mazda 3, Toyota Corolla, Volkswagen Jetta

I drove the 2014 Honda Civic EX-L Navi on a short road trip to a dance competition for my seventeen-year-old daughter. We stuffed it to the brim with three humans and their luggage, one canine and her house, and an incredible amount of dance gear. Pay attention, Dance Moms; this car may save you enough money to buy a few more sequined costumes.

I have always considered the Honda Civic sedan as strictly a commuter car or an excellent second car, not my first choice for a road trip. But with gas prices nipping at $4 a gallon in a good portion of the country and the Civic’s impressive combined 33 mpg, perhaps it is time to reframe my thinking.

There are several trim levels of Honda Civic, starting with the base LX, priced starting at $19,180 (including destination). The EX-L Navi is the top Civic model. It comes loaded with so many standard features that the only options available are interior and exterior accessories to pimp out your ride and a remote starter for $399. For a certain demographic, being able to add underbody molding may be a bonus. For me, I would skip the flash and go with the remote start.
Are you looking for a family car that offers both safety and great fuel economy, but at a reasonable price? At $25,030, the Civic EX-L Navi is definitely a contender.

As the EX-L Navi name indicates, navigation, along with a rearview camera, is standard and includes voice recognition and continuously updated traffic. The seven-inch display is a touchscreen that you can swipe, tap, and pinch to navigate. It worked well from the driver’s seat but was glitchy when used from the passenger's seat. I often rely on my passenger to manage the infotainment, so I consider that a significant ding.

Also standard is LaneWatch, a side-view camera that displays what's on the right side of your car in the center touchscreen. The image is automatically displayed when you use your right turn signal, or it can be activated manually via a button to the left of the steering wheel. It is a little odd at first, but I love the feature when zipping around bike-infested downtown streets, and it also helped with parallel parking.

As long as we are on the subject of safety, the Civic has excellent marks from both the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS). The 2014 model has earned the hard-to-get Top Safety Pick + from IIHS. It was given the top Good rating in small overlap front, moderate overlap front, side, roof strength, and head restraint and seat tests. NHTSA bestowed five stars overall on the Civic, with four stars for frontal crash and rollover and five in side crash testing.

Honda completely redesigned the Civic in 2012and made some significant tweaks for 2013, but the automaker still found room to make more adjustments for 2014. One of the big changes for 2014 is the addition of the continuously variable transmission (CVT). If you desire a manual, you need to stick with the base LX. The CVT is responsible for upping fuel economy figures to 30 mpg city/39 mpg highway. Also new is the keyless passive entry key fob and push-button start. When I get in a car without pushbutton start these days, it seems like it is old school now.

The EX-L Navi also comes standard with HondaLink Next Generation, a suite of four apps that integrates your smartphone and your car:
• AppLauncher organizes Honda-approved third-party apps and integrates them into your vehicle.

• Connect App displays the owner's manual, local weather and points of interest, destinations, and messaging, and will receive messages directly from Honda about your maintenance. You can actually schedule a service visit using this app.

• Aha App provides a selection of constantly evolving audio content—from featured new stations, podcasts, and audiobooks to Internet radio, Facebook, and Twitter. It also includes nearby locations like restaurants, hotels, and gas stations. In my opinion, Facebook and Twitter may be a step too far in the car.
• Navigation App displays turn-by-turn directions, traffic updates, and searches for points of interest or specific addresses. This one has a monthly fee.

This seamless integration is the direction that all manufacturers are leaning, and I for one appreciate the user-friendly interface that allows me to interact with my phone and car effortlessly. It is easier (and safer) to use the steering-wheel-mounted controls than to interact with the touchscreen while driving.

The Civic EX-L's 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine does not deliver a sporty driving experience, but the CVT does a great job of handling both acceleration and deceleration without a noticeable lag or clunky noise. That is, until you really need power fast, and then it is slow to respond. The ride is smooth. I found the cabin loud when driving on the highway, but it is quieter than previous generations.

My daughter felt the rear seat was hard and slightly uncomfortable, but once she found the center fold-down armrest she was much happier. The rear seat also folds down so that you can load longer items in the trunk, but the pass-through is smaller than some of its competitors. The trunk ate up our cargo, but the 12.5 cubic feet is not the best in class. If you are looking for a larger trunk you may want to look at the Volkswagen Jetta, which offers 15.5 cubic feet in the truck with nearly identical passenger volume to the Civic. If you need even more space, you may need to move over to the hatchback category.

Speaking of the cabin, the front seats are leather and were very comfortable with an eight-way power driver’s seat and the added luxury of heated front seats. The interior is a black-and-gray color combination with brushed metallic details and has some useful open compartments to hold the debris of traveling. The materials had a utilitarian feel and appeared to be built to withstand heavy use. That's a good trait in a vehicle that has a reputation of passing the 100,000-mile mark and possibly the 200,000 as well.

The split dash display is a little off-putting at first, but once I adjusted the steering wheel I really liked the positioning of the information. When my husband drove, he used the upper dash area to store things—which not only caused obstruction of vital information, but annoyance as the items slid around. But this is a marital issue rather than a criticism of the car.

The Verdict:

The Civic is the bestselling compact sedan in the United States and the sixth bestselling vehicle overall. Honda’s willingness to keep tweaking it to match their customers' demands proves that it intends to hold on to this lofty position. Are you looking for a family car that offers both safety and great fuel economy, but at a reasonable price? At $25,030, the Civic EX-L Navi is definitely a contender. It is good as a commuter, a city car, or a cross-country tourer—but the back seat is best left to smaller travelers or additional cargo space for longer hauls. It is a great car for young drivers, too, thanks to its safety features like LaneWatch, and the connectivity will appeal to that audience as well. In fact, it is worth a test drive just to experience LaneWatch and decide if you think this is a technology worth making a purchase decision on.

The folding rear seat makes it easy to load oversize items, while retaining the ability to secure valuable items in the truck. There are plenty of compact-car contenders, and a savvy buyer needs to consider many of them, particularly the Ford Focus and the Toyota Corolla. This segment is full of great cars at entry-level prices, so it comes down to making the time to test drive a handful and finding out which is right for you.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura Sky Brown: Can I just say that I love the rearview and LaneWatch cameras on this and other Hondas? The rearview camera gives you a choice of wide, normal, or over-the-bumper settings. I'm a big fan of the all-encompassing wide angle. As for Lane Watch, when you arrive at an intersection and put on your right turn signal, it comes on automatically to show you a back view from a camera in the passenger's-side mirror. (You can also activate it by pushing the end of the turn signal stalk, or deactivate it using the touchscreen's menu.) It is brilliant, and you have to see its dynamic and incredibly helpful images to believe them. Worth the price of the car.

As for the car itself, the Civic long ago ceased to be the tiny fuel sipper that belonged in every cheapskate's driveway and has become a thoroughly mainstream compact car. I like it a lot, but it doesn't stand out from the crowd enough that I would dream of it at night.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The Miata and I go all the way back to the late Eighties, when I was invited by Mazda chairman Kenichi Yamamoto to have the very first journalist test drive of a pre-production prototype at the Miyoshi Proving Ground. This was not a press trip. We had bonded in the early Eighties over our love of baseball: me the Detroit Tigers, him the Hiroshima Carp, for which Mazda was the major sponsor. In fact, in 1984, the year the Tigers won the World Series, the Carp won the Japan Series. I just happened to be in Hiroshima that night, and all the clubs and bars were giving away free sake. There were a lot of salarymen in three-piece suits lying drunk in the gutters of Hiroshima that night.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/U8Vpd4Leia4?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
But I digress.

Mr. Yamamoto wanted to know what I thought of this new roadster from Mazda, a completely new kind of car for them. It was outstanding. It was unbelievable. The simplest way to describe it was a Lotus Elan that didn't break and had a high-tech suspension. It was absolutely perfect in concept for the time, and I didn't want to get out of it; I drove around and around, I drove engineers around, and when I was done driving, I was taken into a room at the track, and all the engineers for the various components filed in and began to ask me questions about it. Eventually I had to beg them to stop. "There's nothing left in my brain," I said.
When the first cars came to the States, I wrote the story for Automobile Magazine. It was so fantastic that it inspired us to name it our first Automobile of the Year.

It was such a fantastic car, it inspired us to name it our first Automobile of the Year, despite the fact that Motor Trend's Car of the Year was such a strong franchise that we had resisted doing this for the first four years of the magazine.

image.altText: Jean Jennings in Mazda MX 5 Miata

pageElements.text: In 2004, my husband gave me a very special Mazdaspeed Miata for my birthday. If it hadn't been this turbocharged Miata, I would have called him a crazy man for buying the editor of a car magazine a car, but the Miata is so magic, of all the hundreds upon hundreds of cars I have driven, that's one car I wanted to own.

So here it is the twenty-fifth anniversary of that very special car, and we are on the verge of seeing the first brand-new Miata from the ground up since that car came into existence in 1989. Mazda threw a little champagne celebration at the New York Auto Show, gathering there the three original 1989 Chicago Auto Show cars: the red, white, and blue cars you see here and in this video, and every special one-off Miata model they could get their hands on. It was a perfect chance to talk to the "fathers" of the Miata: the brilliant Bob Hall, who had the original idea and convinced Mazda to build it, and its first designer, Tom Matano, who came from BMW to the Miata project at Mazda and sketched the first car. Mazda's current head of design, Derek Jenkins, was also there and had a few things to say about what it was like to be the guy in charge of redesigning the icon.

title: World's Longest Line of Toy Cars
promoTitle: World's Longest Line of Toy Cars
promoTeaserSmall: A U.K. museum creates 1.2-mile line of cars in pursuit of Guinness World Record fame.
promoTeaser: A U.K. museum creates 1.2-mile line of cars in pursuit of Guinness World Record fame.
keywords: world's longest line of toy cars
metaTitle: World's Longest Line Of Toy Cars - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The National Motor Museum in the U.K. goes for new Guinness World Record for the longest line of toy cars. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
It was clear from an early age that I had an affinity for cars. As a child I would spend hours arranging toy cars in elaborate races on the living room floor, and once spent time on a vacation in France reading the owner's manual to my parents' Ford Mondeo. The first auto show I attended was in Birmingham; after moving to Michigan I began attending the Detroit auto show almost every year. I couldn't wait to take driver's ed., get my driver's license at age 16, and tirelessly polish my slightly rusty first car.

By the time I entered the University of Michigan, I had decided I wanted to pursue journalism and began writing for the student paper. But I also had an internship at Car and Driver, and quickly realized that cars were the only thing I was truly interested in reporting on. After all, countless teachers and professors had passed on the wisdom that you should, "Write what you know." I pursued that interest after graduation and managed to land a job at Automobile Magazine, just down the street from where I'd studied for the prior four years.

Fast forward to today, and I've been fortunate enough to attend auto shows on three different continents. I've learned to drive sports cars like a Fiat 500 Abarth on a race track, and spent a week eking mileage out of a Nissan Leaf electric car.

Although I love driving new cars, one of my favorite parts of this job is having the opportunity to meet the people responsible for those cars. Whether it's the executives speaking at launches or engineers revealing tech secrets at auto shows, I love being able to get a feel for how things work behind the scenes.

The most surprising part about this job is that I've become the de facto go-to for friends or family members who have questions or want advice about cars. Surprisingly enough, not everybody I talk to wants to buy a two-seat sports car.

pageElements.text:
This article originally appeared on the website of Automobile Magazine.

We spent many hours creating races and traffic jams with toy cars, but never did our exploits reach the lengths achieved by the U.K.'s National Motor Museum. This week, volunteers spent ten hours arranging 24,189 toy cars in a 1.2-mile line, long enough to garner a new Guinness World Record.
Sir Stirling Moss gave the museum a model of a Mercedes-Benz 300SLR that matches the one in which he won the 1955 Mille Miglia.

The record for the longest line of toy cars was previously set in Germany, at 14,310 cars. To ensure they'd have enough miniature motors to set a new record, staff at The National Motor Museum put out a call for donations in early February. Locals donated thousands of toy cars at special drop-off bins installed at nearby supermarkets, while several celebrities also pitched in. Pink Floyd's Nick Mason, as well as British T.V. celebrities Question Willson, Vicki Butler-Henderson, and Edd China, all signed cars for the record attempt. Sir Stirling Moss gave the museum a model of a Mercedes-Benz 300SLR that matches the one in which he won the 1955 Mille Miglia race. Making matters tougher, the record attempt consisted only of cars; toy tanks, trains, caravans, and boats were specifically disallowed.

Although Guinness World Records hasn't yet fully examined and confirmed the new record, museum staff say they're confident they've beaten the existing German record. Now that the record attempt is over, the museum plans to sell the 24,189 toy cars on May 17, with proceeds benefiting a nearby children's hospice house.

images.caption: The Guinness people are expected to honor The National Motor Museum with a world record.
That is a lot of toy cars: 24,189, to be exact.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

title: 17 Car Things Not to Do
subTitle: A survey reveals how many people admit to these embarrassing (sometimes dangerous) mistakes. You?
promoTeaserSmall: A survey reveals how many people admit to these embarrassing (sometimes dangerous) mistakes. You?
promoTeaser: A survey reveals how many people admit to these embarrassing (sometimes dangerous) mistakes. You?
metaTitle: 17 Car Things Not to Do - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 17 Car Things Not to Do: A survey reveals how many people admit to these embarrassing (sometimes dangerous) mistakes. You? Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
Have you ever done something embarrassing with your car? Before you answer that question, think of all the things other people do that seem ridiculous...until they happen to you. The website Insurance.com surveyed 2,000 people in April on which of seventeen screw-ups they have had happen, and it made me think: Have I really done all seventeen of these?
Jean: I will admit to committing "only" ten of these sins.
(Averages are shown in the images below.)

1. The most frequent issue for both men and women was forgetting where they'd parked the car, with 44 percent of men and 59 percent of women admitting to it. (The Android users among them ought to check out this app, just released, that will keep track for them.)

Jean: My biggest problem is forgetting which car I'm driving. The old Union 76 gas station used to give away orange Styrofoam antenna balls for a reason.
Here's the breakdown for the other items on the list:
2. Driving over a curb: 51 percent of women and 35 percent of men.

3. Locking the keys in the car: 41 percent of women and 34 percent of men.
Jean: I've done that so many times in the past that I became really handy with a coat hanger back in the day. The most egregious example was dragging all my little brothers to the beach and, in the course of getting them and all their gear out of the car, I not only locked my keys in the car, the engine was still running. Just as beach security got the door open, the car ran out of gas.

4. Driving down a one-way street in the wrong direction: 38 percent of women and 30 percent of men.
Jean: I was pulled over three times in France on one day: once for running a yellow light, the second time for speeding (in which the national police blocked the autoroute to pull me over), then later that afternoon in Toulon, in the south of France, in a driving rainstorm. I made a right turn only to face four lanes of traffic coming right at me. I made a quick U-turn, but not quick enough to avoid the police. Not one of those stops resulted in a ticket.
5. Driving off with something sitting on the top of the car (coffee, a purse?): 34 percent of women and 28 percent of men.

6. Mistakenly attempting to open the door of a car that isn't actually yours: 34 percent of women and 24 percent of men.
Jean: See item 1.
7. Giving up on backing out of a parking spot because other cars or obstacles are too close: 33 percent of women, 21 percent of men.
8. Dropping money or food at the drive-through: 28 percent of women and 23 percent of men.

9. Accidentally triggering the car alarm, then unable to get it shut off quickly: 26 percent of women, 18 percent of men.
Jean: I mistakenly set off a car alarm on a Ford pickup truck while demonstrating the force of an air bag explosion on Good Morning, America.I immediately leapt through the passenger window to try to get the key, an action caught in gory detail by the cameraman. The resulting clip appeared on the hilarious outtake show Talk Soup that week, shown in forward and reverse, so it looked like an early version of an animated GIF. They showed it three times.
10. Losing a toll ticket at the payment booth: 17 percent of women, 18 percent of men.
11. Unable to get out of a traffic circle roundabout and kept going around...and around: 13 percent of women and 12 percent of men (hey, people, see our instructional video on this one).
12. Failing to have license, registration, and/or insurance card when pulled over: A tie! 11 percent of both men and women.

13. Driving away from the gas pump without taking the nozzle out of your tank: 7 percent of women, 14 percent of men.
Jean: The most famous case was a newly hired motor gopher at Automobile Magazine who did this and tore the nozzle right out of the pump. Needless to say, his first day was his last day.
14. Unable to get your key remote to work to open your car door: 8 percent of women, 10 percent of men.
15. Almost hit someone with your car: 9 percent of women, 8 percent of men.

16. Forgetting a passenger and having to go back to get him or her: 6 percent of women, 11 percent of men.
Jean: I didn't own the car and wasn't driving, but I had convinced a cabdriver friend to take my roommate, me, and my golden retriever Odin home to visit our parents. Driving back to Ann Arbor through Detroit on the Interstate, he heard a squeak in his wheel and pulled off into a closed grocery store parking lot at 2 a.m. He proceeded to jack his car up on the sidewalk under the lights, take the wheel off, and repack the wheel bearing while we stood outside in the freezing cold and waited. When he was finally done, we jumped in the car and took off. We realized fifteen minutes later that we'd forgotten the dog. We hustled back and there he was, sitting patiently in front of the grocery store, waiting for us. The horror.

17. Getting into a car and then realizing it wasn't your car: 8 percent of women, 7 percent of men.
Jean: This hasn't happened to me with a car, but it has happened two different times in hotel rooms, both times in Europe, where the tradition is to leave your key at the front desk when you go out. The first time, the guy was in the shower and all his shoes were lined up beside the door so I backed out. The second time, the guy was actually asleep in the bed so I turned around and ran. I now carry a card with my room number written on it.
You might notice that women admitted to more of these than men did, averaging 4.2 mistakes to men's 3.5, while five percent of all respondents admitted they were guilty of ten or more mistakes.

These are all embarrassing and annoying, but at least they are (mostly) harmless. However, Insurance.com notes that 40 percent of those responding said at least one of their gaffes ended up causing damage to the car.

It's refreshing to know that the most feared item on this list is number 15, almost hitting someone, feared most by nearly a quarter of those surveyed. Let's hope that the other three-quarters are confident enough in their driving skills to know this is unlikely to happen to them!
Are you guilty of some (or all) of these mistakes? Or even better ones? Tell us your stories!

title: Auto & Design Turns 35
subTitle: It's the finest car design publication ever to exist, and it's run by women. Here's the back story.
promoTeaserSmall: It's the finest car design publication ever to exist, and it's run by women. Here's the back story.
promoTeaser: It's the finest car design publication ever to exist, and it's run by women. Here's the back story.
metaDescription: Auto & Design: It's the finest car design publication ever to exist, and it's run by women. Here's the back story. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com

contributors.bio:
Robert Cumberford is a designer who became a writer by accident. His race report on the 12 Hours of Sebring was published when he was an eighteen-year-old Art Center student in 1954. Subsequently he has published thousands of articles on cars and airplanes, in American, Asian, English, European, and South American magazines. He contributed to several books, including the entire text of the well-reviewed Auto Legends, now available in five translated editions -- French, German, Spanish, Italian, and Polish in addition to the original English version. In 1985, Automobile Magazine founder David E. Davis, Jr., invited him to be one of two executive editors when Automobile was in the planning stages. Cumberford demurred, saying he knew nothing about magazine production and claims he still doesn’t, except that it’s important to meet deadlines. He contributed features from the beginning and began his popular “By Design” column in the sixth issue, September 1986.

In car design, Cumberford was even more a youthful prodigy. He sketched the body for the first car ever built to his designs when he was a fifteen-year-old Los Angeles high-school student. That car, the Parkinson Jaguar Special, is still active in historic racing sixty years after it was created. Hired directly by General Motors’ legendary Vice President of Design, Harley J. Earl, Cumberford became a professional car designer at nineteen. Leaving Detroit, he returned to California to attend UCLA to study philosophy. He rejoined the automotive world in the early 1960s and has continued to create new automotive shapes since then, always as an independent design consultant. He has lived and worked in six of the fifty United States and in France, Mexico, and Switzerland. The range of his design projects includes both racing and touring cars, trucks, aircraft, boats, hovercraft, and even ecological architecture.

He is known worldwide for strong opinions but is well-respected in the design world because it is known that he is always completely honest in his views, with no agenda other than respect for good design and good designers. “There’s no ad hominem,” he says, “I judge the design, not the designers. There are designers I really like personally who’ve been credited with designs I heartily dislike -- for reasons I always state very clearly -- and designs I love done by people with whom I have absolutely no affinity. Except that we both like their work.”

pageElements.text:
“We can regret, lament, celebrate the past, but there is no foreseeable future for Italian car design.” I wrote that here last month, and by so doing brought down the wrath of a great many interested parties who desperately want to believe all is for the best in this best of all possible worlds.

But, as much as I’d like for them to be correct in their rose-colored views, they aren’t. The proof of that is pretty simple, as can be seen in the exodus of Fiat, the greatest Italian enterprise since the Roman Empire fell, from Italy to England, Holland, and Michigan… anything to get out of its home nation. That the move was financed by our own government’s jobs-saving gift of Chrysler to the Agnelli family just underlines the general hopelessness of Italy today. It will get better, of course, because Italians are great innovators and have been central to much of the world’s progress in art, science, and business, but it won’t happen soon.

But there is a globally focused automotive activity in Italy that should be celebrated today: the creation thirty-five years ago of the finest publication dedicated to car design ever to exist, Auto & Design. Fulvio Cinti, now in his nineties, who retired at the end of last year as editor and administrator of the publication he had imagined, conceived, and guided for decades, was for a long time the sports editor of La Stampa, one of Italy’s most important daily newspapers, based in Turin, as was Fiat in its glory years. Sports writing in Italy includes motorsport, not just stick-and-ball activities as in U.S. newspapers, so Cinti knew the protagonists in the automotive world, and he knew about cars and racing.

He also knew design and beauty and was on intimate terms with all the leading designers during the unforgettable period of 1945 to 1975, when Italian design absolutely led the world. He was on a first-name basis with Gianni Agnelli, Gianni Lancia, ‘Pinin’ Farina, ‘Nuccio’ Bertone, Giorgietto Giugiaro, Marcello Gandini, and hundreds of others throughout the world and could call on their support.

Cinti's first design publication, Style Auto, launched soon after his retirement from La Stampa, was really good. I found a sole copy in Manhattan long ago and cherish it to this day, but the problems of production and distribution and interfering collaborators put an end to it not long after it began.

But Cinti bided his time, and at the end of the Seventies, he was supported in launching Auto & Design by a group of friends, all movers and shakers in the upper levels of Italian industry and society. It was and is a sumptuous publication, thanks to its brilliant initial art director, the late Eros Sogno, with gorgeous layouts, generous white space, big pictures, and enormous amounts of inside information on the creation of key production and concept cars.

It was Jean Jennings who put me in touch with Cinti sometime in the Eighties. She had encountered him, I presume, at an auto show in Europe, and agreed to work with Auto & Design, but when Automobile Magazine began and I joined my old friend—and Jean’s mentor—David E. Davis, Jr., in the new adventure, she thought I might be a better fit for Cinti’s magazine.

And so it turned out. Cinti and I communicate in less-than-classical French (on both sides), and we have found endless points of convergence and agreement, and some surprising connections. For instance, when the Lancia sports car racing team came to America sixty years ago for the 1954 Sebring 12 Hours race, the first time serious European racing drivers had visited our country since the Gordon Bennett races in the late Thirties, Cinti and I were both there.

No, we didn’t meet. Cinti was then a man in full, handsome and dynamic, with important work at a major newspaper. I was a teenage student who’d dropped out of design school for lack of money, and I was only present in Florida because I and a couple of fellow students desperately wanted to see the cars. That one of my pals had a Volkswagen we could drive nonstop across the U.S., and that I lived in a converted garage in the back yard of the struggling owner of a small car magazine, Road & Track, who wanted coverage and was willing to print my handwritten story of the race—my first-ever publication—meant that we could be in the same place at the same time, but not meet as equals.

I will never forget the first time I met Fulvio Cinti. It was at the Turin Auto Show in 1988. He was affable and charming, but I was wary of him. Why? Because he was completely surrounded by a bevy of the most astonishingly beautiful young women. I say that now, but in fact they were really girls, one of them—certainly the most striking—no more than a teenager. She was statuesque, with long coal-black hair hanging well below her waist. In fact, it was cut off exactly at hem height of her (very) miniskirt. My reaction, based on previous experience in Italy, was that this Cinti was what we usually call “a dirty old man.” An extremely false impression based on irrelevant data, as it turned out.

Cinti’s admirable legacy, quite apart from the magnificence of Auto & Design itself, is to have broken completely with the cult of machismo all too rife in Italian business. Today, all employees of the magazine he founded are female, every one of them highly capable, most of them long serving. Maria Teresa Fausto (at left in the photo below), the supposed “top model” I’d met in the Eighties, is still at Auto & Design twenty-six years later, responsible for handling subscriptions, back issues, and online activities. Cinti’s successor as Amministratore Unico (C.E.O.), Laura Carpaneto, is new in the post, but she is an architect whose connection with the magazine goes back to the beginning. Her father, whose shares she inherited, was one of the founding investors. Giusi Consolaro, head of the administrative office, has been with the magazine since 1980, and I can attest to her competence.

Elisabetta Massola, editorial assistant responsible for web and social media, joined the staff in 1985, and Silvia Baruffaldi (at right in this photo), now only the second-ever Direttore Responsabile (Editor in Chief), joined Cinti’s team two years later; her career was carefully developed with more and more responsibility added as her experience grew. Paola Sorbara, whose activities include schools and books, is a twenty-first-century addition, signing on in 2002. Marta Cinti, Fulvio’s actual granddaughter, has been contributing since 1999 and has been a full-time reporter and graphic designer for four years.

It’s not surprising when the whole staff of a fashion magazine is female, but for a field of interest as typically male-dominated as automobiles, this is a radical transformation, brought about by a man who overcame a strong cultural tradition of ignoring women’s abilities.

As with other automotive publications, the subject matter—automobiles and design, as the title states so clearly—has traditionally been covered by men. Fulvio Cinti gathered the best automotive writers he could find from all over the world. Wim Oude Weernick of Holland has been with the magazine for more than thirty years, and the great L.J.K. Setright from England was on the team until his death. Alberto Mallo of Spain, Serge Bellu in France, Luca Ciferri, Roberto Piatti, and many other Italians, all well known and highly respected in their own countries, have made valued contributions and will continue to do so, always because of Fulvio Cinti’s strong commitment to car design as a serious subject.
But a great part of his legacy will always remain his atypical willingness to acknowledge the abilities and value of intelligent women.
Ave, Fulvio!

title: Car Seats That Keep Babies Cool
subTitle: Thank NASA for fabric that keeps kids comfortable in car seats—and dogs chilling in their crates.
promoTitle: Car Seats That Keep Babies Cool
promoTeaserSmall: Thank NASA for fabric that keeps kids comfortable in car seats—and dogs chilling in their crates.
promoTeaser: Thank NASA for fabric that keeps kids comfortable in car seats—and dogs chilling in their crates.
metaTitle: Car Seats That Keep Babies Cool - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Car Seats That Keep Babies Cool: Thank NASA for fabric that keeps kids comfortable in car seats—and dogs chilling in their crates. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: If you have ever taken a small child out of a car seat, no matter what your climate is like, you have probably felt the sweaty back and neck of one uncomfortable passenger. It's just a fact that it can get clammy in there, being tightly strapped in to a modern child safety seat. But the Evenflo company has looked to NASA to solve this problem, and now you can buy car seats that use the space agency's Outlast technology.

How did NASA get mixed up in how comfortable your baby is? It actually developed Outlast fabric to protect astronauts from changes in temperature while they're out in space. The fabric is made using what NASA describes as phase change materials, or PCM, which means it's able to absorb excess heat and store it in microcapsules inside the fabric, then release it as needed to maintain a comfortable temperature.
This is not the same as your high-tech sweat-wicking underwear or running clothes. It's "proactive" by keeping the passenger below the sweat threshold in the first place.

image.altText: car seats that keep babies cool

pageElements.text: The odd-looking photography of heat storage in a baby's body aside, this is pretty great. As the company that developed the product, Outlast Technologies, explains it, this is not the same thing as your high-tech sweat-wicking underwear or running clothes. It's "proactive" by keeping the passenger's temperature below the sweat threshold in the first place. It's equally good at keeping your small rider from being too cool by releasing heat as needed.

image.altText: car seats that keep babies cool

pageElements.text: Snugli and its parent company, Evenflo, have pioneered the use of the Outlast fabric, in the Snugli All-in-One, shown here (estimated price $329.99, depending on retailer).

There are several choices in the more popularly priced Evenflo Platinum series (from approximately $159.99 for the Secure Kid DLX Platinum, shown here, to $249.99 for the Symphony DLX Platinum). The price ranges here are not noticeably higher than for other similar child seats.

Wondering about care instructions? Evenflo says machine washing won't affect the Outlast's performance and recommends you machine-wash the seat pad separately in cold water on delicate and tumble dry at low heat for ten to fifteen minutes.
But wait! What about the dog? Yes, Outlast fabric can be found on Snoozer Pet Products' dog crate pad ($14.95 to $129.95, depending on size) and pet beds ($109.95 to $129.95).

images.caption: NASA originally developed the Outlast material used in these cars seats.
The difference between a child using an Outlast-equipped seat and...not.

pageElements.text: The Internet is now the go-to place to help plan a road trip. But not for me; I am a fan of old-fashioned travel books. I recently found two excellent ones to help plan a road trip across the good ole U.S. of A. Best of all, you can use them in places where Wi-Fi isn’t available. And, truth be told, those are some of the best places to be.

Lonely Planet’s USA’s Best Trips: 52 Amazing Road Trips

Second edition published March 2014
List price $24.99
Available in print and e-book format from LonelyPlanet.com

image.altText: books to make you road trip ready

pageElements.text: This guide has done all of the legwork to help you experience the U.S.A.  in your jalopy or, if you are a two-wheel fan, on your motorcycle. The trips range from two days to two weeks. The Lonely Planet people  have divided the country into nine regions, which is handy for narrowing down the area of the country that you want to explore. And they also designated fifteen of their road trips as “classics,” including the Pacific Coast Highway, Route 66, Yellowstone, and Coastal New England. I of course, believe the route along Lake Michigan should be considered classic, but Great Lakes water is in my DNA.

image.altText: books to make you road trip ready

pageElements.text: The book is even more perfect for visitors from foreign lands. The front of the book has a highlights section to showcase our biggest attractions to help readers select a region. For those who need more direction, the authors have aligned routes that appeal to certain interests such as beaches, food, or history. There is also a section in the back of the book with essential information about driving on U.S. roads as well as general travel tips for visitors.
I give my highest kudos for the sidebars called Stretch Your Legs. These are one-to-three-mile routes in cities, meant to be experienced on foot.

Peppered throughout the regional sections are the individual routes and the predictable highlights, detours, tips, and recommendations. But I give my highest kudos for the sidebars called Stretch Your Legs. These are one-to-three-mile routes in cities, meant to be experienced on foot. But you have to dig for these gems because they are not called out in the table of contents.

Moon Travel Guide’s Road Trip USA

Sixth edition published May 2012
List price $29.99
Available in print and Kindle editions; for sale at bookstores and online booksellers
More information from RoadTripUSA.com

image.altText: books to make you road trip ready

pageElements.text: The Moon guide offers eleven routes that criss-cross the United States, all on two-lane roads. The routes are not assigned a time frame, but you can pick and choose chunks of a route that fit your availability. The format is a celebration of Americana, including vintage photographs and postcards. To really use this guide,  expect to devote the time to read entire sections, rather than scan for quick reads. There are plenty of sidebars of detours and trivia, but many gems are hidden within the dense text.

image.altText: books to make you road trip ready

pageElements.text: There is a small resource section called Road Trip Essentials, but it is mostly web links. I imagine this book appealing to an older traveler who is familiar with the U.S. but wants to spend a road trip reliving a simpler time.

These are both big books that may give a traveler pause if you are trying to travel light. But I guarantee that both are easy to navigate, come along in the car with you, need no recharging, and will never experience a power outage.

pageElements.text: Are you mesmerized by the Tesla Model S? Who isn't, really? Named 2013 Automobile of the Year by our brother publication Automobile Magazine, and bandied about in tech, automotive, and every other kind of website as the Greatest Thing Since Sliced Bread, the Tesla Model S might be a rare example of the thing that really is as cool as They say.

So, for the same reason people like satire about the president and jokes at the expense of the biggest movie stars, people like to read about the mighty Tesla Model S and maybe chuckle at it a little. Not to say these same people (and I include myself) wouldn't jump at the chance to drive one!
Here are five most amusing and interesting Tesla Model S tales and videos from around the Net, in no particular order.

1. The Comic

Even if you've already seen this, see it again. "What It's Like to Own a Tesla Model S." In detail. Pure brilliance and more than a little worshipfulness for the Model S.

2. The Hack

With great computing power comes great computing responsibility. Somebody figured out how to hack that giant seventeen-inch, multifunction Web browser of a touchscreen in the Model S. Apparently there's a "disguised ethernet port hidden in the dashboard," it says here. Well? It had to happen, as this story says. How does Tesla like that? Not much, according to this story. Owners? Well, they could load various third-party apps of their choice, if they knew how to do it....

3. The Tesla-tastrophe

In which a guy takes a trip in a Tesla Model S, the whole recharging thing does not go well, the car ends up on a flatbed....you had to be there. But you know what? The driver was "a little sad" to say goodbye to the car anyway.

4. The Three Little Girls in the Back Seat

If you want to see pure joy (and, one assumes, pure affluence) on three little faces, check this out.

5. The Two Very Different Ways to Dance with a Tesla Model S

There's the nice, clean factory way:



And then there's this way.
