contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: Pink is a powerful mystery. Repaint a dowdy brown Toyota Camry or a gruesome green Honda Accord in pink, the color of femininity, and you’ve created an enigma, one that’s on par with the black monolith in 2001: A Space Odyssey.
Why was this done? What could it mean? The car now has a new power that goes beyond the size of its engine or the length of its wheelbase.

Pink expresses femininity but also outrageousness. The mixture of red and white and a little blue—or yellow—also represents success. Thinking pink hard enough and long enough will lead to one of the cars that Mary Kay sales directors drive.
But sometimes, pink suggests frivolity. A pink hot rod? A pink Lamborghini Murciélago?
Let us consider automotive pink through the ages.

Pink in the Art Deco Era

DuPont introduced Duco lacquer in 1923, and the colorful, quick-drying finish soon replaced the dull varnishes that had predominated in the automobile industry. Even famously black Fords eventually began to wear interesting raiment.

Pink cars weren’t exactly a familiar sight—but then again, as the historian Jo B. Paoletti has explained in her book Pink and Blue, neither was the color pink freighted with the same gender coding we find today. Some department stores recommended pink for boys. After World War II, pink was established in a marketing sense as the color for girls.

So a pink car was merely a flamboyant statement in the 1930s. When the novelist and car collector Clive Cussler was restoring a fabulous 1936 Avions Voisin C28 Ambassade, he decided to spray it pink. Speaking with me in a phone interview, Cussler recalled: “I did some study and found out that the French, there in that Art Deco era, used to paint cars just all kinds of wild colors. I thought I’d just go back to the old days and do it kind of a loud color.”

Displayed in the Cussler Museum, in Arvada, Colorado, the Voisin’s enthusiastic squalling can be heard on the plains of Nebraska and Kansas. Cussler’s book on his collection, Built for Adventure: The Classic Automobiles of Clive Cussler and Dirk Pitt, also showcases a 1936 Ford cabriolet hot rod in approximately the same tone of pink.

Elvis Starts a Pink Thing

Pink Cadillacs started rolling through the verses and choruses of popular songs in the early 1950s. Elvis Presley toured in a custom-painted 1955 Cadillac Series 60 sedan, which remains part of the collection at Graceland. In Baby, Let’s Play House, his first national hit, he mentions the car while imploring his sweetheart to return from college and be with him. In the next few years, as Elvis was conquering the world from a little Memphis recording studio, pink spread through Detroit: it turned up on Fords, Buicks, and Chryslers, among others.

As Modernist architecture and design flourished, the color palette expanded. The Postwar era embraced tones we wouldn’t even consider in our current white-black-silver-red conformism, which gives resale value an unnaturally important position above individual expression. Of course, pink Cadillacs (and their metaphorical work on behalf of sex) went on to accumulate well more than 200,000 miles in the songs of Bruce Springsteen and Aretha Franklin.

Selling to the Ladies

In 1955, Chysler Corporation’s Dodge Division had a nutty idea. The brand’s Custom Royal sedan wasn’t doing much. But the backslapping, cigar-puffing honchos who ran the division had apparently learned that not all cars were driven by men. And maybe some of the fairer sex even conducted their own transactions! For this niche market, why not create a unique car?

So the Custom Royal Lancer La Femme was a midyear offering. “The industry’s first appeal to women,” says the Standard Catalog of American Cars. Heather Rose and Sapphire White paint distinguished the La Femme, and it had floral upholstery. The purchaser received a pink umbrella, cape, boots, and shoulder bag. (Instead of the healthy snacks and cruelty-free emollients the latter would contain today, it was filled with a compact, lipstick, cigarette case, and lighter.) For several years, Chrysler’s top-of-the-line Imperial was offered in Shell Pink and Persian Pink. The 1959 Imperial wasn’t fully loaded until the buyer added the available Elizabeth Arden travel makeup case. Product literature urged, “Slip it into the glove compartment of your Imperial against the inevitable times when ravages demand repair.”
1969 Playmate of the Year Connie Kreski merited some serious horsepower: she received the most potent of all Mustangs, the Shelby GT500—in pink.

From the Playboy Garage

MX 707908 was code for an optional Ford Mustang color known informally as Playboy Pink. The first pink Mustang was a gift from the magazine to Donna Michelle, the 1964 Playmate of the Year, who first posed for Playboy when she was seventeen. Soon, Ford dealers were capitalizing on the availability of pink for special promotions. In Portland, Oregon, Marv Tonkin Ford ordered twenty-five examples and arranged test drives with Playmate Kelly Burke. Ford historian Tony Popish has written that most Playboy Pink Mustangs were not upgraded from the stock six-cylinder engines because “they would be driven by the ladies.” But 1969 Playmate of the Year Connie Kreski merited some serious horsepower: she received the most potent of all Mustangs, the Shelby GT500—in pink. Then again, Kreski was from the downriver Detroit suburb of Wyandotte, Michigan, with the Ford Motor Company’s central operations within a short drive, so she would have known the difference between a potent V-8 and an anemic six.

Pink and Mary Kay, Inc.

You know what you’re seeing even before your eyes rove to the script. A Mary Car “career car” is a singular corporate emblem, always worthy of note and generating immediate admiration for the driver’s gumption and grit. She had to work hard to get that car!

It all started in 1968 when Mary Kay Ash, who had absorbed the pink Cadillac myth, entered a Dallas dealership and ordered a car to match her young cosmetics company’s Mountain Laurel blush. She soon rewarded her five top-selling consultants with pink Coupe de Villes. Since then, General Motors has produced about 100,000 pink Cadillacs. Lesser pink cars like Saturns and Pontiacs have been available to Mary Kay consultants, and the program is global. (One of Jo B. Paoletti’s big points is that pink isn’t uniformly interpreted across cultures.)

At the 2014 Mary Kay Leadership Conference, a surprise announcement brought more than 10,000 women to their feet: a black BMW 320i was presented as the newest addition to the beauty fleet. Indeed, the pink Cadillac was green with envy.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Price: $38,950 (including destination charge); AWD model is $40,500 (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.8-liter V-6, 311 horsepower, 293 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/29 mpg highway (AWD model: 16/25 mpg)
My favorite standard feature: Hyundai BlueLink telematics system with Siri integration
Option I can’t live without: Matte wood (only available by purchasing all three option packages, $11,000)
Notable standard features on this model: Navigation system with rearview camera, lumbar support on driver's seat, height-adjustable passenger's seat with lumbar support, HD radio, Sirius XM Travel Link, proximity sensing key, push-button start
Notable options: Panoramic sunroof (part of Signature package, $4,000); lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, smart cruise control with full stop, parking assist (part of Tech package, $3,500); head-up display and CO2 sensor (part of Ultimate package, $3,500)
You might also be considering: Acura RLX, BMW 528i, Buick LaCrosse, Cadillac CTS, Lexus GS350, Lincoln MKZ, Mercedes-Benz E350

When I say Genesis, do you think of Phil Collins? Or when I say Hyundai, do you think of cheaply built cars? If you answered yes to either question, it is time to join the modern age and meet the 2015 Hyundai Genesis. At right around $40,000 and bursting with amenities, improved handling, and sophisticated styling, this second-generation Genesis is neither old nor cheaply built. Hyundai is aiming to win over current buyers of mid-size luxury cars with this sedan. The Korean automaker is also hoping the new entry will lift the brand’s status overall. The Genesis has been refined and tweaked to help achieve these goals, but I wanted to know, is it good enough to succeed?

There are three flavors offered: a 3.8-liter V-6 with rear-wheel drive—which is the one we drove—plus a 3.8-liter V-6 with all-wheel drive and the top-end, 420-horsepower 5.0-liter V-8 with rear-wheel drive. All three are paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters. The addition of the AWD V-6 may be a game changer for sales in areas of the country that shy away from rear-wheel drive.

Part of the appeal of the new Genesis will also be the plethora of standard features, including navigation with rearview camera, hill hold control, power folding outside mirrors, a twelve-way power driver’s seat with lumbar support, a power height-adjustable passenger's seat with lumbar, HD radio, Hyundai’s BlueLink telematics system, SiriusXM Travel Link, and a proximity sensing key with push-button start. The most unusual feature: when you stand behind the locked vehicle with the key in your pocket for more than three seconds, the trunk magically opens.

Our test car, the $38,950 base 3.8-liter V-6 with rear-wheel drive, did not include any options, but I checked out other Genesis models that included three option packages. Some or all of these can make the Genesis swankier and boost its safety feature count. The Signature package has blind spot detection, a panoramic roof, and power rear sunshades with manual rear-seat side shades; it costs $4,000. The next step up is the Tech package, which includes premium leather, a driver’s seat extender, lane departure warning and lane keeping assist, smart cruise control, and parking assist; it's priced at $3,500. But to get the Tech package, you also must purchase that $4,000 Signature package. And the hits keep on coming. The Ultimate package is $3,500 and includes impressive matte finish wood, a head-up display, a power trunk, and a CO2 sensor to avoid drowsiness. But you must purchase both the Signature and Tech packages as well. Ouch, we are now at $49,950. I prefer to trick out my ride one item at a time.

There are a few gems buried in these pricey packages. The panoramic roof that is currently all the rage does add glamour, and those sun shades are nice for keeping the sun off your precious cargo. The smart cruise control with full stop is also a nice feature. The CO2 sensor is interesting, but it seems like the emperor’s new clothes to me.

But my heart goes thump-thump for the matte wood available in the ultra-expensive Signature package. Bentleys and Rollers can keep their glossy wood. I like wood that actually looks like wood, and this, my friend, actually has grain you can feel. At the very least, when you are sniffing around the Hyundai dealership, check out the matte wood.

I do have a bone to pick with Hyundai about the head-up display (HUD). It is a fabulous feature that can display speed, turn-by-turn navigation, blind spot detection, smart cruise, lane departure, traffic, and collision warning. But it does not work with polarized glasses! I wear sunglasses 365 days a year, so this function would only help me at night. As a huge fan of HUDs, to say I was disappointed is an understatement.

The Genesis can hold its own in the looks department against any luxury or near-luxury competitor. It is elegant, with an expansive hood and a graceful swooping roofline. The grille is big and bold without being gaudy. I love the way the side mirrors fold when you lock the door, as if to remind you that your car is special and deserves to be protected from a careless neighbor car. The new winged badge replaces the standard Hyundai badge on the previous generation, putting the icing on the upscale modern design.
Near-luxury buyers who are looking to move up into the luxury category will be especially pleased with the cabin design.

Helping achieve the sleeker design is a gain of nearly three inches in the wheelbase but only 0.2 inch in overall length. This allows for shorter rear and front overhangs while also increasing the passenger volume to 107.7 cubic feet. Compare that with 100 cubic feet in the Lexus ES. In fact, the rear seat of the Genesis is downright spacious. Once you are in the cabin, you will forget your preconceived notion that Hyundai builds economy cars. The standard leather actually feels premium. The steering wheel is leather wrapped and sports the winged Genesis badge, and its buttons are handsome as well. The standard wood is slightly disappointing after seeing the optional matte variety, but not a deal breaker. Near-luxury buyers who are looking to move up into the luxury category will be especially pleased with the cabin design.

BlueLink apps will deliver notifications when maintenance is due, and customers can use the system to schedule service. There is even a special app for Google Glass users. And iPhone users can use Siri through their phone for voice commands. I have a love/hate relationship with Siri, but she did help me find the phone number to Target as I kept my eyes glued to rush-hour traffic.

The Ride

The driving experience has taken a giant step forward from the previous generation, but the 2015 Genesis still doesn't quite make it to the front of the luxury pack. There are three drive modes: Sport, Eco, and Normal. Suspension enhancements have improved the ride, although over our potholed asphalt it wasn’t as smooth as some of its competitors. The steering was light, but the car cornered nicely with minimal body roll. I didn't find the cabin as quiet as a luxury car's should be.

As I mentioned, Hyundai used luxury models as its benchmark, specifically the Lexus GS and ES, the Mercedes E-Class, and the Cadillac CTS, as well as the BMW 5 Series and the Audi A6. That is great news for their more likely buyers, people in the near-luxury market who are considering competitors such as the Acura RLX, Buick LaCrosse, and Lincoln MKZ. It is also a nice step up for Hyundai's Sonata and Azera owners.

The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) gave its Top Safety Pick + award to the 2015 Genesis. IIHS specifically called out the automatic emergency braking system that is part of the technology package, which initiates braking if it senses a car approaching at an unsafe speed. The 2015 Genesis has not yet been tested by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

The Verdict:

I think Hyundai is doing an excellent job of changing American buyers' perceptions, and the Genesis will bolster that climb. Journalists are aware of the new quality that Hyundai has achieved, but you as the consumer may still be working with your first impression of the brand. So let me say this: If you're a near-luxury buyer with an open mind, the 2015 Hyundai is a slam dunk. If you are a current luxury-car owner but want (or need) to downsize a little, this car could make your fall back to earth less painful. But really, all consumers should pay attention to Hyundai and give them a fresh look.
Jean Jennings: Back to work on engine smoothness, especially upon acceleration...Disconcerting and not so luxurious.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura Sky Brown: This is one fine car to sit inside, with special mention for the extremely tasteful perforated leather seats (cushioned precisely enough) and the classy center storage bin that opens from the center, like a cereal box. It feels like a car that costs at least $10,000 more. The HyundaiLink telematics are easy to understand and use, and I love the gentle chime that sounds when you first climb into the car and the sinuous voice of the HyundaiLink woman. It's also one fine car to look at. I appreciate the sleek "Fluidic Sculpture" design very much. The driving experience was competent, although as assertive as I expected; maybe the V-8 version is more in line with what the looks of the Genesis led me to expect.

Jean Jennings: The Genesis is gorgeous inside. Yes, it has an Audi grille and a Chrysler logo, but the materials and fits and finishes inside the Genesis are unquestionably sublime and rewarding. Now. Back to work on engine smoothness, especially upon acceleration. When you press the accelerator in a smooth and linear fashion (that is, you don't just stomp on it), the engine answers with a two-step response. It hesitates, then accelerates. Disconcerting and not so luxurious.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: Tires are that expense we often balk at when it comes to making sure our car is up to snuff. For instance, many people feel that they can’t afford the price of four new tires.
The new tires go on the back because in dangerous conditions like wet weather you want to feel the car beginning to hydroplane as soon as possible, so you can correct.

When I visited the Michelin proving ground outside Greenville, South Carolina, recently to participate in the Michelin Safe Driving Experience, I had the opportunity to explore just why Michelin recommends that you always buy four new tires at a time (and get them rotated regularly to extend their life).
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/NP8wit28uHs" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Of course, they want you to buy four. But what about those times when you feel you can only afford two tires? The least you can do is install them correctly.

There is a common myth that if you only have two new tires they should go on the front. Technical marketing manager Sarah Robinson explained that the new tires go on the back because in dangerous conditions like wet weather you want to feel the car beginning to hydroplane as soon as possible, so you can make a correction. If the new tires are on the front, you don’t feel the instability in the car until it’s too late.

So it was off to a part of the 3,500-acre facility to test this theory, as you see in the video above. We would be driving Toyota Camrys around a giant circle track with sprinklers creating a deluge on the polished concrete. Engineer Michelle Phillips was my co-pilot as I took out a Camry with new tires on the rear and worn tires on the front. She had me circle the track at speed, getting the car up to about 55 mph, until I naturally felt the need to lift off. I could feel the car begin to lose grip but corrected in time to avoid a spin. The reverse was true in another Camry that had the worn tires on the back and the new tires in front. I took it around faster and faster, but when I felt the car getting loose, the back end was already coming around. It was pretty exhilarating to experience that kind of spin on a wide empty test track. In actual traffic, it would be horrifying.
Note to self: If you can only buy two new tires, they go on the back.

pageElements.text: Have you jumped on the GPS bandwagon? If you don't have an in-car navigation system yet and are relying on your smartphone, or if you haven't yet found a nav solution that you're happy with, the Scout app provides a painless way to move into and through the twenty-first century.

The free application was created by Telenav, the first company to bring GPS to phones (way back in the Nextel days) and is so easy to use that even a novice like myself found I could just pick it up and start navigating. The clear, bright orange and gray graphics, bold lettering, and well-placed features immediately trumped the interface of the map features that come with my iPhone.

Scout’s improvements recognize we are creatures of habit, as well as social animals, so the app helps you keep track of your favorite haunts with Likes or find yesterday’s locations in Recents. A super convenient feature is the ability to quickly share your ETA, taking real-time traffic into account, right from the map, so you can let your spouse know via text message what route you're taking and when to expect you for dinner. Or select an eatery from the interactive dashboard and easily send a link via text, email, Facebook, or Twitter that provides a map to that location so your friends know exactly where to meet up.

For searches, I preferred using the voice command feature as opposed to typing in my destination. Scout seems to understand my Midwestern English a lot better than Siri.  To activate it, you just say, “Hey Scout,” and then ask it to find whatever destination you are looking for. The list of matching choices that appears is very readable.  Because this is a free app, your list of search results starts with a “relevant ad,” but that’s easy to ignore.  Then you tap the car icon alongside your choice, and a map pops up with three different route choices and their associated mileage. Tap your choice, tap Go, and you are on your way.

Sooner Heath of Telenav told me that the app was designed to reduce the number of taps you need to execute a task. “Users were zooming out an average of four times and zooming in four times to get from the turn-by-turn view to the whole-route view.” So they created a shortcut that toggles between those two views in two taps.

Other time savers appear when you tap the Explore icon to find the most commonly searched for destinations like Coffee, Restaurants, Gas, or ATMs. Because Scout displays search results with not only proximity but popularity in mind, sometimes the closest option is not what you’ll see first. For instance, when I searched generally for “grocery stores,” the first thing to appear was a megastore over a mile away, while the closest store, a Whole Foods, didn’t even show up. When I asked Scout to find Whole Foods, both local locations did appear. So, if you know exactly what you want, make your search request specific.

Telenav predicts some of us will soon see an automotive-grade version of Scout, called Scout for Cars, built into our cars’ infotainment systems and able to connect seamlessly with Scout on our smartphones. Telenav technology is already present in many Ford vehicles. For the future, Telenav says, the look of Scout for Cars will likely be customized to the specifications of carmakers that adopt Scout technology. Those systems should still retain Scout’s signature simple interface and expand on personalized features to include predictive routing and search results that take your historical preferences into account.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: When she was four years old, Kaylin Stewart watched her father, Tom, set a land speed record at the Bonneville Salt Flats, in Utah, and resolved to race on the salt as well.

A few weeks from now, upon celebrating her sixteenth birthday, Kaylin will begin her quest to become the youngest driver ever to join the 200 MPH Club. Last year, just two weeks after turning sixteen, Madeline Carlson raced a roadster 147.365 mph on Bonneville’s three-mile short course, becoming the youngest to set a class record. Bill Lattin was seventeen years old in 1987 when he bettered a class record at 212.040 mph, and he remains the youngest to have joined the club.
When Bonneville Speed Week begins on August 9, she will attempt to better the existing mark of 219.509 mph in the B-Blown Modified Pickup class.
Kaylin’s project is more ambitious; just breaking the 200-mph barrier won’t be enough.

To gain membership in the "2 Club" and unseat Lattin, she must eclipse a class record above 200 mph. So when Bonneville Speed Week begins on August 9, she will attempt to better the existing mark of 219.509 mph in the B-Blown Modified Pickup class.
At the moment, Kaylin doesn’t even have a driver’s license.

Never mind that. Not only is she set to attempt the feat that has been achieved by 750 land speed racers over the decades, with just twenty-four women among them, but she is also making a documentary film about it. She has already interviewed several of the “salt sisters”—those women in the 2 Club—on camera. With co-producer Harry Pallenberg now aboard, footage of her own record attempt will be mixed with those interviews for a documentary, Chasing 200, which is planned for release in the summer of 2015.

“After I found out I couldn’t be a cat when I grew up, that’s when I decided I wanted to be a producer-director,” says the high school sophomore from Arroyo Grande, California. She plans to study film production at Chapman University in the Los Angeles area.

Kaylin, who is five feet nine inches tall, has already been fitted for her racing seat in the Jesel Land Speed Team’s 2005 Dodge Ram 1500 crew cab pickup, which holds seven class records and has achieved 262.118 mph on the salt. Under the Ram’s hood, a fearsome twin-turbocharged 385-cubic-inch V-8 produces 2,100 horsepower. This engine is matched with a five-speed manual transmission. Gears are shifted by pressing a button on the steering wheel, releasing a blast of pressurized air that stimulates electromechanical actuation within the gearbox.

Team owner Wayne Jesel, whose family business manufactures valvetrain components for high-performance engines, is an acquaintance of the Stewarts. At the Dry Lakes Racing Hall of Fame banquet in January 2013, Kaylin told him about her dream of being the youngest member of the 2 Club. She mentioned that the truck’s picture hung in her room at home.
“Well, why don’t you just drive the truck at Speed Week next year, when you turn sixteen?” she remembers Jesel saying.
“I don’t think I stopped smiling for a week,” Kaylin says. She helped out on Jesel’s team last August.

Before she can drive during Speed Week, she must obtain a regular driver’s license and then a competition license. The process starts on her birthday, July 10, when she goes to the Department of Motor Vehicles for the state’s test. After passing, she will immediately head for Bonneville, where the Utah Salt Flats Racing Association holds a “test and tune” meet from July 11 to 13. Kaylin will strap herself in a converted Chevrolet stock car, offered by a friend of Jesel’s, for a series of progressively faster runs. (Motorcycle racer Valerie Thompson will also do license qualifying in the car.) These sessions will ultimately result in Kaylin’s receiving a “B” license for 200-mph-plus racing.
She told me it’s “incredible” to have people show this much confidence in her. “It’s terrifying, but it’s incredible.”

In August, she will return to Bonneville for Speed Week. Record attempts are staged over six miles of the salt-covered ancient lake bed. The first two miles are the acceleration zone. Three timed one-mile sections follow. Then the driver releases the parachute that helps her slow over the sixth mile before turning off the course. One of the biggest challenges during the run is to keep the driven wheels from spinning when powering across the salt. It isn’t enough to surpass the established record just once. A second run must be made on the following day, and the average of the two top speeds is used for scoring.

Last Saturday, I caught up with the Stewarts at El Mirage dry lake near Victorville, California. The Southern California Timing Association, which sanctions land speed racing here and at Bonneville, was holding its season-opening meet. With Kaylin’s eleven-year-old brother, Riley, they had driven their pickup about five hours after school on Friday in order to help out Robbie Cohn with his F-Classic Gas coupe. Cohn’s car is the near twin of the 1978 Chevrolet Monza that Tom raced to 214.160 mph in 2002.

After arriving at El Mirage, Riley and Kaylin slept in back of the truck while Tom, a machinist at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant on California’s coast, climbed into a tent on a platform. Cohn’s car had already made one run when I caught up with them.

Marveling at the scene, with various characters and some of the most bizarre and beautiful cars and motorcycles on the planet, I asked if Kaylin’s fellow students at Central Coast New Technical High School have any concept of what she is doing. She fixed her blue eyes on me and gestured often with her hands when saying the boys think her racing is “cool because of the cars” but girls are more skeptical, asking why she would “want to spend a week getting dirty and sweaty.”

El Mirage is an off-highway vehicle area administered by the federal Bureau of Land Management. For $15, you can enter the lakebed and do your thing. Kaylin, who has a driver’s permit, has already driven here. In January, while helping some friends test a land-speed car, Tom coned off a course, and Kaylin, behind the wheel of their Hyundai Sonata, made a dozen or so runs over the smooth dirt at speeds between 80 and 100 mph. “It was just to get the feeling of running down the course with cones and making safety turn-outs,” Tom says.

Meanwhile, as Kaylin continues explaining about her desire to race and how she decided to make the movie, her polished deadpan wit is often in evidence. For example, she says her mother has imposed a strict rule against her going over 275 mph until she’s eighteen.
“But I can always say, ‘I didn’t know how fast I was going. There’s no speedometer!’”

Much of her poise comes from extensive acting experience. She says she has “gone on a hundred auditions and been in a million plays, and I get nervous every time I’m about to go onstage or into the audition room.” But there is also the barrel racing. “When I race a horse, before I make a run, I visualize everything I’m going to do.” http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1801553/

Tom thinks the latter experience will pay dividends on the salt. “It helps a lot,” he says. “I can see the focus and the nerves. She has to control the horse and be timely. When it’s your turn to go, you have to be the show and turn it on.” The loud music in the arena, the yelling of her coach--she doesn’t remember any of that afterward, he says.
Kaylin's polished deadpan wit is often in evidence. For example, she says her mother has imposed a strict rule against her going over 275 mph until she’s eighteen.

Later I call up Kaylin's mother, Jessica, who has stayed behind on the family’s ten-acre ranch to manage the opening of the movie’s Indiegogo fundraising campaign. (It’s off to a slow start.) She is prepared for the obvious question. “We have people tell us we’re crazy all the time,” she says. “We’re driven by that mama bear instinct. Your gut reaction is, ‘How can you let her do something like that?’”

Like Tom, she expresses confidence in the Jesel team’s attention to detail and emphasis on safety. She considers the upside. Kaylin, she says, will be better prepared for life than 90 percent of her classmates.

And even without taking the philosophical view, Jessica allows there’s a certain inevitable quality to it all, especially when considering Kaylin’s precocity. “She was talking in full sentences when she was a year old. She’s never had a fear in her life. She rode in the push truck when she was an infant. She’s talked about it since she was six. She was going to drive like Daddy.”
In August, Kaylin might drive faster than Daddy.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The first time I drove the Chevrolet Corvette Stingray was last fall at Gingerman Raceway in western Michigan, during the Automobile Magazine Automobile of the Year competition. Every staff member and many freelance contributors came to that event, and it was all I could do to get any seat time. The Corvette was obviously a track animal and very exciting to drive, but it really showed its mettle on the two-lanes all around the west side of the state. When the dust cleared, the Stingray had won the 2014 Automobile of the Year award.

Next, I went to California in February for two months to film the reality show Motor City Masters (premiering June 24 at 10 p.m. on TruTv). The day after I arrived, a Stingray appeared in my parking spot as a loan from Chevrolet to use as my daily transport the whole time. I was sorry to see it go when I came back home in the spring.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/IYyBu0fKFk0?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

As luck would have it, the white Stingray in this test arrived in our offices on April 8 to begin its stint as a Four Seasons test car, meaning it’s going to live at our offices for a year. It all comes full circle. My life is complete.

pageElements.text: Have you ever been to the Indy 500? That's OK; watching it on TV is good, even if not quite the same as being in the middle of the action. The 99th running of the legendary race happens on Sunday, May 24, on ABC. The green flag goes down at 12:00 noon Eastern time, and NASCAR stock-car racing star Jeff Gordon heads out to kick off the action in the pace car, a Chevrolet Corvette Z06. While you wait, here are ten things you may not have known, but ought to.

1. This year is the first Indy 500 in thirty-seven years without Jim Nabors (of Andy Griffith Show and Gomer Pyle fame) singing "Back Home Again in Indiana" just before the race. (You can watch his final rendition from 2014 on YouTube.) It took ten people to replace him: the a cappella group Straight No Chaser, alumni of Indiana University, will do the honors this year.

2. Nine women have competed in the Indianapolis 500. A full list of their accomplishments is on the Indianapolis Motor Speedway website. This year, Pippa Mann will compete in her fourth Indy. She's racing on behalf, not only of women, but of the Susan G. Komen anti-breast-cancer organization. Go to her Indiegogo page and pledge a donation in exchange for Pippa-related souvenirs. Also in the starting lineup: Simona de Silvestro in the #29 Dale Coyne Racing Honda, in her fifth Indianapolis 500 start.

3. There are 29 bars dedicated specifically to margaritas and bloody Marys at Indianapolis Motor Speedway. Let it not be said that Indy fans drink only that, however. They also consume 145,000 gallons of beer and 24,000 gallons of Coca-Cola products, and they put 475 gallons of ketchup on the 8,000 pounds of pork fritters and ten tons of Track Fries, among other products served during the event.

4. The first Indy 500 champion drove something known as a Marmon Wasp. The bright-yellow, wasp-tailed racer won at an average speed of 74.6 mph. The driver was Ray Harroun, and the year was 1911. The luminous yellow car made it onto a commemorative U.S. Postal Service stamp in 2011 for the centennial. (This year is only the 99th running because the action stopped during both World War I and World War II.)

5. It’s harder than you think to understand how much Indy drivers get paid. The Indianapolis Star noted this week that it’s nothing like other major-league sports. With no driver’s union, no collective bargaining agreements, and no minimum salaries—or salary caps—every driver pretty much gets a different deal from every other driver. Some of the top drivers have guaranteed salaries, while others get percentages. Three-time Indy 500 winner (and Dancing with the Stars champion) Helio Castroneves was revealed, because of a court case, to have been paid $6 million from 2000-02 by the Penske racing group, but that, apparently, is far more than most earn. The paper suggests $1.5 million a year is the top end, while many others make low to middle six figures.

6. An INDYCAR Series car could run upside down. It generates 5,000 pounds of downforce when going 220 mph. Since the cars weigh only 1,575 pounds, this amount of downforce would, in fact, allow the car to run upside down if that speed is maintained, according to the INDYCAR people. Let's see that!

image.altText: Janes Addiction Carb Day Credit Karl Zemlin
image.caption: photo: Karl Zemlin

pageElements.text: 7. There are no more Carbs, but there's still a Carburetion Day; the racing cars have been fuel injected, not carbureted, since the Sixties. Held the Friday before the race, which is May 22 this year, Carb Day is the last day of on-track practice. There are festivities, too: Jane’s Addiction is among the bands performing that night.

8. What do they do with all that unused real estate on the back stretch? Solar power, that’s what. Last July, the largest solar farm at any sporting facility in the world opened for business. It makes solar energy for Indianapolis Power and Light, stretching over 68 acres and generating enough power for up to 2,700 homes.

9. The Indy 500 might be the most tradition-laden event in racing. Among those traditions is the annual parade on the Saturday before the big day. (You can watch it on the NBC Sports network.) This year’s grand marshal is 2008 Olympic gymnastics gold medalist Nastia Liukin, for some reason. Among other unexpected Grand Marshals in the parade’s fifty-eight-year history: Shirley MacLaine (1958); Jimmy Stewart (1965); the ambassadors of Peru, Bolivia, and Ecuador (1968); Anderson Cooper (2011); and Mickey Mouse (1974, 1985, and, with Minnie, 1992).

10. The speedway is the world’s largest spectator sports venue, with 250,000 permanent seats. The Roman Colosseum, Yankee Stadium, the White House, Vatican City, the Taj Mahal, the Rose Bowl, and Churchill Downs fit inside the oval with room to spare. Room for you, perhaps.

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text:
Molly Says: No! If Your Car Isn't Going to Roll down a Hill, Don't Bother

Do you need to engage the parking brake in an automatic-transmission car on level ground? I say no, and it annoys me when other people do. I wear a helmet every time I ride a bike. I do not tailgate. I look both ways before I cross the street. But when it comes to the emergency brake in an automatic car, I throw caution to the wind and skip it on all but the steepest of inclines. In my over thirty years of driving, my car has never, ever rolled. I will admit that I have actually left a car in gear and it still did not roll. That I know was just karma from clean living.

Having spent most of my driving years sharing a fleet of vehicles with other drivers, I have been exposed to the emergency brake sycophants. In fact they get all car-slangy with their nouns—e-brake, hand brake, parking brake. Finally, I decided to get my frustration out and confront the issue head on.
In my over thirty years of driving, my car has never, ever rolled. I will admit that I have actually left a car in gear and it still did not roll.

First I explored what happens, technically speaking, when I put my car in Park. A metal pin called a transmission parking pawl stops the output shaft and drive wheels from turning. Unless that pin fails, this vehicle is going nowhere, and even if it fails it will only roll if it is on an incline. For those who say the parking brake will protect you if you forget to put the transmission in Park, I respond, What?! So the logic is that I will remember the brake, but not to put it in Park—not bloody likely. More likely I will forget both.

Laura is a big fan of the emergency brake (see below), and I often drive a vehicle immediately after her. I have started to back out of a parking spot more than a few times and thought the car was misbehaving. But then I quickly realized that it is Miss Brown that is misbehavin’. I am prepared to listen to her side of the story, but I am skeptical that thirty years of parking could be wrong.

Laura Says: Yes! I Use the Parking Brake Whenever I, You Know, Park

Molly Jean and I frequently take turns driving test cars, and I have grown used to her complaints that she has to take three seconds to release the parking brake after I've been in a car. To which I respond: Tough luck. That's three seconds of her life she is not getting back. Why? Because I am one of those people who take the parking brake's name to be its job description, and I generally engage the brake when I park any car.

Is this a stupid idea? I know, my car is almost never going to roll away if I don't. I guess it started for me because I owned a manual-transmission car for several years, and I know nearly everyone parks one of those with the car in gear and the parking brake set. If you don't, there's a chance it will slip out of gear, and then nothing is holding it in place. But an automatic?
Yes, I say, even an automatic, because the car is equipped with that brake in the intention of having you use it. I did some research to see if my instinct is correct. Here's what I found.
I know owner's manuals tell you to do a lot of things, but what's the big deal about also doing this? I ask you.

I checked the owner's manuals for a random sample of cars: the 2014 Ford Fusion, Toyota RAV4, Porsche Panamera, and Mazda MX-5 Miata. All of them instructed that the parking brake should be set whenever you park, even on automatic-transmission models. Yes, I know owner's manuals tell you to do a lot of things, but what's the big deal about also doing this? I ask you.

Does it do any good? According to Paul Seredynski, Ford's manager of global powertrain technology communications, using the parking brake regularly "keeps the components from crusting up and often maintains the cable's lubrication." He uses his! I'm glad to join him. I know I want my car's components un-crusty.

He even has a ritualized sequence, which he credits to having learned from a colleague at Land Rover: "It's all about removing transmission loading: stop, allow vehicle to settle, apply [parking] brake
firmly, allow to settle, place transmission in Park." Good enough for me.
And you? Molly and I are both very interested to see who's on our side. Let us know.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Vital Stats

Base price: $33,795 (includes destination charge)
This car's price: $36,645 (includes destination charge)
EPA fuel economy: 24 mpg city/33 mpg highway
Engine: 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 220 horsepower, 228 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed S tronic dual-clutch automatic with Audi quattro all-wheel drive
Safety features: Eight airbags, including driver and front passenger knee bags; not yet tested by National Highway Traffic Safety Administration; named a Top Safety Pick + by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. This award applies to the 2015 Audi A3 with the optional Advanced Technology package ($1,400), not on the model we tested, which includes active lane assist, Audi pre sense front crash protection, and adaptive cruise control
Tech features: Quattro all-wheel drive; Audi MMI Navigation Plus ($1,900) includes CD/DVD player, navigation system with voice control, Audi MMI Touch, and color driver information display; Cold Weather package ($500) includes heated front seats and exterior mirrors and heated windshield washer nozzles; Aluminum Style package ($450) includes aluminum interior trim and window surrounds; Audi music interface with iPod cable ($350)
Chief competitors: 2014 Acura ILX (base price $27,885), 2014 BMW 320i (base price $33,675), 2014 Mercedes-Benz CLA250 (base price $30,825); all prices include destination charges

Key Points:

• There's a huge rivalry between the 2015 Audi A3 and the 2014 Mercedes-Benz CLA250. the tussle is over bringing in younger buyers to the brand, which both Audi and Mercedes consider essential.
• Impressive standard features on the A3 include a panoramic sunroof, Bluetooth, LED daytime running lights, leather seats and leather-wrapped steering wheel, and bi-xenon headlights.
• The line will be beefed up even further in the coming months with models including the A3 TDI clean diesel and the Audi A3 Sportback e-tron plug-in hybrid.

• The A3 is a safety leader, offering several advanced tech features that are new to the entry-luxury segment, including the standard pre sense basic system that detects when an emergency maneuver is being made and prepares the car and its occupant restraint systems in advance of a possible crash.

• The 2015 A3 is the first Audi model to earn a Top Safety Pick or Top Safety Pick + award and the first to earn a Good or Acceptable rating in the small overlap front crash test by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.
• Connectivity is a major theme, especially as cars evolve into data centers on wheels. The A3 leads the pack.

• The A3 gets 4G LTE high-speed wireless connectivity through Audi Connect. Simply put, when passengers connect their mobile devices to the hot spot integrated into the A3, they can surf the Web independently of each other. For example, one can participate in a video conference while another watches a video. Audi Connect is standard on the top-end Prestige model, which costs $8,450 more than the base Premium. The midrange Premium Plus gets Audi Connect as part of a $2,600 MM Navigation plus package.
• Another feature found in the MMI Navigation plus package is a handwriting recognition system. The driver can trace letters on top of the controller knob (MMI) for navigation and music searches.
• Facebook and Twitter are “vehicle friendly,” with a text-to-speech function.
• Audi and AT&T have hooked up on two data plan options: $99 for six months and 5 GB, or $499 for thirty months and 30 GB. That works out to about $16.50 a month after a free six-month trial period.

pageElements.text: It was a long and auspicious Memorial Day weekend for car lovers everywhere, because of the Indianapolis 500. By the way, I never got around to watching it this year, but I’ve been to the Indy 500 many times and I love it, love it, love it.

The first time I went, I had no idea what to expect, although I’d been to many IndyCar races at Michigan International Speedway. Back when Roger Penske owned that tri-oval in Brooklyn, Michigan, I lived up the road less than ten miles away and spent a lot of time in the infield drinking beer, getting sunburned, and cheering for my favorite NASCAR and IndyCar drivers.
The noise of Indy cars when you’re clinging to the fence, the great cavalcade of weirdos both inside the infield and outside, was an amazing spectacle to be part of.

The first time I made it to Indy, I was standing outside the main gate in a crowd of people. When the gates opened, I was literally pressed up and off my feet for a brief second by the crowd surging in. It was terrifying despite the fact that I’m almost six feet tall.

My favorite visit to Indy was when Carroll Shelby gave me a ride in the Viper pace car.

But Indy is always great. The noise of Indy cars when you’re clinging to the fence, the great cavalcade of weirdos both inside the infield and outside along Sixteenth Street drinking beer, shouting at people, crowd watching, and, for the most part, acting kind of badly, was an amazing spectacle to see and be part of.
Somehow, TV coverage doesn’t do it justice.

And neither did the Formula 1 cars when they ran there. I went to the first Formula 1 Grand Prix at Indianapolis, in 2000, and noted that the crowd had better, more international T-shirts and they were more likely to be holding bottled water than cans of beer. It was a bizarrely quiet and well-behaved group wherever you went. Even the police on the corners directing traffic noticed it. Two cool things happened: one, I got in the elevator of my hotel to go to my room and found I was standing next to Michael Schumacher. It was a riveting moment. The second thing was a ride with the head of Jaguar in his car chauffeured by a local state patrolman. We were escorted at high speed via back roads by motorcycle cops on full-dresser Harleys right to the pits.

I sauntered up to the cops who were sitting on their bikes waiting to leave and taunted them about the prowess of the California Highway Patrol and their ability to do tricks with their Harleys including wheelies. Then I sauntered back to the car and got in. I knew something was up when the head of the motorcade came back and said to our driver, “Make sure you keep up with us,” and went back, and we were off.

We were halfway to the track when the last cop in the line suddenly stood up on his seat with his arms straight out, holding on to nothing, at about 70 mph. Before he sat down, he bent over and mooned me. He then sat down, and away we went. Another precious highlight of my young life. I was so proud that I had given the British head of Jag something to tell his mom, to whom he was speaking on the cell phone at the time it happened.
We only had to flop down the third row of the GMC Yukon XL to fit in two kennels. Stella rode, secured on the floor, between the two captain’s chairs in the second row.

Flash forward to where I was, which was in northern Michigan at our cabin, planting flowers. My husband and I usually drive up in separate vehicles. He takes our Chevrolet Suburban with all the dogs; I bring whatever SUV is at our office, or  sometimes sports cars if I don’t have any work to do up there. This time, I had a 2015 GMC Yukon XL, and we decided the whole family would go together. It was so exciting. We used the electric buttons in the back, and we only had to flop down the third row to fit in Bob and Ray's two kennels. Stella rode, secured on the floor, between the two captain’s chairs in the second row, and there was plenty of room for everything.

The 5.3-liter V-8 is one of GM’s new high-tech engines that has variable valve timing, spark ignition direct injection, and active fuel management that help make it powerful and yet very efficient. It is amazing how different it feels from our 2007 Suburban, which feels like it’s trundling along next to the new Yukon XL. I was kind of nervous about having my husband at the wheel because I could see a Yukon becoming our fourth Suburban.

After I got everybody out, I went to the greenhouse in nearby Grayling and completely packed the back with flats of perennials for the garden, which had been blown to smithereens by the winter of the century. The rhododendrons, the azaleas, and the hydrangeas, which all saw their best years last year, are mostly dead, but I’m holding out hope that a few signs of life in the form of  leaves will pop before I get back up there.

We have an old Jeep Wrangler that we keep in the barn, and we rode some trails and had a generally pleasant time driving around. It’s been a long time since my husband and I just hung out with nowhere to go and nothing to do. For twenty-four hours. Probably won’t see that again anytime soon.

We drove down early on Sunday to celebrate my mom’s ninetieth birthday. All my brothers and spouses came to her nursing home, where she announced to everyone that she was outraged when one of my sisters-in-law congratulated her on turning ninety. “What did you say?” she shouted. “I am not ninety. I am fifty-two.” You go, Mom.

The sing-along reached a crescendo with "Anchors Aweigh." Having been in the navy during World War II, she sang louder than anyone else and pumped her arms like she was marching. A happy mom is always a good mom.

On Memorial Day, the last day of our long weekend, we rode bicycles, which makes that twice in two years, and then I hauled out the Kubota from the pole barn for Ray the Stray’s evening run. There is no walking this dog enough to wear him out. Three to five miles an hour around about eighty of our acres just sends him straight back into his kennel, where he leaps into his swimming pool.

I love that Kubota so much, but it’s a little embarrassing, kind of like riding a Segway everywhere instead of walking. What I’d really like to do is teach the dogs how to ride in it with me. Stella, who’s now twelve years old, is game and actually made one trip with me. I got Bob to sit on the seat long enough to have a picture. But Ray will do nothing but run through the footwell and bark at it at the top of his lungs until I start rolling down the path. I guess that means he likes it as much as I do.

Love,
Jean

pageElements.text: As his creamy butterscotch leather passenger's seat envelops me and I listen to the inviting metronomic tick of his turn signal, Paul Fisher announces, “It’s a lot nicer to ride a Jaguar than the other way around. I prefer to stick my head in this Jaguar than the other kind.”
What?

Paul, a Florida art dealer, is perhaps the only Jaguar owner in the world to have been attacked by the actual big cat, whose bite is twice as strong as that of a lion, and survived. Paul has always been both a car guy and an animal aficionado, who nurtures two birds, a reptile and four (small) cats at home.

In 1983, Paul was working as a Connecticut park and forest law enforcement officer, protecting wildlife.  A desire for warmer weather took him to Dallas,  where he thought he’d further pursue police employment.  “But I just got lucky and happened to fall into a job selling rare and classic cars," he tells me. "It turns out I was a really good salesman. They had the franchises for Bertone and Pininfarina cars, which were the former Fiat Spider and the former Fiat X1/9.  I became the number-one salesman in America on those two cars.”

When an Aston Martin DB2 Mark II drophead in slate blue came his way,  “Dale Chihuly [the world-renowned glass sculptor], whom I had never heard of, bought the car and wanted me to help him assemble a collection of Aston Martins, every one from postwar to present, and I thought, that’s like a dream come true.  He had the money and the ambition, and I knew how to find the cars. And I had all these ex-cop, Sherlock Holmes reader tricks to finding cars. I would go to the library and look at old magazines and see who was selling what and figure out what got sold and go through old motor vehicle records and advertisements.”

Paul noticed that some classic car collectors were also collecting Chihuly’s artwork, and he began to sell the revolutionary glass sculptures as well as the often elusive automobiles. Paul eventually moved to West Palm Beach, Florida, where, “In 1999, I met Irina [now his wife] and wanted to spend all my time with her.“ Paul became a full-time art dealer, representing numerous artists, including Chihuly, at his eponymous gallery.

He recalls his encounter with the jaguar clearly. “On December 30, 2010, I got mauled by a jaguar at a big cat sanctuary. It was a freak accident where the cat had escaped. I had a moment of warning that the cat was dashing our way, and I put myself between the cat and somebody else because I thought, as I’d been around big cats before, I could handle it better.
The jaguar jumped me, landing on my head, sinking her fangs into my face, and tearing my face apart.

"It turned out I could. Most people who get pounced on by a jaguar die. She jumped me, landing on my head, sinking her fangs into my face, and tearing my face apart. Because I’d been a martial artist my whole life and had done yoga, as soon as she got me I was able to completely calm down and relax. I had turned so she couldn’t land on my neck," he goes on. "In around thirty seconds, they were able to get her off me.” Only a faint scar marks Paul’s left cheek.  “I had a terrific plastic surgeon,” he acknowledges.

The circumstances surrounding his Jaguar car purchase are equally vividly recalled: “A couple months after, I’m on eBay late at night and I see this fabulous car, a dark blue 1998 Jaguar Vanden Plas. I just adored that car but, being an enthusiast, I knew there was one that was better.“

Soon he found the 2002 Jaguar XJ Super V8 (X308), of which he says, “It is the absolute peak of evolution of the Jaguar four-door saloon, which I think is the best looking four-door ever made. Between 1997 and 2003, it was absolute perfection in form. It’s just gorgeous, a silver ocean blue.”

Paul’s car makes 370 horsepower from its supercharged 4.0-liter V-8. It has an extended wheelbase, four headlamps, and Computer Active Technology Suspension (CATS). Paul notes, “In 2002, they had all the performance upgrades they were going to have in later models including the DVD, navigation, better suspension, a warning system; with burled walnut trim, thick carpeting, and a sunroof that tilts and slides. The back seat has so much room, and it has mahogany tables (like elegant airplane trays).
This Jaguar is made so that if I am driving hard and fast and digging into corners, I don’t need to look at anything, I know where everything is.

"Of all the cars I’ve owned, including newer cars, it has probably the best sound system I’ve ever heard. And the clock is always on time, that analog clock with the beautiful Jaguar round face. Every control is beautifully laid out.

image.altText: pauls2002 jaguar super v8 vanden plas

pageElements.text: "This Jaguar is made so that if I am driving hard and fast and digging into corners, I don’t need to look at anything, I know where everything is.  I know exactly where the Sport button is.  It is laid out as well as possibly can be imagined. It’s made in England, and this is the last car that Jaguar as Jaguar completely designed, engineered, and built.”

And he has driven the XJ fast.  “When I first got it, I touched 130 on the way home.  I really wanted the supercharged engine because it was one of the fastest sedans in the world the year it came out, but I don’t really drive it that fast. At 130 it was rock solid, steady, no flow, no lift, no uncertainty or play in the wheel.  I think it’s 5.4 zero to sixty.”
Paul disputes Jag’s former reputation for requiring expensive repairs: “The secret to Jaguar is that it’s like a thoroughbred horse. As long as they are active, they are happy.”
