contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2015 Hyundai Genesis RWD 3.8

Base price: $38,950, inc. $950 destination charge
Price as tested: $38,950, including $950 destination charge. This is the base model with no options. Mid-level 2015 Hyundai Genesis 3.8 AWD starts at $41,450, including shipping. The top-of-the-line 2015 Hyundai Genesis 5.0 RWD starts at $52,450, including shipping. Note the jump to over $50K for the top-of-the-line model.
Genesis prices are creeping up. The base 2014 Hyundai Genesis starts at $36,120, inc. $920 destination charge. The top-of-the-line 2014 Hyundai Genesis R-Spec starts at $48,320, inc. shipping.
Fuel economy: 18 city/29 highway (311-hp 3.8-liter V6 engine; eight-speed automatic transmission)
Note: Worse fuel economy with new AWD model. 16 city/25 highway, according to EPA.
Safety: Not yet rated by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration; major coup in testing by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. The redesigned Genesis earned the Top Safety Pick+ award, scoring Good ratings in all IIHS crash tests and a Superior rating for front crash protection
The Genesis is one of only three large luxury cars to earn this award for 2014. The other two vehicles are the 2014 Acura RLX with the optional front crash prevention system and the 2014 Volvo S80
The IIHS said the Genesis earned the superior rating because of the automatic braking capabilities (previews autonomous driving) on the optional front crash prevention system. The system is being offered for the first time on the 2015 model.
Automatic Emergency Braking is part of a $3,500 3.8L Technology Package. The AEB system will initiate braking if it senses a car approaching at an unsafe speed.
Standard safety features on 2015 Genesis include nine airbags, inc. driver’s knee airbag, electronic stability control and anti-whiplash head restraints.
Chief competitors: 2014 Mercedes-Benz E-Class (base price $53,125, inc. $925 destination charge); 2014 BMW 528i (base price $50,425, inc. $925 destination charge); 2014 Cadillac CTS (base price $46,025, inc. $925 destination charge)

Key Points:

This is a major redesign of the Genesis, replacing the first version that bowed in 2009. Is this a true luxury contender? Now features a “statement” grille, contours patterned after the Audi A7 and BMW 5 Series.
It's roughly the same size as outgoing model, but many upgrades, including the first use of an AWD system in a Hyundai sedan. Where were you when we had two feet of snow on the ground?

Plus, lots of stuff you don’t see on the competition:
1)	Automatic trunk opening system that will pop the trunk if you stand next to the car for three seconds with the key in your pocket. Competitors have leg kick system. Hyundai allows you to keep both feet on ground with its system.

2)	Smartphone app that can remind you to get service or start the car remotely if it’s cold. Temperature outside vehicle is determined via Zip code prior to estimated departure time. User will receive phone notification is temp is above or below default level.
3) There is also an app that will interface with Google Glass if you use the wearable computer. Functions include remote vehicle start, remote Find My Car, call roadside assistance.

subTitle: Versatile eight-seater.

promoTeaser: Versatile eight-seater.
metaDescription: 2014 Honda Pilot: Versatile eight-seater. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The big and boxy Honda Pilot shares many of its qualities with its minivan cousin, the Odyssey.  The Pilot, however, falls squarely in SUV territory with its high stance, nicely tuned suspension and a serviceable five-speed V-6 that will tow up to 4,500 pounds when paired with the four-wheel drive.  Up to eight passengers can fit in three rows and still have 18 cubic feet of cargo space in the way back.  Fold the two passenger rows down and cargo space becomes nearly epic.  A recent and welcome tech upgrade brought new audio and media interfaces plus a rearview camera to modernize the driver’s experience.  Inside and out the look is pleasant but the strength of the Pilot is its utility, reliability and capable handling rather than standout styling presence.  In the asset column is that at 17 to 18 mpg in the city and 24 to 25 on the highway, the Pilot is the highest EPA-rated fuel economy for an eight passenger SUV.  Safety-wise the car is coated with high tech airbags and was rated in 2013 as an IIHS Top Safety Pick.  Expect to pay between $30,000 for the base two-wheel drive Pilot and $40,000 plus for all the bells and whistles, which will be prohibitive for some.  Neither showy nor ground-breaking the Pilot’s versatility has still won over loads of fans who will be looking forward to seeing what a 2015 redesign will add to their favorite SUV.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: Who would want a basic small sedan after seeing the cheeky 2016 Mazda CX-3?

This crossover, just introduced at the Los Angeles Auto Show, knocks your hat off with its great looks. Although it stands only 61 inches tall (the same height as Reese Witherspoon) and measures just over 14 feet long (as far as Reese Witherspoon can long jump), it has an extraordinary presence.

As Mazda Motor Europe designer Kevin Rice said, “No other vehicle in this category has such a long nose, compact cabin, and sits so strongly on its wheels.” And indeed, the 18-inch wheels do their part to embolden the CX-3.

Under the aforementioned long hood is an efficient 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine and six-speed automatic transmission, which promise vivid responsiveness. The CX-3 is a front-wheel-drive vehicle but can be ordered with an advanced all-wheel-drive system.

To create a large cargo area, engineers laid out a compact rear suspension. Inside the five-seat cabin, a relatively high quality of trim (this isn’t a Rolls-Royce) culminates with handsome parchment-and-black leather upholstery. There appears to be just the right combination of contemporary infotainment and radar-based safety technology to make the vehicle strongly competitive in its class.

But let’s get back to the great looks. “We wanted the design to convey an agile, nimble vehicle for crowded urban spaces,” Rice said. With such a combination of features and striking appearance, expect the CX-3 to fly out of dealerships.
The 2016 Mazda CX-3 goes on sale next summer.

pageElements.text: To improve the third-generation 2016 Audi TT Coupe and Roadster, CrossFit trainers evidently got involved in the development process.
At least, that’s how it appears upon looking at the cars, which made their North American debut at the Los Angeles Auto Show today.

Going back to Freeman Thomas’s original design, the TT was purely teardrop shaped. The new car remains so—but with pecs and quads. It’s ripped. And even as it gains muscle mass, this third-generation car is lighter than ever, weighing under 3,000 pounds. So, with a turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine making 220 horsepower, the TT races from 0 to 62 mph in just 5.3 seconds.
A dual-clutch automatic transmission performs smoothly and quickly in complicity with Audi’s standard Quattro all-wheel drive.

Sitting in the new TT Coupe, as I just did, pleases three of the five senses: touch, sight, and smell. The quilted leather seats are almost expected, given Audi’s level of interior quality. But wait! Where is the speedometer? The huge animated display filling the entire instrument panel can be almost endlessly reconfigured to advise and inform the driver.

But we must return to the TT’s refinement of the original design. Eyes narrowed and expressing intensity, it stands here, ready to brawl, on its 20-inch wheels and ultra-low-profile tires. The roofline slopes always to a tail that faintly suggests the Audi A8 supercar. And then there’s the Roadster, dominated by the creased beltline and wheels that say, “Just try it!”
It’s to die for.
The TT’s price point will be above $40,000 when it arrives midyear in 2015.

pageElements.text: An icon on par with Captain Sully or Seabiscuit, the Ford Shelby GT350 Mustang, originally introduced in 1965, made its return at the Los Angeles Auto Show.
And may we say that it quickened our hearts?

Thick blue stripes stretching over the white body have a way of doing that, of evoking American—and Ford—success in international sports car racing. Based on the new 2015 Mustang, the Shelby GT350 is a street-legal car also capable of storming around the racetrack. (Owning one may earn the enmity of your fellow car club members.)

At the core is a new 5.2-liter V-8 engine that even without turbo- or supercharging makes “more than 500 horsepower,” according to Ford—its most powerful naturally aspirated engine ever. Be ready to change gears with a six-speed manual transmission, while remaining assured of traction at the rear, thanks to a limited-slip differential.

Of course, the suspension and brakes are made to measure, to endure and enhance the oh-so-capable powertrain. Aerodynamic refinements further distinguish the GT350. Riding on specially engineered 19-inch aluminum alloy wheels and unique Michelin Pilot tires, it will grip the pavement like an ant crawling over the cupboard.
Chevrolet has brought back the Camaro Z-28, which is sensational. Now the GT350 rises to meet it.

pageElements.text: Seek huge and pillowy, and you’re usually led to the back of the home goods store, just beyond oversized bedding. But at the Los Angeles Auto Show, we wafted over to the presentation of the 2016 Mercedes-Maybach S600, which goes on sale in April. This is, Mercedes assures, "the world's quietest production sedan" and the most ultraluxurious member of the S-Class family.

There’s less Benz in this Mercedes and more cushion—as found in the executive rear seating area. The Maybach name invokes the marque that created limousines before World War II. In recent years, Mercedes’s parent company, Daimler-Benz, failed with a separate Maybach brand, but in typically stubborn German fashion, it is bringing back the glory in this new way. Mercedes-Maybach will be a sub-brand selling ultra-exclusive luxury cars "for customers for whom status is important."

Based on the Mercedes-Benz S-Class sedan, the Mercedes-Maybach S600 is powered by a twin-turbocharged 6.0-liter V-12 engine making 523 horsepower. Its force is so great, it could pull any of L.A.’s Art Deco buildings through a black hole into the postmodern era.

How large is it? At 214.6 inches, it’s shorter than a dual-cab Chevrolet pickup but longer than two Smart cars put end to end. The extra 8.1 inches it has over the mundane S-Class sedan (actually, one of the world’s greatest cars) goes into the back seat, where the Chinese ruling class and lucky kids from Beverly Hills do much of their business.

The woody, leathery cabin will be infused with its own exclusive Agarwood fragrance and cluttered with bubbles from the two silver-plated champagne flutes. This car doesn’t live behind a garage door. It sweeps from behind Door Number Three on Let’s Make a Deal and delivers you to your fantastic domain, whether it’s in Napa Valley or comes from cyberspace.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. pageElements.text: “Most of the customers we appeal to are looking for something that not everybody else is driving,” said Doug Murtha, Scion’s vice-president, after posing with the iM Concept at the Los Angeles Auto Show.

From the front, the five-door hatchback sneers. While big-brother Toyota division sucks the air out of the room with its well-focused mass-market cars, the Scion division directs the iM at individualists.

Although nothing specific was said about them at this introduction, the mechanical components aren’t special, but who cares? The most important specifications will be the size of its bass speaker and the price, which Murtha hoped would be under $20,000.

Whatever happens next will still get you to work in time to put on socks. (Yes, socks suck!) Meanwhile, you have a very practical car that’s nevertheless compellingly pocked and speckled in front, elongated in profile, and nearly as daring as Miley Cyrus in the back.

Cloaked in vivid blue with gray trim, the iM looks like lapis in silver. It's energy drink fervor in steel. Seeing it drive through the East Wing, President Obama might choke on his Nicorette gum. On the Harbor Freeway, street-sweeping trucks would bow down on their brushes.
The production iM will arrive at the New York Auto Show in April, and it will be available in dealerships later in 2015.

pageElements.text: We have to confess our disappointment with the 2016 Honda HR-V, which was introduced at the Los Angeles Auto Show. Yes, this new small crossover utility vehicle offers the right available features: heated leather seats, lane keeping assist, and a highly responsive seven-inch screen.

But having just glimpsed the 2016 Mazda CX-3 for the first time, how can we get stoked about the HR-V? Whereas the CX-3 commands the eye, we think the “V” in HR-V stands for “vanish.” Even within the Honda family, the HR-V is related to the Honda Fit but didn’t inherit any of its looks.

Price will be important, although Honda is keeping quiet about that until latter until next spring, when the vehicle goes on sale.
If your Aunt Myrtle asks about the HR-V, don’t try to dissuade her from buying it. But if your niece Caitlin seeks advice, tell her about the Mazda.

title: Your Wiper Blade 5-Point Plan
subTitle: Tips to help you celebrate Car Care Month, starting with these essentials up front.
promoTeaserSmall: Tips to help you celebrate Car Care Month, starting with these essentials up front.

pageElements.text: April is National Car Care Month, and to celebrate, Sears Auto called in world-famous "dirty windshield" artist Scott Wade to call attention to the glass in the front of your car. See it in Jean's related story, My Name Is Mud.
Wade's Dirty Car Art website is brilliant, and so is the work he created featuring Jean, but it's all to prove a point: you need to focus on the health of your wipers.

After a long winter, or just a lot of time since you last replaced wiper blades, you're driving at a disadvantage. Sears Auto's chain of 700 service facilities changes more than its share of them. Yet the company says more than 46 million cars on the road today have worn wiper blades. And, shameful fact, three-quarters of us only break down and change the blades when they become an actual hazard.
Don't be that way.
Here are five things you should do, and the reasons they make sense:

1. Replace your blades every six months.

Why? Because the blades need to be fresh to make firm contact with the windshield surface. Otherwise, they might streak, smear, or skip right when you need them most.

2. Have a good look at the windshield wiper assembly on a regular basis.

Why? There's a lot that can go wrong: for instance, detachment of the frame arms at joints or connection points, or even a broken wiper frame. Metal corrosion, particulalry at the joints. Visible cracks or tears in the rubber.

3. Is your rubber flexible? Find out.

Why? The squeegee part of the wiper needs to be flexible to conform to the windshield's shape. When it wears out, the edges can round off, the rubber loses that flexibility, and you can see streaks.

4. Are your blades loose? Find out.

Why? If it's not securely installed on the wiper arm, or secure in the frame, it is obviously not going to do the optimal job for you.

5. Take good care of your wipers in the first place.

Why? Preventive care is going to make those pricey blades last a little longer, after all. Wipe the rubber surfaces with a damp paper towel to keep dirt and oil from accumulating; keep your windshield clean (Sears recommends you wash the windshield every time you fill up the tank); and the big one for us Northerners, don't make your wipers do the ice scraping on frosty mornings. Use an ice scraper and the defroster for that.

pageElements.text: The first auto show in America was staged in New York City in 1900. To this day, it is one of the most heavily attended, which is most surprising because a paltry 23 percent of the population in Manhattan actually own a car.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/9oegDRCdqmY?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Jeff Curry, head of Jaguar marketing, told me, "New York is the center of culture in the U.S. It sets the tone in business and drives the consumer business. So as far as we are concerned, those 23 percent are influencers. It's definitely the center for high-end car buyers."

It's no surprise that those high-end buyers are buying European cars, and it's also no surprise that the New York show is the showplace for the European and British carmakers. They are, after all, just across the pond; New York is their closest port of entry.
Jaguar has had a showroom in New York since 1948 and debuted the classic E-Type to the U.S at the 1961 NY Show.

While New York is Jaguar's second largest U.S. market behind California, it is sister company Land Rover's biggest U.S. market. The first Land Rover dealership in the U.S. was opened in 1987, in New York City. You have to admit, any Land Rover is the perfect choice to handle Manhattan’s potholes on the way to the Met.

image.altText: New York Auto Show The Europeans

pageElements.text: Not one to shy away from a big New York party, Land Rover chose the deck of the legendary Intrepid aircraft carrier—which is now an air, sea, and space museum—to announce both its first global partner, Virgin Galactic, and its futuristic Discovery Vision Concept. It was a stunning juxtaposition to see the Virgin Galactic SpaceShipTwo alongside the futuristic Discovery Vision Concept on the deck of the Intrepid.

At the very least, it was the wildest new-car reveal I’ve ever seen. When I mentioned that to chief designer Gerry McGovern, he said: “Did you see my event at the Battersea Power Station? It was equally amazing. In that one, I literally walked on water!” He smiled at the very idea. Here’s a man with no confidence dilemma.

There were a few whispered comments about the Vision’s front end looking like a Ford Explorer, but the interior was jammed with whimsical future tech suggestions: technology that lets you see the rocks under the car and the depth of water you’re about to ford. It has seven highly configurable seats with backs that can be used as tables. The one-piece tailgate flips up, and a platform flips down, revealing rear-facing "social seating" and a stand-up platform. Armrests double as wheeled luggage, and a panoramic sunroof can change with a hand gesture from a view of the gloomy sky to an augmented-reality sky of your choosing. In fact, all of the Vision's glass is interactive and referred to as “Smart Glass,” a name a little too close to the disconnected Google-Glass-wearing zombies at the party for my taste.
Land Rover made it clear that the Discovery Vision Concept is not a replacement for the current Discovery, but its vision for a future Discovery family.

image.altText: New York Auto Show The Europeans

pageElements.text: I hit the Jag stand to present an Automobile Magazine All-Star trophy to the top dog at Jaguar, Joe Eberhard, for the F-Type roadster. Is there any car more beautiful than that Ian Callum-designed F-Type? Okay, maybe it’s his F-coupe. It looked particularly stunning in red.
Rounding out the Brit brands in New York: Rolls-Royce showed the turbo-6.6-liter V-12, two-tone Ghost II. Not so stunning.
Bentley wowed with a Continental GT Speed convertible, the fastest four-seat convertible ever, with a top speed of 203 mph. That’ll rip your rug off.

image.altText: New York Auto Show The Europeans

pageElements.text: And then there were the Euro exotics: The most anticipated was the Alfa Romeo 4C, signaling that venerable company’s return to America after a very, very long absence. The first Alfa 4C will hit our shores in June in the form of a special Launch Edition. There will only be 500, and most of them are already spoken for.

Tucked behind Maserati (which was celebrating its 100th anniversary with the new Ghibli), and across from the Aston Martin V8 Vantage GT (fresh from its Geneva Motor Show debut), you could find New York’s traditional smattering of supercars.

In quick succession, you could tick off a $2 million Bugatti Veyron Grand Sport Vitesse, a Lotus Evora, a $400,000 Lamborghini Aventador Roadster, and a very rare 273-mph Koenigsegg Agera R from Sweden, of all places.

image.altText: New York Auto Show The Europeans

pageElements.text: Last but certainly far from least, five German car companies are always heavily represented in New York. Mercedes-Benz rolled out its high-roller 577-hp 2015 S63 AMG Coupe.
VW wowed all present with the hot little Golf Sportwagen TDI Motion Concept. That one looked for all the world like it was ready for immediate production. Just add four-wheel drive. Please.

image.altText: New York Auto Show The Europeans

pageElements.text: I also handed out an Automobile Magazine All-Star to the mighty BMW 3 Series, its eighteenth, while gawking at the new 425-horsepower 4 Series convertible.

image.altText: New York Auto Show The Europeans

pageElements.text:
Porsche also got All-Star statuary for the Boxster and Cayman, and I got champagne. So that was a jolly stand.
 
As we left, Audi, which received its All-Star for the A7, our 2012 Automobile of the Year, was in the midst of tearing apart its press-day display to create an entirely new look for the public, scheduled to mob the place over spring holiday.

The East Coast appreciates the European carmakers as much as they love that show, and I always love to go to New York. With Automobile Magazine awarding four out of its ten All-Stars to European cars this year, it just made it an extra happy place for me to be.
All that's left to do is pick up the chocolate Easter Bunnies from Vosges Chocolate on Spring Street and head for home.

images.caption: Scene from the 2014 New York Auto Show.
Champagne with Porsche's Detlev von Platen as I hand out  Automobile Magazine All-Star awards for the Boxster and Cayman.
With Ludwig Willisch, BMW's U.S. chief. Automobile Magazine All-Star award goes to BMW's 3 Series (again).

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: When researching the Ford Mustang on the top of the Empire State building at the New York Auto Show I stumbled over this story about cars and the World’s Fair. And NBC made a video too showing now and then shots.
Why drive on four wheels? In fact, do you even need to pull over to change a tire?
This photo strikes me as odd. There is no driver and no one is staring at this $92,000 car stuck in the wet cement?
Car exercise program: if you own a car you don’t have an excuse not to work out anymore.
Ethiopia intersection without a traffic light. Balls of steel.
Greatest car chase ever. I got a little teary eyed.
Come on, Los Angeles, help fund this mobile slot car party. It sounds like a great idea.
Deep thoughts: are electric cars cleaner?
Spoiler alert: you will gasp and then you will laugh.

pageElements.text: Henrik Fisker, designer of BMWs, Aston Martins, and the beautiful but ill-fated Fisker Karma, had an idea for a Ford Mustang.
Fisker also had a collaborator in Beau Boeckmann, who says his Galpin Ford dealership in Los Angeles is the nation’s largest.

The Galpin Auto Sports spinoff took up Fisker’s project to transform a 2015 Ford Mustang GT with custom coachwork for low-volume production. Keeping the original doors and roof, Fisker designed replacement body panels, trying, as he said at the Los Angeles Auto Show, “to get the last emotion, a really sexy feeling out of the car.”
Meet the Fisker-Galpin Auto Sports 2015 Ford Mustang Rocket...but you can call it the Galpin Rocket.

The new carbon fiber bodywork exaggerates every edge and contour, with the result being tasteful and voluptuous. It’s as if your little brother got on the wrong bus and, instead of music camp, went to the bodybuilding one instead. Headlamps squint, fenders bulge, and scoops seem almost predatory.

Center caps on the 21-inch wheels bear the “HF” logo, and the Rocket label on the tail can be read at, let us say, some distance. Some exaggeration went on inside as well: a supercharger was added to the V-8 engine, increasing output to 725 horsepower.
“So it should be fast enough,” Fisker said.
Anyone who forgets that number need only look at the hood, where a bold graphic serves to remind of this fact.
While pricing wasn’t addressed, sales will begin early next year. On first seeing Fisker’s drawings, Boeckmann said, “My jaw dropped. I got chills.” Now we understand why.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. SafetyTec group adds advanced brake assist, lane departure warning with lane keeping assist, forward collision warning, and blind spot and cross-path detection.

Chief competitors:

2015 Ford Fusion (base price, $23,225, including $825 destination charge)
2015 Honda Accord sedan (base price $22,895, including $790 destination charge)
2015 Toyota Camry (base price $23,795, including $825 destination charge)
The 2015 Ford Fusion with a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine and six-speed automatic transmission returns 25 mpg in city driving and 37 mpg on the highway.
The 2015 Honda Accord with a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine and six-speed manual transmission returns 24 mpg in city driving and 34 mpg on the highway.
The 2015 Toyota Camry with a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine and six-speed automatic transmission returns 25 mpg in city driving and 35 mpg on the highway.

Key Points:

  • Chrysler is on a charm offensive with the 2015 Chrysler 200 in terms of styling.
  • The 200 is redesigned and all new for 2015, with nice proportions and droplet-shaped headlights.
  • The previous model was dowdy, with a low-rent interior. Can this one unseat the bestselling Camry?
  • The 2015 Chrysler 200 undercuts its three main competitors in the mid-size market in base price.
  • The rearview camera is optional on the base car, standard on 200C.

pageElements.text: With the Lexus LF-C2 Concept, unveiled at the Los Angeles Auto Show this week, the upscale Toyota brand proved it's in touch with the reason it exists: to provide us with an ethereal level of indulgence. This concept roadster is not likely to be the favorite of the sports-car purist, but l applaud Lexus's ambition to differentiate itself from the more mainstream-looking cars they make at Toyota.

That assertiveness is captured in the LF-C2 Concept, which gleamed in a multi-layer yellow paint treatment on the show floor. The color is polarizing in more ways than one, but I think it's just right for a show car, the better to show off the LF-C2's cool white-and-gray leather interior. There's no roof on this concept, giving a clear view of the interior with its central video monitor, remote touchpad on the center console, and old-school analog clock.
The LF-C2 concept previews what's expected to be a convertible version of the Lexus RC coupe.

Close your eyes and go to your happy place. You know, the one with a gleaming yellow sun presiding over a tree-lined, winding road in the southern French countryside. You're in a 2+2 roadster, and you don't know which part of that you enjoy most: the bursts of speed your roadster handles with aplomb, or the looks you get from envious passers-by when they get a glimpse of you in that luxurious leather interior when you stop. Love or hate the intensity of this concept with its massive grille and 20-inch tires, isn't it good to live in a world where these exist?

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: The Cadillac ATS is sweet to look at, to sit in, and to drive.
But more power wouldn’t hurt.

At the Los Angeles Auto Show, Cadillac gave us the ATS-V coupe and sedan, which are packing new heft under the hood. Or rather, generating 455 horsepower makes this twin-turbocharged V-6 the stoutest six-cylinder engine in any small sedan.

As Cadillac’s new president, Johan de Nysschen, said, it’s aimed at aficionados. They will have their choice between an eight-speed automatic transmission or an advanced six-speed manual gearbox that features no-lift shifting when the car is shrieking from 0 to 60 mph in just 3.9 seconds.

You know it’s the ATS-V when you see the 18-inch forged alloy wheels, which are lightweight but strong. (The Michelin Pilot tires were exclusively developed for the V.) You’ll also note vented bodywork, which de Nysschen assured is “functionally developed.” Third-generation Magnetic Ride Control intelligently modulates ride and handling responses, and killer Brembo brakes stop the car from its 189-mph top speed.
For those special track days, the ATS-V records high-definition video, then overlays lap times and other data for playback. How cool is that?

The midsize CTS-V has developed a big following over the years, and it’s easy to foresee the same happening with the ATS-V after it arrives in showrooms next spring. We can hardly wait to test it, and when they’re handing out the keys, we’re grabbing one for a coupe.

pageElements.text: Is it German blended with French and Italian? A synthesis of Esperanto and Estonian? The Audi Prologue concept car, revealed to our amazement and awe at the Los Angeles Auto Show, represents the brand’s future design language, and we desperately want to be immersed in it.

At the cutting edge of automotive style for years, Audi has courted the question: What can they do next? At once blunt and sleek, the Prologue forcefully persuades us that Audi has just been getting started.

Design chief Marc Lichte spoke of creating and releasing tension within body surfaces, and that is certainly going on. But he underplayed just how boldly masculine the concept is. The hood edge thrusts beyond the chin spoiler. The bladed grille is looking for rare steak. Long, sharp creases speak of defeating the wind, yes, but also of overcoming the ordinary. The 22-inch wheels and low-profile tires suggest the coupe pawed its way onto the turntable. Tall shoulders with a low helmet of a roof offer a hint of California custom. Did the magnetic poles swap places and mysteriously affect the design program? Oh, and the interior, equally a step forward, integrates touchscreen controls with the dashboard.
Then there’s the promise of 605 horsepower from 4.0 liters of engine to go with all-wheel drive.
“What’s past is prologue,” Shakespeare wrote. But this Prologue makes you forget the past and look forward to what's coming next.

pageElements.text: The 2016 Acura ILX has received significant technology upgrades and minor styling changes as Acura tries to boost its slow-selling, entry-level car. In doing so, two ILX powertrain choices are eliminated. The 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine and gas-electric hybrid are dropped from the mix in favor of the robust 2.4-liter four, which makes 201 hp, and the new, smooth-shifting eight-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission, which sport-minded drivers can operate manually with paddle shifters.

You’ll know you’re seeing the 2016 model when noting the standard five-module LED headlamps, which are shared with other Acuras, and the revised grille with a flaring center bar boldly proffering the Acura badge.

The designers also added LED taillamps. Included among three new trim levels (there are six in all), the racy A-SPEC package has foglamps, 18-inch wheels, and a rear spoiler. Inside the A-SPEC’s all-black cabin, suede inserts and gray stitching adorn the seats. Driver assistance and safety features available on all grades include adaptive cruise control and systems that help the car to avoid collisions and running off the road. The ILX Premium augments all of that with blind spot and rear cross traffic monitoring.
And here’s important news: the Premium’s heavily revised infotainment touchscreen now works better.
Yes, the ILX is loaded, and it’s more appealing than before. It does have an inner Honda Civic that's still visible, but for the many fans of the Civic, that may not be a bad thing.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: “Zoom-zoom.”
“Always the soul of a sports car.”

You would be embarrassed by Mazda’s goofy taglines if they weren’t such utterly perfect declarations of engineering intent. Pure and honest. Mazda designers have their own special declarations of intent. In 2010, Mazda adopted Kodo—soul of motion—to describe and inspire its design language.

Kodo is not sweet and smiley; it’s a powerful blend of aggressive and smooth forms and surfaces. When Derek Jenkins, Mazda’s soft-spoken North American director of design, approached the difficult task of infusing zoom-zoom into a smaller version of the popular CX-5 sport-utility vehicle, he studiously applied a little Kodo, and a star was born.

title: 5 Last-Minute Car-Themed Gifts
subTitle: Toys, books, jewelry, and wearables for anyone and everyone who loves cars as much as we do.

pageElements.text: If you're running behind on your shopping this year, well, that's what this guide is for. Here's something for just about everyone on your list, and you can order it all online in time for holiday giving (if you act quickly). Any of these gifts would be just as great for any occasion, or to keep for yourself.

1.

Especially this one: Jean loves her Crash by Minabea jewelry. Not just fabulous to look at, they have provenance: artist Christi Schimpke makes the bracelets out of crashed high-end European luxury cars. Jean's favorite, shown here, comes from a 2014 Mercedes-Benz SLK. Schimpke makes the jewelry by hand, using cold connections to preserve the original paint, in her studio, conveniently located in her husband's body shop in Los Angeles. Want one? Who wouldn't? The bracelets start at $65.

Want to hear more? Christi sent us images of this Ferrari Leopard Cuff, made from the metal of a crashed 458 Ferrari. She told us, "We etched the leopard pattern into the metal, added copper rivets to the 'spots,' created a setting from vintage brass with a black onyx stone, and lined the cuff with soft leather."

2.

Dwight Knowlton is a Friend of JKC, and we love everything he comes up with. His instant classic book, The Little Red Racing Car, is a must-buy for car lovers of any age. This hardcover picture book is currently on sale for an unbelievable $15.99.

But save his contact information for spring, when you'll also be able to get his Stirling Moss-themed children's book, The Greatest Race. Sir Stirling is collaborating on the book with him! This will be another indispensable purchase for sure.

Another instant classic: his "Plays with Cars" T-shirts, in adult and child sizes (both for $29.99). Shop for all Knowltoniana here.

3.

You've had your share of toy cars. We know you have. But nothing like these. You've got to gift the toy-car lover on your list with Automoblox, the best damn toy cars in the world. They're made of wood, with impeccable taste and interchangeable parts. There's even an aftermarket; you can visit the Automoblox Parts Department to shop for customizable parts like wheels. Jean was just looking at one of the latest from Automoblox's Patrick Calello, a three-pack of mini rescue vehicles. "The treads are designed, the wheels are designed," she marveled. So will you. Calello, also a Friend of JKC, is a car designer who studied industrial design at Carnegie Mellon, and it shows. The mini size start at $12, with three-packs starting at $30. The regular size start at $38. There's a special deal for holiday shoppers: Buy $100 worth, and get your cars signed by the designer.

4.

Modarri also makes great toy cars. This relatively new company (founded in 2013) is based in Santa Cruz, California. You can actually drive them, because they have a steering system, a tiny real suspension, and a bucket seat sized right for your finger to fit. "Whip the car in tight figure eights, do slalom racing, spin in a circle....do time trials!" the website promises (with a demo). Or put two fingers to work, and do wheelies and spinouts. Challenge accepted? $19.95 each, or a four-pack for $49.95.

5.

So many toy cars, so few roads to travel on. InRoad Toys makes rolls of highway and train track that rolls out like duct tape, sticks to any surface, and comes back up again without leaving a residue. It's called PlayTape, and it's awesome. The most fun part is that the founder created it when his car-mad three-year-old son, Brian, got a huge bucket of toy cars for Christmas and he realized there were no play roads to drive them on. (Brian's a teenager now, and he works on marketing for the company.) PlayTape comes in two-inch ($7.99) and four-inch ($12.99) widths, in various colors including orange and purple. I think I'd enjoy having this on my desk.

After smoldering for forty years, the embers of a unique motorcycling passion have finally rekindled flames with the introduction of the 2015 Ducati Scrambler.
Lightweight and inexpensive, the Scrambler revives a model produced from 1962 to 1975, a Ducati street bike modified for “scrambles” races on off-road circuits.

And indeed, as I found during the Scrambler’s press introduction in Palm Springs, California, it delivers the elemental riding experience. The narrow tank, upright seating, and long saddle made me remember my own first motorcycle of long ago.
“The Scrambler has been with Ducati for more than fifty years and has always been alive, like the coals under the ashes, if you will,” said Cristiano Silei, vice-president of sales and marketing.

As the Ducati Monster and other offerings have climbed the ladder in capability and price, the Scrambler’s return became inevitable. Starting at $8,495 for the base Icon model, it gives the brand a fresh entry-level product, appealing to new riders looking for distinction and to veteran ones returning to their roots.

What I lacked back in my earlier riding days was the Ducati mystique. This derived from racing success, brilliant technical developments (intricate “Desmodromic” valvetrains), and a signature orotund engine sound. Ducatis have remained rare on the ground, exotic in their makeup, and on the cutting edge of design.
It stands out in an era when bikes increasingly (and tediously) look like cyborgs. There is no aggression or menace here.

The new model approximates the simplicity of the 1993 Monster and the 1973 750 GT, as well as the first Scrambler. It stands out in an era when bikes increasingly (and tediously) look like cyborgs. There is no aggression or menace here. Instead, the Scrambler promises efficient mobility, friendly fun, and individual style.

And fun it definitely is. The air-cooled 803cc V-twin produces 75 horsepower and 50 pound-feet of torque. On the 375-pound (dry) bike, it’s like CrossFit muscle. Power delivery is smooth, going from docile to feral in a twist of the wrist.

When our group rode into the mountains near Palm Springs, I appreciated the Icon’s light action of the clutch and shifter when changing the six-speed transmission up and down. Banking the bike over for the tightest turns and holding my line was a trifling matter, like flicking away a fly. The wheels—18-inch front and 17-inch rear—wear modest Pirelli MT 60 RS tires with blocky treads, but grip was unwavering.

The Scrambler’s scant but well-chosen standard amenities also express simplicity. A single round LCD instrument combines speedometer, tachometer, odometer, time display, and turn signals. The LED headlamp and taillamp are unexpectedly premium features at this price. Crucially, antilock brakes are included. And under the seat, a USB socket powers a smartphone.
Beyond these features, the Scrambler can be upgraded with any of three trim levels, each with special logo and markings and priced at $9,995.
Classic: New York Fashion Week, anyone? The orange tank, wire-spoke wheels, and polished aluminum fenders live up to the name.
Urban Enduro: Suggests offroad capability with a green tank, spoked wheels, high front fender, headlamp grille, cross-braced handlebar, front fork guards, skid plate.

Full Throttle: Let’s do some mud-spattered laps at the Springfield Mile! It wears a black tank with yellow accents, tapered handlebar, tiny front (and no rear) fender, bobbed tail, and twin-outlet tailpipe.

Ducati offers a big selection of parts and apparel to encourage individualization. The gas tank’s side panels pop off in an instant; replacements come from a raft of choices. (My favorites flaunted bold red and green checks.) Saddlebags of vinyl or canvas and leather—all carrying the Scrambler logo—add character. High exhaust pipes will be available after the bike arrives in showrooms in April.

“One of the key values for the Ducati Scrambler brand is self-expression,” Silei told me. “When each one of us sees a Scrambler, they already see how they’re going to personalize it. The four versions are our way to give departure points where anyone can take a Scrambler and make it totally individual.”

BMW does something similar with the R nineT—more powerful, more expensive, less likable. Moto Guzzi has the V7, competitive in price but not performance. Otherwise, such a degree of variation is more common among jack-o-lanterns than motorcycles.

The Scrambler Icon’s main drawback is a saddle that becomes uncomfortable before an hour passes. The 31.1-inch seat height (a 30.3-inch low seat is available) was perfect for mid-size me but caused problems for a five-foot-two-inch rider, while one a foot taller complained of feeling cramped.
Beyond these minor issues, Ducati has fired a flaming arrow straight into the heart of the popular-price motorcycle market.

The Verdict:

A solid, conventional, stylish motorcycle: ideal for new riders, for anyone with the Mini Cooper mindset of individual expression, and for all who’ve longed for a Ducati. Katniss Everdeen would choose the Urban Enduro version, Becky Thatcher would go for the Classic, and Emma Bovary would place dibs on the Full Throttle.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: How many Mustang variants does the world need? you might ask. Well, it’s certainly going to be a brighter place with this Shelby GT350 coming along, powered as it is by a brand-new 5.2-liter, high-revving V-8, the most powerful (500-plus horsepower) normally aspirated engine ever found in a Mustang.

Performance cars are always fun for car designers. So after the 50th Anniversary Mustang made its debut with its beautiful new body, Moray Callum’s team reimagined that softer body as a hard-edged race car, wrapping the business end of GT350 in tight new aluminum front fenders and hood, aero-optimized and blending seamlessly back into the current sheetmetal.

pageElements.text: I am not driving through another dreadful Michigan winter in this big old 2007 Chevrolet Suburban without a set of winter tires.

It has four-wheel drive, which I thought was good enough. But then there was that night I was convinced we could go to town for a party, despite the raging snowstorm outside. We didn’t make it a mile before two cars in front of us slid off the two-lane and pirouetted into the ditches on either side of the road. We nearly executed a four-wheel-drive version of the same maneuver trying to stop.
Enough.

This year, I proposed a Real World Test of Bridgestone Blizzaks, as experienced by my aircraft-carrier-sized, zillion-pound four-wheel-drive Suburban. Bridgestone isn’t the only maker of winter tires. You can find them as well as many other choices at Tire Rack, America’s go-to online tire and wheel warehouse. Tire Rack is a non-denominational supplier of all good tire brands, and the company conducts its own independent tests, even going above the Arctic Circle to test winter tires. (Check their great videos at TireRack.com.)

Step One was entering make, model, and year of our vehicle in the middle of Tire Rack’s home page. Then we clicked on the Winter tab, which brought us to the Bridgestone Blizzaks Preferred Winter/Snow Tire & Wheel Package, priced at just over $1,000.

Tire Rack volunteered the tires and sent them mounted on a new set of rims (you can save money by using basic wheels—“steelies”). They were already balanced and fitted with a Tire Pressure Monitoring System (TPMS). A special jack and thin-wall socket for the deep-set lug nuts was included. I thought Tire Rack did all that as a special media favor. But the same courtesy is afforded any customer who orders the Preferred Winter/Snow Tire & Wheel Package.

My local garage, K&J Tire and Auto Repair in Jackson, Michigan, checked the tire pressures and mounted them on the Suburban, something I could have done in my garage. But I’d have gotten dirty. They tried to charge nothing. I bought them pizza.

I will come back over the course of the winter and report on our experience with the Blizzaks. I want to know how accurate (or annoying) the TPMS proves to be.

What about fuel economy, you ask? Don’t know. We will measure. Will the Suburban ride more roughly? Will the Blizzaks be louder? How will they wear?
All questions for the winter ahead. Send your own questions (and advice), and we will respond to all based on our Real World Testing.

Love,
Jean
